translated: By the practice of that and by higher non-attachment, there is the attainment of the superconscious concentration for those who desire liberation. This is the meaning.🔽For things, except for the power of consciousness, are subject to moment-to-moment change, according to the principle.

original: cittapariṇāmapravāhas tajjanyasaṃskārapravāhaś ca bhavaty evety abhipretya saṃskāraviśeṣa ity uktam /
analyzed: citta pariṇāma pravāhaḥ tad janya saṃskāra pravāhaḥ ca bhavati eva iti abhipretya saṃskāra viśeṣaḥ iti uktam
translated: With this in mind, it is said that there is a special impression, even in that state of cessation of all modifications of consciousness.

original: tasya ca saṃskārasya prayojanam uktam tataḥ praśāntavāhitā saṃskārāt YogaS / iti /
analyzed: tasya ca saṃskārasya prayojanam uktam tatas praśāntavāhitā saṃskārāt yogas iti
translated: And the purpose of that impression is stated: From that, the yoga of tranquil flow is due to the impression.

original: praśāntavāhitā nāmāvṛttikasya cittasya nirindhanāgnivat pratilomapariṇāmenopaśamaḥ /
analyzed: praśāntavāhitā nāma avṛttikasya cittasya nirindhana agni vat pratiloma pariṇāmena upaśamaḥ
translated: Tranquil flow is the cessation of the mind that is free from modifications, like a fire without fuel, by a reverse transformation.

original: yathā samidājyādyāhutiprakṣepe vahnir uttarottaravṛddhyā prajvalati /
analyzed: yathā samidh ājya ādi āhuti prakṣepe vahniḥ uttarottara vṛddhyā prajvalati
translated: Just as when oblations of kindling, ghee, etc. are offered, the fire blazes with increasing intensity.

original: samidādikṣaye tu prathamakṣaṇe kiṃcic chāmyati /
analyzed: samidh ādi kṣaye tu prathama kṣaṇe kiṃcid śāmyati
translated: But when the fuel, etc., are destroyed, something is pacified in the first moment.

original: uttarottarakṣaṇeṣu tv adhikam adhikaṃ śāmyatīti krameṇa śāntir vardhate /
analyzed: uttara uttara kṣaṇeṣu tu adhikam adhikam śāmyati iti krameṇa śāntiḥ vardhate
translated: In the subsequent moments, however, it is pacified more and more, so the pacification increases gradually.

original: tathā niruddhacittasyottarottarādhikaḥ praśamaḥ pravahati /
analyzed: tathā niruddha cittasya uttara uttara adhikaḥ praśamaḥ pravahati
translated: Similarly, the pacification of the mind that has ceased flows on more and more.

original: tatra pūrvapraśamajanitaḥ saṃskāra evottarottarapraśamasya kāraṇam /
analyzed: tatra pūrva praśama janitaḥ saṃskāraḥ eva uttarottara praśamasya kāraṇam
translated: There, the impression produced by the previous pacification is itself the cause of the subsequent pacification.

original: tadā ca nirindhanāgnivac cittaṃ krameṇopaśāmyadvyutthānasamādhinirodhasaṃskāraiḥ saha svasyāṃ prakṛtau līyate /🔽tadā ca samādhiparipākaprabhavena vedāntavākyajena samyagdarśanenāvidyāyāṃ nivṛttāyāṃ taddhetukadṛgdṛśyasaṃyogābhāvād vṛttau pañcavidhāyām
analyzed: tadā ca nirindhana agni vat cittam krameṇa upaśāmyat vyutthāna samādhi nirodha saṃskāraiḥ saha svasyām prakṛtau līyate  tadā ca samādhi paripāka prabhavena vedānta vākya jena samyak darśanena avidyāyām nivṛttāyām tad hetuka dṛś dṛśya saṃyoga abhāvāt vṛttau pañcavidhāyām
translated: Then, like a fire without fuel, the mind gradually becomes pacified and dissolves into its own nature along with the impressions of withdrawal, concentration, and cessation.

original: api nivṛttāyāṃ svarūpapratiṣṭhaḥ puruṣaḥ śuddhaḥ kevalo mukta ity ucyate /
analyzed: api nivṛttāyām svarūpa pratiṣṭhaḥ puruṣaḥ śuddhaḥ kevalaḥ muktaḥ iti ucyate
translated: Then, when ignorance ceases due to the perfect knowledge born from the Vedanta texts, which is produced by the maturity of concentration, due to the absence of the union of the seer and the seen caused by that, and also when the five kinds of modifications cease, the person established in his own nature is said to be pure, solitary, and liberated.

original: tad uktaṃ tadā draṣṭuḥ svarūpe 'vasthānam YogaS / iti /
analyzed: tat uktam tadā draṣṭuḥ svarūpe vasthānam yogaḥ iti
translated: That is said: Then, the seer abides in his own nature - that is concentration.

original: tadā sarvavṛttinirodhe /
analyzed: tadā sarva vṛtti nirodhe
translated: Then, when all modifications cease.

original: vṛttidaśāyāṃ tu nityāpariṇāmicaitanyarūpatvena tasya sarvadām śuddhatve 'py anādinā
analyzed: vṛtti daśāyām tu nitya apariṇāmi caitanya rūpa tvena tasya sarva dām śuddha tve pi anādinā
translated: But in the state of activity, although it is always pure by being of the nature of eternal, unchanging consciousness, due to the superimposition of identity with the internal organ caused by the beginningless

original: dṛśyasaṃyogenāvidyakenāntaḥkaraṇatādātmyādhyāsād antaḥkaraṇavṛttisārūpyaṃ prāpnuvan
analyzed: dṛśya saṃyogena āvidyakena antaḥkaraṇa tādātmya adhyāsāt antaḥkaraṇa vṛtti sārūpyam prāpnuvan
translated: association with the visible world, which is unreal, it assumes the likeness of the modifications of the internal organ.

original: nabhoktāpi bhokteva duḥkhānāṃ bhavati /
analyzed: na bhoktā api bhoktā iva duḥkhānām bhavati
translated: Although not the experiencer, it becomes as if the experiencer of sufferings.

original: tad uktaṃ vṛttisārūpyam itaratra YogaS /
analyzed: tat uktam vṛtti sārūpyam itaratra yogaḥ
translated: This is stated: Yoga is the likeness of modifications in the other.

original: itaratra vṛttiprādurbhāve /
analyzed: itaratra vṛtti prādurbhāve
translated: In the other, in the manifestation of modifications.

original: etad eva vivṛttaṃ draṣṭṛdṛśyoparaktaṃ cittaṃ sarvārtham YogaS / cittam eva
analyzed: etat eva vivṛttam draṣṭṛ dṛśya uparaktam cittam sarva artham yogaḥ cittam eva
translated: This itself is explained: Yoga is the mind endowed with all objects, which is the mind tinged with the seer and the seen. The mind

original: draṣṭṛdṛśyoparaktaṃ viṣayiviṣayanirbhāsaṃ cetanācetanasvarūpāpannaṃ viṣayātmakam
analyzed: draṣṭṛ dṛśya uparaktam viṣayi viṣaya nirbhāsam cetana acetana svarūpa āpannam viṣaya ātmakam
translated: itself, tinged with the seer and the seen, appearing as the subject and the object, having assumed the nature of the conscious and the insentient, is of the nature of objects.

original: apy aviṣayātmakam ivācetanam api cetanam iva sphaṭikamaṇikalpaṃ sarvārtham ity ucyate /
analyzed: api aviṣaya ātmakam iva acetanam api cetanam iva sphaṭika maṇi kalpam sarva artham iti ucyate
translated: Although not of the nature of objects, it is said to be endowed with all objects, like a crystal gem, although insentient, as if conscious.

original: tad anena cittasārūpyeṇa bhrāntāḥ kecit tad eva cetanam ity āhuḥ /
analyzed: tat anena citta sārūpyeṇa bhrāntāḥ kecid tat eva cetanam iti āhuḥ
translated: Deluded by this likeness of the mind, some say that it itself is conscious.

original: tad asaṃkhyeyavāsanācitram api parārthaṃ saṃhatyakāritvāt YogaS / /
analyzed: tat asaṃkhyeya vāsanā citram api para artham saṃhatya kāri tvāt yogaḥ
translated: Although variegated with innumerable latent impressions, it is for the sake of another, because it acts collectively. Yoga is thus.

original: yasya bhogāpavargārthaṃ tat sa eva paraś cetano 'saṃhataḥ puruṣo na tu ghaṭādivat saṃhatyakāri cittaṃ cetanam ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: yasya bhoga apavarga artham tat saḥ eva paraḥ saṃhataḥ puruṣaḥ na tu ghaṭa ādi vat saṃhatya kāri cittam cetanam iti arthaḥ
translated: The one who is for the sake of the enjoyment and liberation of that [puruṣa] is the supreme, non-composite, conscious puruṣa, not the conscious mind which acts by aggregation like a pot, etc. This is the meaning.

original: evaṃ ca viśeṣadarśina ātmabhāvabhāvanāvinivṛttiḥ YogaS / /
analyzed: evam ca viśeṣa darśinaḥ ātma bhāva bhāvanā vinivṛttiḥ yogaḥ
translated: And thus, yoga is the cessation of the conception of the self in the internal organ for one who sees the distinction [between the self and the internal organ].

original: evaṃ yo 'ntaḥkaraṇapuruṣayor viśeṣadarśī tasya yāntaḥkaraṇe prāgavivekavaśād ātmabhāvabhāvanāsīt
analyzed: evam yaḥ ntaḥkaraṇa puruṣayoḥ viśeṣa darśī tasya yā antaḥkaraṇe prāk aviveka vaśāt ātma bhāva bhāvanā āsīt
translated: Thus, for one who sees the distinction between the internal organ and the self, the conception of the self in the internal organ which previously arose due to the absence of discrimination

original: sā nivartate /
analyzed: sā nivartate
translated: ceases.

original: bhedadarśane saty abhedabhramānupapatteḥ /
analyzed: bheda darśane sati abheda bhrama anupapatteḥ
translated: Because when the distinction is seen, the superimposition of non-distinction is not possible.

original: sattvapuruṣayor viśeṣadarśanaṃ ca bhagavadarpitaniṣkāmakarmasādhyam /
analyzed: sattva puruṣayoḥ viśeṣa darśanam ca bhagavat arpita niṣkāma karma sādhyam
translated: And the seeing of the distinction between sattva and puruṣa is accomplished by the worship of the Lord and by actions without desire for results.

original: talliṅgaṃ ca yogabhāṣye darśitam /🔽yathā prāvṛṣi tṛṇāṅkurasyodbhedena tadbījasattānumīyate thatā mokṣamārgaśravaṇena
analyzed: tad liṅgam ca yogabhāṣye darśitam  yathā prāvṛṣi tṛṇa aṅkurasya udbhedena tad bīja sattā anumīyate tha tā mokṣa mārga śravaṇena
translated: And that indication is shown in the Yoga Bhāṣya.🔽Just as the existence of a seed is inferred from the sprouting of a grass shoot in the rainy season,

original: siddhāntarucivaśād yasya lomaharṣāśrupātau dṛśyete tatrāpy asti viśeṣadarśanabījam
analyzed: siddhānta ruci vaśāt yasya loma harṣa aśru pātau dṛśyete tatra api asti viśeṣa darśana bījam
translated: in the same way, when one hears about the path to liberation, and horripilation and tears are seen due to the inclination towards the conclusion, there also exists the seed of the seeing of the distinction [between the self and the internal organ].

original: apavargamārgīyaṃ karmābhinirvartitam ity anumīyate /
analyzed: apavarga mārgīyam karma abhinirvartitam iti anumīyate
translated: It is inferred that the action which is the path to final beatitude has been performed.

original: yasya tu tādṛśaṃ karmabījaṃ nāsti tasya mokṣamārgaśravaṇe pūrvapakṣayuktiṣu rucir bhavaty aruciś ca siddhāntayuktiṣu /
analyzed: yasya tu tādṛśam karma bījam na asti tasya mokṣa mārga śravaṇe pūrvapakṣa yuktiṣu ruciḥ bhavati aruciḥ ca siddhānta yuktiṣu
translated: But for one who does not have such a seed of karma, when hearing the path of liberation, there is interest in the arguments of the prima facie view and disinterest in the arguments of the conclusion.

original: tasya ko 'ham āsaṃ katham aham āsam ity ādir ātmabhāvabhāvanā svābhāvikī pravartate /
analyzed: tasya kaḥ ham āsam katham aham āsam iti ādiḥ ātma bhāva bhāvanā svābhāvikī pravartate
translated: For him, the natural contemplation of the self arises, beginning with Who was I?, How was I?, and so on.

original: sā tu viśeṣadarśino nivartata iti /
analyzed: sā tu viśeṣa darśinaḥ nivartate iti
translated: But that is averted for one who sees the distinction.

original: evaṃ sati kiṃ syād iti tad āha tadā vivekanimnaṃ kaivalyaprāgbhāraṃ cittam YogaS / /
analyzed: evam sati kim syāt iti tat āha tadā viveka nimnam kaivalya prāgbhāram cittam yogaḥ
translated: When this is so, what would happen? He says that then the mind, inclined towards discrimination and inclined towards isolation, is yoga.

original: nimnaṃ jalapravahaṇayogyo nīcadeśaḥ /
analyzed: nimnam jala pravahaṇa yogyaḥ nīca deśaḥ
translated: Inclined means a low place suitable for the flow of water.

original: prāgbhāras tadayogya uccapradeśaḥ /
analyzed: prāgbhāraḥ tad ayogyaḥ ucca pradeśaḥ
translated: Inclined towards means an unsuitable high place.

original: cittaṃ ca sarvadā pravartamānavṛttipravāheṇa pravahajjalatulyaṃ tat prāgātmānātmāvivekarūpavimārgavāhiviṣayabhogaparyantam asyāsīt
analyzed: cittam ca sarvadā pravartamāna vṛtti pravāheṇa pravahat jala tulyam tat prāk ātma anātma aviveka rūpa vimārga vāhi viṣaya bhoga paryantam asya āsīt
translated: And the mind, always flowing with the current of active states, is like flowing water. Its flow was previously towards the objects of enjoyment that carry the wrong path in the form of the discrimination of self and not-self.

original: adhunā tv ātmānātmavivekamārgavāhikaivalyaparyantaṃ sampadyata iti /
analyzed: adhunā tu ātma anātma viveka mārga vāhi kaivalya paryantam sampadyate iti
translated: But now it is accomplished towards isolation, which carries the path of the discrimination of self and not-self.

original: asmiṃś ca vivekavāhini citte ye 'ntarāyās te sahetukā nivartanīyā ity āha sūtrābhyām tacchidreṣu pratyayāntarāṇi saṃskārebhyaḥ /
analyzed: asmin ca viveka vāhini citte ye ntarāyāḥ te sa hetukāḥ nivartanīyāḥ iti āha sūtrābhyām tad chidreṣu pratyaya antarāṇi saṃskārebhyaḥ
translated: And in this mind flowing towards discrimination, the hindrances along with their causes should be removed. This is stated by two sūtras: The other conditions arise from the formations through the gaps in that [mind].

original: hānam eṣāṃ kleśavad uktam YogaS / /
analyzed: hānam eṣām kleśa vat uktam yogaḥ
translated: The destruction of these is said to be like the destruction of the afflictions by yoga.

original: tasmin vivekavāhini citte chidreṣv antarāleṣu pratyayāntarāṇi vyutthānarūpāṇy ahaṃ mamety evaṃrūpāṇi vyutthānānubhavajebhyaḥ saṃskārebhyaḥ
analyzed: tasmin viveka vāhini citte chidreṣu antarāleṣu pratyaya antarāṇi vyutthāna rūpāṇi aham mama iti evaṃrūpāṇi vyutthāna anubhava jebhyaḥ saṃskārebhyaḥ
translated: In that mind flowing towards discrimination, the other conditions, which are the forms of distraction, such as I and mine, arise from the formations born of the experience of distraction,

original: kṣīyamāṇbhyo 'pi prādurbhavanti /
analyzed: kṣīyamāṇbhyaḥ pi prādurbhavanti
translated: even though they are being destroyed.

original: eṣāṃ ca saṃskārāṇāṃ
analyzed: eṣām ca saṃskārāṇām
translated: And the destruction of these formations

original: kleśānām iva hānam uktam /
analyzed: kleśānām iva hānam uktam
translated: is said to be like the destruction of the afflictions.

original: yathā kleśā avidyādayo jñānāgninā dagdhabījabhāvā ca punaś cittabhūmau prarohaṃ prāpnuvanti tathā jñānāgninā dagdhabījabhāvāḥ saṃskārāḥ
analyzed: yathā kleśāḥ avidyā ādayaḥ jñāna agninā dagdha bīja bhāvā ca punar citta bhūmau praroham prāpnuvanti tathā jñāna agninā dagdha bīja bhāvāḥ saṃskārāḥ
translated: Just as the afflictions such as ignorance, when their seed-like nature is burned by the fire of knowledge, do not sprout again in the field of the mind, in the same way, the formations, when their seed-like nature is burned by the fire of knowledge,

original: pratyayāntarāṇi na praroḍhum arhanti /
analyzed: pratyaya antarāṇi na praroḍhum arhanti
translated: are not able to sprout from the other conditions.

original: jñānāgnisaṃskārās tu yāvac cittam anuśerata iti /
analyzed: jñāna agni saṃskārāḥ tu yāvat cittam anuśerate iti
translated: But the formations that are burned by the fire of knowledge continue to influence the mind.

original: evaṃ ca pratyayāntarānudayena vivekavāhini citte sthirībhūte sati prasaṃkhyāne 'py
analyzed: evam ca pratyaya antara anudayena viveka vāhini citte sthirībhūte sati prasaṃkhyāne pi
translated: And thus, when the mind flowing towards discrimination becomes stable due to the non-arising of the other conditions, even in conceptualization,

original: akusīdasya sarvathāvivekakhyāter dharmameghaḥ samādhiḥ YogaS / prasaṅkhyānaṃ
analyzed: akusīdasya sarvathā viveka khyāteḥ dharmameghaḥ samādhiḥ yogaḥ prasaṅkhyānam
translated: The Yoga is the concentration called Dharmamegha, of one who is not lazy, who has the knowledge of complete isolation in every way.

original: sattvapuruṣānyatākhyātiḥ śuddhātmajñānam iti yāvat /
analyzed: sattva puruṣa anya tā khyātiḥ śuddha ātma jñānam iti yāvat
translated: Discrimination is the knowledge of the pure Self, i.e., the knowledge of the difference between the Spirit and the Nature.

original: tatra buddheḥ sāttvike pariṇāme kṛtasaṃyamasya sarveṣāṃ guṇapariṇāmānāṃ svāmivad
analyzed: tatra buddheḥ sāttvike pariṇāme kṛta saṃyamasya sarveṣām guṇa pariṇāmānām svāmi vat
translated: There, for one who has practiced concentration on the sattvika modification of the intellect, there is the conquest of all the modifications of the gunas, as if they were his own servants,

original: ākramaṇaṃ sarvādhiṣṭhātṛtvaṃ teṣām eva ca śāntoditāvyapadeśyadharmitvena sthitānāṃ
analyzed: ākramaṇam sarva adhiṣṭhātṛ tvam teṣām eva ca śānta udita avyapadeśya dharmi tvena sthitānām
translated: and the lordship over all, and the knowledge of them as they are, as having the nature of being tranquil, manifest, and indescribable,

original: yathāvad vivekajñānaṃ sarvajñātṛtvaṃ ca viśokā nāma siddhiḥ phalaṃ tadvairāgyāc
analyzed: yathāvat viveka jñānam sarvajñātṛ tvam ca viśokā nāma siddhiḥ phalam tad vairāgyāt
translated: and the omniscience, which is the result called Vishoka, and from detachment from that,

original: ca kaivalyam uktaṃ sattvapuruṣānyatākhyātimātrasya sarvabhāvādhiṣṭhātṛtvaṃ
analyzed: ca kaivalyam uktam sattva puruṣa anya tā khyāti mātrasya sarva bhāva adhiṣṭhātṛ tvam
translated: liberation, which is said to be the Yoga of the mere knowledge of the difference between the Spirit and the Nature, the lordship over all things,

original: sarvajñātṛtvaṃ ca YogaS / sattvapuruṣayoḥ śuddhisāmye kaivalyam YogaS / iti sūtrābhyām /
analyzed: sarvajñātṛ tvam ca yogaḥ sattva puruṣayoḥ śuddhi sāmye kaivalyam yogaḥ iti sūtrābhyām
translated: and the omniscience, and the liberation when the purity of the Nature and the Spirit is equal, which is said in the two aphorisms.

original: tad etad ucyate tasmin prasaṅkhyāne saty apy akusīdasya phalam alipsoḥ pratyayāntarāṇām
analyzed: tat etat ucyate tasmin prasaṅkhyāne sati api akusīdasya phalam alipsoḥ pratyaya antarāṇām
translated: This is said: Even when that discrimination exists, for one who is not lazy, who does not desire the result, and who is free from other conditions,

original: anudaye sarvaprakārair vivekakhyāteḥ paripoṣād dharmameghaḥ samādhir bhavati /
analyzed: anudaye sarva prakāraiḥ viveka khyāteḥ paripoṣāt dharmameghaḥ samādhiḥ bhavati
translated: When there is no rising of the modifications, then, by the nourishment of the manifestation of discrimination in all ways, the concentration called Dharmamegha arises.

original: ijyācāradamāhiṃsādānasvādhyāyakarmaṇām /
analyzed: ijyā ācāra dama ahiṃsā dāna svādhyāya karmaṇām
translated: Worship, conduct, self-control, non-violence, giving, self-study, and action -

original: ayaṃ tu paramo dharmo yad yogenātmadarśanam // iti smṛteḥ //
analyzed: ayam tu paramaḥ dharmaḥ yat yogena ātma darśanam iti smṛteḥ
translated: But this is the highest dharma: the realization of the Self through yoga, according to the Smriti.

original: dharmaṃ pratyagbrahmaikyasākṣātkāraṃ mehati siñcatīti dharmameghas tattvasākṣātkārahetur ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: dharmam pratyak brahma aikya sākṣātkāram mehati siñcati iti dharmameghaḥ tattva sākṣātkāra hetuḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: It is called Dharmamegha because it rains, i.e., pours down, the dharma, which is the direct realization of the identity of the individual self with Brahman. The meaning is that it is the cause of the direct realization of reality.

original: tataḥ kleśakarmanivṛttiḥ /
translated: Then there is the cessation of afflictions and actions.

original: tato dharmameghāt samādher dharmād vā kleśānāṃ pañcavidhānām avidyāsmitārāgadveṣābhiniveśānāṃ
analyzed: tatas dharma meghāt samādheḥ dharmāt vā kleśānām pañcavidhānām avidyā asmitā rāga dveṣa abhiniveśānām
translated: Then, from that concentration called Dharmamegha or from that dharma, there is the cessation of the five kinds of afflictions - ignorance, conceit, attachment, aversion, and clinging,

original: karmaṇāṃ ca kṛṣṇaśuklakṛṣṇaśuklabhedena trividhānām avidyāmūlānām avidyākṣaye
analyzed: karmaṇām ca kṛṣṇa śukla kṛṣṇa śukla bhedena trividhānām avidyā mūlānām avidyā kṣaye
translated: and of the three kinds of actions, which are divided into black, white, and mixed, and which have ignorance as their root.

original: bījakṣayād ātyantikī nivṛttiḥ kaivalyaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: bīja kṣayāt ātyantikī nivṛttiḥ kaivalyam bhavati
translated: By the destruction of ignorance, there is absolute cessation, which is liberation, due to the destruction of the seeds.

original: kāraṇanivṛttyā kāryanivṛtter ātyantikyā ucitatvād ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: kāraṇa nivṛttyā kārya nivṛtteḥ ātyantikyāḥ ucita tvāt iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it is proper that the effect should cease by the cessation of the cause.

original: evaṃ sthite yuñjann eva sadātmānam ity anena samprajñātaḥ samādhir ekāgrabhūmāv uktaḥ /
analyzed: evam sthite yuñjan eva sat ātmānam iti anena samprajñātaḥ samādhiḥ ekāgra bhūmau uktaḥ
translated: Thus, when this is the case, by the statement one who is always engaged in yoga, the concentration with mental constructs is stated to be on the stage of one-pointedness.

original: niyatamānasa ity anena tatphalabhūto 'samprajñātasamādhir nirodhabhūmāv uktaḥ /
analyzed: niyata mānasaḥ iti anena samprajñāta samādhiḥ nirodha bhūmau uktaḥ
translated: By 'with a controlled mind', the result of that, the superconscious concentration, is stated to be in the state of cessation.

original: śāntim iti nirodhasamādhijasaṃskāraphalabhūtā praśāntavāhitā /🔽nirvāṇaparamam iti dharmameghasya samādhes tattvajñānadvārā kaivalyahetutvaṃ /
analyzed: śāntim iti nirodha samādhi ja saṃskāra phala bhūtā praśānta vāhitā  nirvāṇa paramam iti dharmameghasya samādheḥ tattva jñāna dvārā kaivalya hetu tvam
translated: 'Tranquility' is the state of being completely calm, which is the result of the impressions born of the superconscious concentration.

original: matsaṃsthām ity anenaupaniṣadābhimataṃ kaivalyaṃ darśitam /
analyzed: mad saṃsthām iti anena aupaniṣada abhimatam kaivalyam darśitam
translated: 'Having final beatitude in Me' shows the absolute freedom as accepted by the Upanisads.

original: yasmād evaṃ mahāphalo yogas tasmāt taṃ mahatā prayatnena sampādayed ity abhiprāyaḥ ////
analyzed: yasmāt evam mahā phalaḥ yogaḥ tasmāt tam mahatā prayatnena sampādayet iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: By this, the meaning is that since Yoga has such great results, therefore one should accomplish it with great effort.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha:

original: ātmānaṃ mano yuñjan dhyānayogayuktaṃ kurvan /
analyzed: ātmānam manaḥ yuñjan dhyāna yoga yuktam kurvan
translated: One should unite the mind with the Self, make it fit for the yoga of meditation.

original: yato niyatamānaso viṣayoparatacittaḥ /
analyzed: yatas niyata mānasaḥ viṣaya uparata cittaḥ
translated: Because one has a controlled mind, one whose mind is detached from objects.

original: nirvāṇo mokṣa eva paramaḥ prāpyo yasyāṃ mayy eva nirviśeṣabrahmaṇi samyak sthā sthitir yasyāṃ tāṃ śāntiṃ saṃsāroparatiṃ prāpnoti ////
analyzed: nirvāṇaḥ mokṣaḥ eva paramaḥ prāpyaḥ yasyām mayi eva nirviśeṣa brahmaṇi samyak sthā sthitiḥ yasyām tām śāntim saṃsāra uparatim prāpnoti
translated: One attains that peace, the cessation of worldly existence, which has final beatitude, which is to be attained, in Me alone, in Brahman without distinctions, where there is perfect stability.

original: baladevaḥ / evam āsīnasya kiṃ syāt tad āha yuñjann iti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ evam āsīnasya kim syāt tat āha yuñjan iti
translated: Balarama: What happens to one who sits thus? The Lord says, 'uniting' etc.

original: yogī sadā pratidinam ātmānaṃ yuñjann arpayan /
analyzed: yogī sadā pratidinam ātmānam yuñjan arpayan
translated: The yogi, always, every day, uniting, dedicating, the Self.

original: niyatamānasaḥ matsparśapariśuddhatayā niyataṃ niścalaṃ mānasaṃ cittaṃ yasya sa /
analyzed: niyata mānasaḥ mad sparśa pariśuddha tayā niyatam niścalam mānasam cittam yasya sa
translated: He whose mind is controlled, by the purity brought about by contact with Me, has a mind that is controlled, that is steady.

original: matsaṃsthāṃ madadhīnāṃ nirvāṇaparamāṃ śāntim adhigacchati labhate /
analyzed: mad saṃsthām mad adhīnām nirvāṇa paramām śāntim adhigacchati labhate
translated: He attains the supreme peace, which is dependent on Me, which has final liberation as its highest goal.

original: tam eva viditvātimṛtyum eti ŚvetU / ity ādi śravaṇāt /
analyzed: tam eva viditvā atimṛtyum eti śvetu iti ādi śravaṇāt
translated: For it is heard: Having known Him alone, one goes beyond death, O Śveta (Śvet Up. 6).

original: nirvāṇaparamāṃ mokṣāvadhikām iti siddhayo 'pi yogaphalānīty uktam ////
analyzed: nirvāṇa paramām mokṣa avadhikām iti siddhayaḥ api yoga phalāni iti uktam
translated: The supreme peace is the highest goal, beyond liberation. Thus it is said that even the perfections are the fruits of yoga.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: Bhagavadgita

original: nātyaśnatas tu yogo 'sti na caikāntam anaśnataḥ /
analyzed: na atyaśnataḥ tu yogaḥ sti na ca ekāntam an aśnataḥ
translated: For one who eats too much, there is no yoga, nor for one who eats only a little.

original: na cātisvapnaśīlasya jāgrato naiva cārjuna ////
analyzed: na ca ati svapna śīlasya jāgrataḥ na eva ca arjuna
translated: Nor for one who is excessively sleepy, nor for one who is always awake, O Arjuna.

original: śrīdharaḥ / yogābhyāsaniṣṭhasyāhārādiniyamam āha nātyaśanata iti dvyābhyām /
translated: Sridhar: He states the rules regarding food etc. for one who is devoted to the practice of yoga with the two verses beginning with not for one who eats too much.

original: atyantam adhikaṃ bhuñjānasya ekāntam atyantam abhuñjānasyāpi yogaḥ samādhir na bhavati /
analyzed: atyantam adhikam bhuñjānasya ekāntam atyantam a bhuñjānasya api yogaḥ samādhiḥ na bhavati
translated: Yoga, concentration, does not exist for one who eats excessively, nor for one who eats only a little.

original: tathātinidrāśīlasyātijāgrataś ca yogo naivāsti ////
analyzed: tathā ati nidrā śīlasya ati jāgrataḥ ca yogaḥ na eva asti
translated: Similarly, yoga does not exist for one who is excessively sleepy, nor for one who is always awake.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana:

original: evaṃ yogābhyāsaniṣṭhasyāhārādiniyamam āha nātyaśanata iti dvyābhyām /
analyzed: evam yoga abhyāsa niṣṭhasya āhāra ādi niyamam āha na ati aśanataḥ iti
translated: Thus, he states the rules regarding food etc. for one who is devoted to the practice of yoga with the two verses beginning with not for one who eats too much.

original: yad bhuktaṃ sajjīryati śarīrasya ca kāryakṣamatāṃ sampādayati tadātmasaṃmitam annaṃ tad atikramya lobhenādhikam aśnato na yogo 'sti ajīrṇadoṣeṇa
analyzed: yat bhuktam sat jīryati śarīrasya ca kārya kṣama tām sampādayati tat ātma saṃmitam annam tat atikramya lobhena adhikam aśnataḥ na yogaḥ sti ajīrṇa doṣeṇa
translated: That food which, when eaten, is digested and makes the body capable of performing its functions, is equal to the self. Beyond that, for one who eats more out of greed, there is no yoga,

original: vyādhipīḍitatvāt /
analyzed: vyādhi pīḍita tvāt
translated: because one is afflicted by disease due to indigestion.

original: na caikāntam anaśnato yogo 'sti /
analyzed: na ca ekāntam an aśnataḥ yogaḥ sti
translated: And for one who eats absolutely nothing, there is no yoga.

original: anāhārād atyalpāhārād vā rasapoṣaṇābhāvena śarīrasya kāryākṣamatvāt /
analyzed: anāhārāt ati alpa āhārāt vā rasa poṣaṇa abhāvena śarīrasya kārya akṣama tvāt
translated: Because due to lack of food or very little food, the body becomes incapable of performing its functions due to lack of nourishment.

original: yad u ha vā ātmasaṃmitam annaṃ tad avati tan na hinasti yad bhūyo hinasti tad yat kanīyo 'nnaṃ na tad avati ŚatapathaB / / / iti śatapathaśruteḥ
analyzed: yat u ha vai ātma saṃmitam annam tat avati tat na hinasti yat bhūyas hinasti tat yat kanīyaḥ nnam na tat avati śatapathap iti śatapatha śruteḥ
translated: For it is said in the Shatapatha Brahmana: That food which is equal to the self sustains it and does not harm it. That which is more harms it. That which is less food does not sustain it.

original: tasmād yogī nātmasaṃmitād annād adhikaṃ nyūnaṃ vāśnīyād ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: tasmāt yogī na ātma saṃmitāt annāt adhikam nyūnam vā aśnīyāt iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, the meaning is that a yogi should not eat more or less than the food equal to the self.

original: athavā
analyzed: athavā
translated: Or else,

original: pūrayed aśanenārdhaṃ tṛtīyam udakena tu /
analyzed: pūrayet aśanena ardham tṛtīyam udakena tu
translated: one should fill half with food, one-third with water,

original: vāyoḥ saṅcaraṇārthaṃ tu caturtham avaśeṣayet //
analyzed: vāyoḥ saṅcaraṇa artham tu caturtham avaśeṣayet
translated: and leave the fourth for the movement of air.

original: ity ādi yogaśāstroktaparimāṇād adhikaṃ nyūnaṃ vāśnato yogo na sampadyata ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: iti ādi yoga śāstra ukta parimāṇāt adhikam nyūnam vā aśnataḥ yogaḥ na sampadyate iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that for one who eats more or less than the quantity stated in the Yoga scriptures, yoga does not succeed.

original: tathātinidrāśīlasyātijāgrataś ca yogo naivāsti he 'rjuna sāvadhāo bhavety abhiprāyaḥ /
analyzed: tathā ati nidrā śīlasya ati jāgrataḥ ca yogaḥ na eva asti he rjuna sa avadhāaḥ bhava iti abhiprāyaḥ
translated: Similarly, O Arjuna, there is no yoga at all for one who is excessively sleepy or excessively wakeful. The idea is that you should be attentive.

original: yathā mārkaṇḍeyapurāṇe
analyzed: yathā mārkaṇḍeyapurāṇe
translated: As it is said in the Markandeya Purana:

original: nādhmātaḥ kṣudhitaḥ śrānto na ca vyākulacetanaḥ /
analyzed: na ādhmātaḥ kṣudhitaḥ śrāntaḥ na ca vyākula cetanaḥ
translated: Not puffed up, not hungry, not tired, not with a disturbed mind,

original: yuñjīta yogaṃ rājendra yogī siddhyartham ātmanaḥ //
analyzed: yuñjīta yogam rāja indra yogī siddhi artham ātmanaḥ
translated: the yogi should practice yoga, O lord of kings, for the sake of his own perfection.

original: nātīśīte na caivoṣṇe na dvandve nānilānvite /
analyzed: na ati śīte na ca eva uṣṇe na dvandve na anila anvite
translated: Not in excessive cold, nor in heat, nor in extremes, nor in windy conditions,

original: kāleṣv eteṣu yuñjīta na yogaṃ dhyānatatparaḥ // ity ādi ////
analyzed: kāleṣu eteṣu yuñjīta na yogam dhyāna tatparaḥ iti ādi
translated: in these times, one devoted to meditation should not practice yoga.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha:

original: yogābhyāsaniṣṭhasya niyamam āha nātyaśanata iti dvyābhyām /
analyzed: yoga abhyāsa niṣṭhasya niyamam āha na ati aśanataḥ iti
translated: He states the rules for one who is devoted to the practice of yoga with the two verses beginning with not by excessive eating.

original: atyaśnato 'dhikaṃ bhuñjānasya / yad uktaṃ
analyzed: atyaśnataḥ dhikam bhuñjānasya yat uktam
translated: For one who eats excessively, who eats too much. As it is said:

original: pūrayed aśanenārdhaṃ tṛtīyam udakena tu /
analyzed: pūrayet aśanena ardham tṛtīyam udakena tu
translated: One should fill half the stomach with food, one-third with water,

original: vāyoḥ saṅcaraṇārthaṃ tu caturtham avaśeṣayet // iti ////
analyzed: vāyoḥ saṅcaraṇa artham tu caturtham avaśeṣayet iti
translated: and leave one-fourth for the movement of the wind.🔽Balarama:

original: baladevaḥ / yogam abhyasyato bhojanādiniyamam āha nātīti dvyābhyām /🔽atyaśanam anatyaśanaṃ ca /
analyzed: atyaśanam an atyaśanam ca
translated: He states the rules for eating and so on for one who is practicing yoga with the two beginning with not excessively.🔽Excessive eating and not excessive eating.

original: atisvāpo 'tijāgaraś ca /
analyzed: ati svāpaḥ ti jāgaraḥ ca
translated: Excessive sleep and excessive wakefulness.

original: yogavirodhyativihārādi cottarāt ////
analyzed: yoga virodhi ativihāra ādi ca uttarāt
translated: And excessive indulgence etc. which are contrary to yoga, from the next verse.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: yuktāhāravihārasya yuktaceṣṭasya karmasu /
analyzed: yukta āhāra vihārasya yukta ceṣṭasya karmasu
translated: For one who has regulated food and recreation, regulated activity in work,

original: yuktasvapnāvabodhasya yogo bhavati duḥkhahā ////
analyzed: yukta svapna avabodhasya yogaḥ bhavati duḥkha hā
translated: regulated sleep and waking, yoga becomes the destroyer of suffering.

original: śrīdharaḥ / tarhi kathambhūtasya yogo bhavatīti /
analyzed: bhavati iti
translated: Shridhar: Then, what kind of person does yoga become?

original: ata āha yuktāhāreti /
analyzed: atas āha yukta āhāra iti
translated: Therefore, it is said regulated food and so on.

original: yukto niyata āhāro vihāraś ca gatir yasya /
analyzed: yuktaḥ niyataḥ āhāraḥ vihāraḥ ca gatiḥ yasya
translated: One whose food and recreation are regulated, limited.

original: karmasu kāryeṣu yuktā niyatā ceṣṭā yasya /
analyzed: karmasu kāryeṣu yuktā niyatā ceṣṭā yasya
translated: One whose activity in work, in tasks, is regulated, limited.

original: yuktau niyatau svapnāvabodhau nidrājāgarau yasya /
analyzed: yuktau niyatau svapna avabodhau nidrā jāgarau yasya
translated: One whose sleep and waking, one's sleep and being awake, are regulated, limited.

original: tasya duḥkhanivartako yogo bhavati sidhyati ////
analyzed: tasya duḥkha nivartakaḥ yogaḥ bhavati sidhyati
translated: For him, yoga becomes the remover of suffering, becomes successful.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana:

original: evam āhārādiniyamavirahiṇo yogavyatirekam uktvā tanniyamavato yogānvayam āha yuktāhāra iti /
analyzed: evam āhāra ādi niyama virahiṇaḥ yoga vyatirekam uktvā tad niyamavataḥ yoga anvayam āha yukta āhāraḥ iti
translated: Having thus stated the absence of yoga for one devoid of regulation of food etc., he says the presence of yoga for one with such regulation, with regulated food and so on.

original: āhriyata ity āhāro 'nnam /
analyzed: āhriyate iti āhāraḥ nnam
translated: Food is that which is eaten.

original: viharaṇaṃ vihāraḥ pādakramaḥ /
analyzed: viharaṇam vihāraḥ pāda kramaḥ
translated: Recreation is walking.

original: tau yuktau niyataparimāṇau yasya /
analyzed: tau yuktau niyata parimāṇau yasya
translated: One whose food and recreation are regulated, limited.

original: tathānyeṣv api praṇavajapopaniṣadāvartanādiṣu karmasu yuktā niyatakālā ceṣṭā yasya /
analyzed: tathā anyeṣu api praṇava japa upaniṣad āvartana ādiṣu karmasu yuktā niyata kālā ceṣṭā yasya
translated: Similarly, one whose activity in other rites such as the repetition of the Pranava, the recitation of the Upanishads, is regulated, limited in time.

original: tathā svapno nidrā avabodho jāgaraṇaṃ tau yuktau niyatakālau yasya tasya yogo bhavati /
analyzed: tathā svapnaḥ nidrā avabodhaḥ jāgaraṇam tau yuktau niyata kālau yasya tasya yogaḥ bhavati
translated: Similarly, sleep and waking are united with him who has fixed hours for sleep and waking.

original: sādhanapāṭavād ātmasamādhiḥ sidhyati nānyasya /
analyzed: sādhana pāṭavāt ātma samādhiḥ sidhyati na anyasya
translated: By the excellence of the means, the concentration of the self is accomplished, not for anyone else.

original: evaṃ prayantaviśeṣeṇa sampādito yogaḥ kiṃphala iti tatrāha duḥkhaheti /
analyzed: evam sampāditaḥ yogaḥ kiṃphalaḥ iti tatra āha duḥkha hā iti
translated: Thus, yoga accomplished by the specific means, what is its fruit? There, he says: the cause of suffering.

original: sarvasaṃsāraduḥkhakāraṇāvidyonmūlanahetubrahmavidyotpādakatvāt samūlasarvaduḥkhanivṛttihetur ity arthaḥ /
translated: Because it produces the knowledge of Brahman, which is the cause of uprooting ignorance, which is the cause of all worldly suffering, it is the cause of the cessation of all suffering along with its roots. This is the meaning.

original: atrāhārasya niyatatvam /
analyzed: atra āhārasya niyata tvam
translated: Here, the restriction on food is stated.

original: ardham aśanasya savyañjanasya tṛtīyam udakasya tu /
analyzed: ardham aśanasya sa vyañjanasya tṛtīyam udakasya tu
translated: Half of the food with condiments, one-third of water,

original: vāyoḥ saṃcāraṇārthaṃ tu caturtham avaśeṣayet //
analyzed: vāyoḥ saṃcāraṇa artham tu caturtham avaśeṣayet
translated: And the fourth part should be left for the movement of air.

original: ity ādi prāg uktam /
analyzed: iti ādi prāk uktam
translated: This and more has been stated earlier.

original: vihārasya niyatatvaṃ yoganān na paraṃ gacched ity ādi /
analyzed: vihārasya niyata tvam yoganāt na param gacchet iti ādi
translated: The restriction on recreation is stated as one should not go beyond the prescribed limit in yoga and so on.

original: karmasu ceṣṭāyā niyatatvaṃ vāgādicāpalaparityāgaḥ /
analyzed: karmasu ceṣṭāyāḥ niyata tvam vāc ādi cāpala parityāgaḥ
translated: And the restriction on activity is the avoidance of the fickleness of speech and so on.

original: rātrer vibhāgatrayaṃ kṛtvā prathamānyayor jāgaraṇaṃ madhye svapanam iti svapnāvabodhayor niyatakālatvam /
analyzed: rātreḥ vibhāga trayam kṛtvā prathama anyayoḥ jāgaraṇam madhye svapanam iti svapna avabodhayoḥ niyata kāla tvam
translated: Having divided the night into three parts, the first two for staying awake and the middle for sleeping, the fixed times for sleep and waking are stated.

original: evam anye 'pi yogaśāstroktā niyamā draṣṭavyāḥ ////
analyzed: evam anye pi yoga śāstra uktāḥ niyamāḥ draṣṭavyāḥ
translated: Similarly, other observances mentioned in the Yoga scriptures should be understood.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha:

original: yukto niyata evāhāro bhojanaṃ vihāro gamanaṃ ca yasya tasya karmasu vyavahārikapāramārthikakṛtyeṣu yuktā niyatā eva ceṣṭā vāgvyāpārādyā 🔽yasya tasya ////
analyzed: yuktaḥ niyataḥ eva āhāraḥ bhojanam vihāraḥ gamanam ca yasya tasya karmasu vyavahārika pāramārthika kṛtyeṣu yuktāḥ niyatāḥ eva ceṣṭāḥ vāc vyāpāra ādyā  yasya tasya
translated: One who has regulated food and movement, whose activities in worldly and spiritual matters are regulated, and whose speech and other actions are regulated,🔽he is the one who is fit for yoga.

original: baladevaḥ / yukteti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ yuktā iti
translated: Balarama:

original: mitāhāravihārasya karmasu laukikapāramārthikakṛtyeṣu mitavāgādivyāpārasya mitasvāpajāgarasya ca sarvaduḥkhanāśako yogo bhavati tasmād
analyzed: mita āhāra vihārasya karmasu laukika pāramārthika kṛtyeṣu mita vāc ādi vyāpārasya mita svāpa jāgarasya ca sarva duḥkha nāśakaḥ yogaḥ bhavati tasmāt
translated: Yoga, which destroys all suffering, is for one who has limited food and movement, whose speech and other actions are limited, and whose sleep and wakefulness are limited, in worldly and spiritual matters. Therefore,

original: yogī tathā tathā vartate ////
analyzed: yogī tathā tathā vartate
translated: the yogi acts in such a way.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: Bhagavad Gita

original: yadā viniyataṃ cittam ātmany evāvatiṣṭhate /
analyzed: yadā viniyatam cittam ātmani eva avatiṣṭhate
translated: When the restrained mind abides in the Self alone,

original: niḥspṛhaḥ sarvakāmebhyo yukta ity ucyate tadā ////
analyzed: niḥspṛhaḥ sarva kāmebhyaḥ yuktaḥ iti ucyate tadā
translated: then he is said to be united, being free from desire for all objects of desire.

original: śrīdharaḥ / kadā niṣpannayogaḥ puruṣo bhavatīty apekṣāyām āha yadeti /
translated: Sridhar: When there is a desire to know when a person becomes perfected in yoga, it is said yada (when).

original: viniyataṃ viśeṣeṇa niruddhaṃ saccittam ātmany eva yadā niścalaṃ tiṣṭhati /
analyzed: viniyatam viśeṣeṇa niruddham sat cittam ātmani eva yadā niścalam tiṣṭhati
translated: When the restrained mind, which is especially checked, abides in the Self alone, motionless,

original: kiṃ ca sarvakāmebhya aihikāmuṣmikabhogebhyo niḥspṛho vigatatṛṣṇo bhavati /
analyzed: kim ca sarva kāmebhyaḥ aihika āmuṣmika bhogebhyaḥ niḥspṛhaḥ vigata tṛṣṇaḥ bhavati
translated: Moreover, he becomes free from desire, free from craving, for all objects of desire, for the enjoyments of this world and the next.

original: tadā muktaḥ prāptayoga ity ucyate ////
analyzed: tadā muktaḥ prāpta yogaḥ iti ucyate
translated: Then he is called liberated, attained to yoga.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: evam ekāgrabhūmau samprajñātaṃ samādhim abhidhāya nirodhabhūmāv asamprajñātaṃ samādhiṃ vaktum upakramate yadeti /🔽yadā yasmin kāle paravairāgyavaśād viniyataṃ viśeṣeṇa niyataṃ sarvavṛttiśūnyatām
analyzed: evam ekāgra bhūmau samprajñātam samādhim abhidhāya nirodha bhūmau asamprajñātam samādhim vaktum upakramate yadā iti  yadā yasmin kāle para vairāgya vaśāt viniyatam viśeṣeṇa niyatam sarva vṛtti śūnyatām
translated: Having thus described samprajnata samadhi on the stage of one-pointedness, he begins to describe asamprajnata samadhi on the stage of cessation with the words 'when'.🔽When, at what time, due to the power of supreme detachment, the mind, made especially fixed, becomes devoid of all modifications,

original: āpāditaṃ cittaṃ vigatarajastamaskam antaḥkaraṇasattvaṃ svacchatvāt sarvaviṣayākāragrahaṇasamartham🔽api sarvatoniruddhavṛttikatvād ātmany eva pratyak citi anātmānuparakte vṛttirāhitye
analyzed: āpāditam cittam vigata rajaḥ tamaskam antaḥkaraṇa sattvam svaccha tvāt sarva viṣaya ākāra grahaṇa samartham  api sarvatas niruddha vṛttika tvāt ātmani eva pratyak citi anātma anuparakte vṛtti rāhitye
translated: and the sattva of the internal organ, free from rajas and tamas, becomes capable of grasping the forms of all objects due to its clarity,🔽even though all modifications are completely stopped, in the self alone, in the opposite cognition not attached to the non-self,

original: 'pi svataḥsiddhasyātmākārasya vārayitum aśakyatvāc citer eva prādhānyān nyagbhūtaṃ
analyzed: pi svatas siddhasya ātma ākārasya vārayitum aśakya tvāt citeḥ eva prādhānyāt nyagbhūtam
translated: even though there is absence of modifications, the form of the self, which is self-established, cannot be prevented, and because cognition is primary,

original: sad avatiṣṭhate niścalaṃ bhavati /
analyzed: sat avatiṣṭhate niścalam bhavati
translated: it remains hidden, becomes motionless.

original: tadā tasmin sarvavṛttinirodhakāle yuktaḥ samāhita ity ucyate /
analyzed: tadā tasmin sarva vṛtti nirodha kāle yuktaḥ samāhitaḥ iti ucyate
translated: Then, at that time, when all modifications cease, he is called 'yukta', 'absorbed'.

original: kaḥ / yaḥ sarvakāmebhyo niḥspṛhaḥ /🔽nirgatā doṣadarśanena sarvebhyo dṛṣṭādṛṣṭaviṣayebhyaḥ kāmebhyaḥ spṛhā tṛṣṇā yasyeti paraṃ vairāgyam asamprajñātasamādher
analyzed: kaḥ yaḥ sarva kāmebhyaḥ niḥspṛhaḥ  nirgatā doṣa darśanena sarvebhyaḥ dṛṣṭa adṛṣṭa viṣayebhyaḥ kāmebhyaḥ spṛhā tṛṣṇā yasya iti param vairāgyam asamprajñāta samādheḥ
translated: Who? He who is free from all desires.

original: antaraṅgaṃ sādhanam uktam /
analyzed: antaraṅgam sādhanam uktam
translated: He who has no desire, no craving, for all visible and invisible objects of desire, by seeing their faults, has supreme non-attachment, which is said to be an internal means for the superconscious concentration.

original: tathā ca vyākhyātaṃ prāk ////
analyzed: tathā ca vyākhyātam prāk
translated: And it has been explained before thus.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: yogī niṣpannayogaḥ kadā bhaved ity ākāṅkṣāyām āha yadeti /
analyzed: yogī niṣpanna yogaḥ kadā bhavet iti ākāṅkṣāyām āha yadā iti
translated: When will the yogi attain perfected yoga? Anticipating this question, he says 'when'.

original: viniyataṃ niruddhaṃ cittam ātmani svasminn evāvatiṣṭhate niścalībhavatīty arthaḥ ////
analyzed: viniyatam niruddham cittam ātmani svasmin eva avatiṣṭhate niścalībhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: The mind, restrained and controlled, rests in the Self itself, the meaning is that it becomes steady.

original: baladevaḥ / yogī niṣpannayogaḥ kadā syād ity apekṣāyām āha yadeti /
translated: Baladeva. Anticipating the question 'when will the yogi attain perfected yoga?', he says 'when'.

original: yogam abhyasyato yoginaś cittam yadā viniyataṃ niruddhaṃ sadātmany eva svasminn evāvasthitaṃ sthiraṃ bhavati /
analyzed: yogam abhyasyataḥ yoginaḥ cittam yadā viniyatam niruddham sat ātmani eva svasmin eva avasthitam sthiram bhavati
translated: When the mind of the yogi, who is practicing yoga, becomes restrained and controlled, and rests in the Self itself, in its own nature, and becomes steady,

original: tadātmetarasarvaspṛhāśūnyo yukto niṣpannayogaḥ kathyate ////
analyzed: tad ātma itara sarva spṛhā śūnyaḥ yuktaḥ niṣpanna yogaḥ kathyate
translated: then, being devoid of all desires for anything other than the Self, he is said to be one who is in union, who has attained perfected yoga.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: Bhagavad Gita

original: yathā dīpo nivātastho neṅgate sopamā smṛtā /
analyzed: yathā dīpaḥ nivāta sthaḥ na iṅgate sā upamā smṛtā
translated: Just as a lamp in a windless place does not flicker, that is said to be the simile,

original: yogino yata cittasya yuñjato yogam ātmanaḥ ////
analyzed: yoginaḥ yata cittasya yuñjataḥ yogam ātmanaḥ
translated: Of the yogi whose mind is restrained, who is practising yoga for the attainment of the Self.

original: śrīdharaḥ / ātmaikyākāratayāvasthitasya cittasyopamānam āha yatheti /
analyzed: āha   iti
translated: Śrīdhara: An analogy is given for the mind which abides in the form of oneness with the Self, with the words 'just as' etc.

original: vātaśūnye deśe sthito dīpo yathā neṅgate na vicalati /
analyzed: vāta śūnye deśe sthitaḥ dīpaḥ yathā na iṅgate na vicalati
translated: Just as a lamp placed in a place free from wind does not flicker, does not move.

original: sopamā dṛṣṭāntaḥ /
analyzed: sā upamā dṛṣṭāntaḥ
translated: This is the analogy, the example.

original: kasya / ātmaviṣayaṃ yogaṃ yuñjato 'bhyasyato yoginaḥ /
analyzed: kasya ātma viṣayam yogam yuñjataḥ bhyasyataḥ yoginaḥ
translated: Of whom? Of the yogi who is practising, who is cultivating, yoga which has the Self as its object.

original: yataṃ niyataṃ cittaṃ yasya tasya niṣkampatayā prakāśakatayā cācañcalaṃ tac cittaṃ tadvat tiṣṭhatīty arthaḥ ////
analyzed: yatam niyatam cittam yasya tasya niṣkampa tayā prakāśaka tayā ca acañcalam tat cittam tadvat tiṣṭhati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that his mind, which is restrained, controlled, remains unmoving, like a lamp, by virtue of its illuminating nature.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana:

original: samādhau nivṛttikasya cittasyopamānam āha yatheti /
analyzed: samādhau nivṛttikasya cittasya upamānam āha yathā iti
translated: An analogy is given for the mind which has ceased to function in samadhi, with the words 'just as' etc.

original: dīpacalanahetunā vātena rahite deśe sthito dīpo yathā calanahetvabhāvān neṅgate na calati /
analyzed: dīpa calana hetunā vātena rahite deśe sthitaḥ dīpaḥ yathā calana hetu abhāvāt na iṅgate na calati
translated: A lamp placed in a place free from wind, which is the cause of the lamp's movement, does not flicker, does not move, because there is no cause for movement.

original: sopamā smṛtā sa dṛṣṭāntaś cintito yogajñaiḥ /
analyzed: sā upamā smṛtā sa dṛṣṭāntaḥ cintitaḥ yoga jñaiḥ
translated: This is considered to be the analogy, the example, by those who know yoga.

original: kasya / yogina ekāgrabhūmau samprajñātasamādhimato 'bhyāsapāṭavād yatacittasya
analyzed: kasya yoginaḥ ekāgra bhūmau samprajñāta samādhimataḥ bhyāsa pāṭavāt yata cittasya
translated: Of whom? Of the yogi who has one-pointedness of mind, who has samprajnata samadhi on the stage of samadhi, whose mind is restrained by the excellence of practice,

original: niruddhasarvacittavṛtter asamprajñātasamādhirūpaṃ yogaṃ nirodhabhūmau yuñjato
analyzed: niruddha sarva citta vṛtteḥ asamprajñāta samādhi rūpam yogam nirodha bhūmau yuñjataḥ
translated: For one who has stopped all mental activities and is practicing yoga in the form of the state of non-apprehension in the stage of cessation,

original: 'nutiṣṭhato ya ātmāntaḥkaraṇaṃ tasya niścalatayā sattvodrekeṇa prakāśakatayā ca niścalo🔽dīpo dṛṣṭānta ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: anutiṣṭhataḥ yaḥ ātmā antaḥkaraṇam tasya niścala tayā sattva udrekeṇa prakāśaka tayā ca  dīpaḥ dṛṣṭānte iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the lamp which is motionless by the immobility of the inner self of one who practices, who engages in yoga in the form of the state of concentration in which all mental activities are ceased, in the stage of cessation, by the elevation of sattva.

original: ātmano yogaṃ yuñjata iti vyākhyāne dārṣṭāntikālābhaḥ sarvāvasthasyāpi cittasya sarvadātmākāratayātmapadavaiyarthyaṃ ca /
analyzed: ātmanaḥ yogam yuñjate iti vyākhyāne dārṣṭāntika alābhaḥ sarva avasthasya api cittasya sarvadā ātma ākāra tayā ātma pada vaiyarthyam ca
translated: In the explanation one who engages in yoga with the self, the meaning of the example is obtained, and the word self becomes meaningless because the mind in all states is always of the form of the self.

original: na hi yogenātmākāratā cittasya sampādyate /
analyzed: na hi yogena ātma ākāra tā cittasya sampādyate
translated: For the mind's form as the self is not accomplished by yoga.

original: kintu svata evātmākārasya sato 'nātmākāratā nivartyata iti /
analyzed: kintu svatas eva ātma ākārasya sataḥ na ātma ākāra tā nivartyate iti
translated: But rather, the non-form of the self, which is naturally existent, is removed.

original: tasmād dārṣṭāntikapratipādanārtham evātmapadam /
analyzed: tasmāt dārṣṭāntika pratipādana artham eva ātma padam
translated: Therefore, the word self is used only to convey the meaning of the example.

original: yatacittasyeti bhāvaparo nirdeśaḥ karmadhārayo vā yatasya cittasyety arthaḥ ////
analyzed: yata cittasya iti bhāva paraḥ nirdeśaḥ karmadhārayaḥ vā yatasya cittasya iti arthaḥ
translated: The expression of the mind that is restrained is a substantive, or a karmadhāraya compound, meaning of the mind that is restrained.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Viśvanātha.

original: nivātastho nirvātadeśasthito dīpo neṅgate na calati yaḥ sa eva dīpa upamā yathā yathāvad ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: nivāta sthaḥ nirvāta deśa sthitaḥ dīpaḥ na iṅgate na calati yaḥ saḥ eva dīpaḥ upamā yathā yathāvat iti arthaḥ
translated: A lamp that is not moving, that is not shaking, that is located in a place without wind, that very lamp is the example, meaning just as it is.

original: so 'ci lope cet pādapūraṇam Pāṇ / / iti sandhiḥ /
analyzed: saḥ ci lope ced pāda pūraṇam pāṇ iti sandhiḥ
translated: If the 'sa' is elided, there is sandhi according to the rule so 'ci lope cet pādapūraṇam pāṇi (Pāṇini 6.1.105).

original: kasyopamā ity ata āha yogina iti /
analyzed: kasya upamāḥ iti atas āha yoginaḥ iti
translated: To whom is this simile? To this he says to the yogi.

original: baladevaḥ / tadā yogī kīdṛśo bhavatīty apekṣāyām āha yatheti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ tadā yogī kīdṛśaḥ bhavati iti apekṣāyām āha yathā iti
translated: Balarāma. When there is expectation of what kind of yogi is he at that time, he says like.

original: nirvātadeśastho dīpo neṅgate na calati niścalaḥ saprabhas tiṣṭhati sa dīpo yathā yathāvad upamā yogajñaiḥ smṛtā cintitā /
analyzed: nirvāta deśa sthaḥ dīpaḥ nā iṅgate na calati niścalaḥ sa prabhaḥ tiṣṭhati sa dīpaḥ yathā yathāvat upamā yoga jñaiḥ smṛtā cintitā
translated: A lamp placed in a place free from wind does not flicker, does not move, stands still with light. That lamp is remembered, thought of, by those who know yoga as a simile, as it is.

original: sopamety atra so 'ci lope cet pādapūraṇam Pāṇ / / iti sūtrāt sandhiḥ /
analyzed: sā upamā iti atra saḥ ci lope ced pāda pūraṇam iti sūtrāt sandhiḥ
translated: Here in with a simile, there is sandhi according to the rule so 'ci lope cet pādapūraṇam pāṇi (Pāṇini 6.1.105).

original: upamāśabdenopamānaṃ bodhyam /
analyzed: upamā śabdena upamānam bodhyam
translated: The upamāna (simile) should be understood by the word upamā (simile).

original: kasyety āha yogina iti /
analyzed: kasya iti āha yoginaḥ iti
translated: To whom? He says to the yogi.

original: yatacittasya niruddhasarvacittavṛtter ātmano yogaṃ dhyānaṃ yuñjato 'nutiṣṭhataḥ /
analyzed: yata cittasya niruddha sarva citta vṛtteḥ ātmanaḥ yogam dhyānam yuñjataḥ nutiṣṭhataḥ
translated: Of the self whose mind is restrained, whose all mental functions are stopped, who is engaged in, practicing yoga, meditation.

original: nivṛttasakaletaracittavṛttir abhyuditajñānayogī niścalasapradīpasadṛśo bhavatīti ////
analyzed: nivṛtta sakala itara cittavṛttiḥ abhyudita jñāna yogī niścala sa pradīpa sadṛśaḥ bhavati iti
translated: The yogi whose all other mental functions are ceased, who has risen knowledge, becomes like a still, bright lamp.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: yatroparamate cittaṃ niruddhaṃ yogasevayā /
analyzed: yatra uparamate cittam niruddham yoga sevayā
translated: Where the mind, restrained by the practice of yoga, ceases to function,

original: yatra caivātmanātmānaṃ paśyann ātmani tuṣyati ///
analyzed: yatra ca eva ātmanā ātmānam paśyan ātmani tuṣyati
translated: And where, seeing the Self in the Self, one is satisfied in the Self.

original: sukham ātyantikaṃ yat tad buddhigrāhyam atīndriyam /
analyzed: sukham ātyantikam yat tat buddhi grāhyam atīndriyam
translated: That which is the highest happiness, which is to be known by the intellect, which is beyond the senses,

original: vetti yatra na caivāyaṃ sthitaś calati tattvataḥ ////
analyzed: vetti yatra na ca eva ayam sthitaḥ calati tattvataḥ
translated: where one does not remain and yet does not move away from the truth,

original: yaṃ labdhvā cāparaṃ lābhaṃ manyate nādhikaṃ tataḥ /
analyzed: yam labdhvā ca aparam lābham manyate na adhikam tatas
translated: obtaining which one does not consider any other gain to be greater than that,

original: yasmin sthito na duḥkhena guruṇāpi vicālyate ////
analyzed: yasmin sthitaḥ na duḥkhena guruṇā api vicālyate
translated: remaining in which one is not shaken even by great sorrow,

original: taṃ vidyād duḥkhasaṃyogaviyogaṃ yogasaṃjñitam /
analyzed: tam vidyāt duḥkha saṃyoga viyogam yoga saṃjñitam
translated: know that to be the union called yoga, which is the separation from the contact with sorrow.

original: sa niścayena yoktavyo yogo 'nirviṇṇacetasā ////
analyzed: sa niścayena yoktavyaḥ yogaḥ nirviṇṇa cetasā
translated: That yoga should be practiced with certainty by one whose mind is not disgusted.

original: śrīdharaḥ / yaṃ saṃnyāsam iti prāhur yogaṃ taṃ viddhi pāṇḍava Gītā / ity ādau karmaiva yogaśabdenoktam /
analyzed: iti
translated: In such passages as That renunciation which they call yoga, know that to be yoga, O son of Pandu, action itself is spoken of as yoga.

original: nātyaśnatas tu yogo 'sti Gītā / ity ādau tu samādhir yogaśabdenoktaḥ /
analyzed: na atyaśnataḥ tu yogaḥ sti gītā iti ādau tu samādhiḥ yoga śabdena uktaḥ
translated: In such passages as But there is no yoga for one who eats too much, concentration is spoken of as yoga.

original: tatra mukhyo yogaḥ ka ity apekṣāyāṃ samādhim eva svarūpataḥ phalataś ca lakṣayan sa eva mukhyo yoga ity āha yatreti sārdhais tribhiḥ /
analyzed: tatra mukhyaḥ yogaḥ kaḥ iti apekṣāyām samādhim eva svarūpataḥ phalataḥ ca lakṣayan saḥ eva mukhyaḥ yogaḥ iti āha yatra iti sārdhaiḥ tribhiḥ
translated: There, when there is a doubt as to which is the primary yoga, in order to define concentration itself in terms of its nature and result, he says that it alone is the primary yoga with three and a half verses beginning with where.

original: yatra yasmin avasthāviśeṣe yogābhyāsena niruddhaṃ cittam uparataṃ bhavatīti yogasya svarūpalakṣaṇam uktam /
analyzed: yatra yasmin avasthā viśeṣe yoga abhyāsena niruddham cittam uparatam bhavati iti yogasya svarūpa lakṣaṇam uktam
translated: Where, in which particular state, the mind, restrained by the practice of yoga, becomes stopped, i.e. ceases to function, that is said to be the nature or definition of yoga.

original: tathā ca pātañjalaṃ sūtram yogaś cittavṛttinirodhaḥ YogaS / iti /
analyzed: tathā ca pātañjalam sūtram yogaḥ citta vṛtti nirodhaḥ yogaḥ iti
translated: And in the same way, the aphorism of Patanjali (says): Yoga is the cessation of the modifications of the mind. Yoga is...

original: iṣṭaprāptilakṣaṇena phalena tam eva lakṣayati /
analyzed: iṣṭa prāpti lakṣaṇena phalena tam eva lakṣayati
translated: And he indicates that very (yoga) by the result in the form of the attainment of the desired object.

original: yatra ca yasminn avasthāviśeṣe /
analyzed: yatra ca yasmin avasthā viśeṣe
translated: And where, in which particular state,

original: ātmanā śuddhena manasā ātmānam eva paśyati na tu dehādi /
analyzed: ātmanā śuddhena manasā ātmānam eva paśyati na tu deha ādi
translated: the pure Self sees the Self only by the pure mind, but not the body etc.

original: paśyaṃś cātmany eva tuṣyati /
analyzed: paśyan ca ātmani eva tuṣyati
translated: And seeing, he is satisfied in the Self alone,

original: na tu viṣayeṣu /
analyzed: na tu viṣayeṣu
translated: but not in the objects.

original: yatrety ādīnāṃ yacchandānāṃ taṃ yogasaṃjñitaṃ vidyād iti caturthena ślokenānvayaḥ ///
analyzed: yatra iti ādīnām yad chandānām tam yoga saṃjñitam vidyāt iti caturthena ślokena anvayaḥ
translated: The connection of where etc. with the fourth verse one should know that to be called yoga is by the fourth verse.

original: ātmany eva toṣe hetum āha sukham iti /
analyzed: ātmani eva toṣe hetum āha sukham iti
translated: He states the reason for satisfaction in the Self alone: happiness etc.

original: yatra yasminn avasthāviśeṣe yat tat kim api niratiśayam ātyantikaṃ nityaṃ sukhaṃ vetti /
analyzed: yatra yasmin avasthā viśeṣe yat tat kim api niratiśayam ātyantikam nityam sukham vetti
translated: Where, in which particular state, one experiences that which is some indescribable, absolute, eternal happiness.

original: nanu tadā viṣayendriyasambandhābhāvāt kutaḥ sukhaṃ syāt /
analyzed: nanu tadā viṣaya indriya sambandha abhāvāt kutas sukham syāt
translated: But then, how can there be happiness in the absence of the connection of the object with the sense organ?

original: tatrāha atīndriyaṃ viṣayendriyasambandhātītam /
analyzed: tatra āha atīndriyam viṣaya indriya sambandha atītam
translated: To that he says: beyond the senses, transcending the connection of the object with the sense organ.

original: kevalaṃ buddhyaivātmākāratayā grāhyam /
analyzed: kevalam buddhyā eva ātma ākāra tayā grāhyam
translated: The self is to be grasped only by the intellect, in the form of the self.

original: ataeva ca yatra sthitaḥ saṃs tattvata ātmasvarūpān naiva calati ////
analyzed: ataeva ca yatra sthitaḥ san tattvataḥ ātma svarūpāt na eva calati
translated: And for this very reason, when one is established in that, one does not move at all from the nature of the self.

original: acalatvam evopapādayati yam iti /
analyzed: acala tvam eva upapādayati yam iti
translated: He explains the immovability with the word yam.

original: yam ātmasukharūpaṃ lābhaṃ labdhvā tato 'dhikam aparaṃ lābhaṃ na manyate /
analyzed: yam ātma sukha rūpam lābham labdhvā tatas dhikam aparam lābham na manyate
translated: Having obtained the gain which is of the form of the self's happiness, he does not consider any other gain superior to that.

original: tasyaiva niratiśayasukhatvāt /
analyzed: tasya eva niratiśaya sukha tvāt
translated: Because that alone is of unsurpassed happiness.

original: yasmiṃś ca sthito mahatāpi śītoṣṇādiduḥkhena na vicālyate nābhibhūyate /
analyzed: yasmin ca sthitaḥ mahatā api śīta uṣṇa ādi duḥkhena na vicālyate na abhibhūyate
translated: And in which, even when one is established in it, one is not shaken, not overcome, by great cold, heat, etc., which are suffering.

original: etenāniṣṭanivṛttiphalenāpi yogasya lakṣaṇam uktaṃ draṣṭavyam ////
analyzed: etena aniṣṭa nivṛtti phalena api yogasya lakṣaṇam uktam draṣṭavyam
translated: By this, the definition of yoga should be seen even with the result of the removal of the undesirable.

original: tam iti / ya evaṃbhūto 'vasthāviśeṣas taṃ duḥkhasaṃyogaviyogaṃ yogasaṃjñitaṃ vidyāt /
analyzed: tam iti yaḥ evaṃbhūtaḥ vasthā viśeṣaḥ tam duḥkha saṃyoga viyogam yoga saṃjñitam vidyāt
translated: Tam - one should know that special state to be called yoga, which is the separation from the union with suffering.

original: duḥkhaśabdena duḥkhamiśritaṃ vaiṣayikaṃ sukham api gṛhyate /
analyzed: duḥkha śabdena duḥkha miśritam vaiṣayikam sukham api gṛhyate
translated: By the word suffering, even sensual pleasure mixed with suffering is included.

original: duḥkhasya saṃyogena saṃsparśamātreṇāpi viyogo yasmin tam avasthāviśeṣaṃ yogasaṃjñitaṃ yogaśabdavācyaṃ jānīyāt /
analyzed: duḥkhasya saṃyogena saṃsparśa mātreṇa api viyogaḥ yasmin tam avasthā viśeṣam yoga saṃjñitam yoga śabda vācyam jānīyāt
translated: One should know that special state called yoga, denoted by the word yoga, in which there is separation from even the mere contact with suffering.

original: paramātmānā kṣetrajñasya yojanaṃ yogaḥ /
analyzed: paramātmānā kṣetrajñasya yojanam yogaḥ
translated: Yoga is the union of the supreme self with the individual self.

original: yad vā duḥkhasaṃyogena viyoga eva śūre kātaraśabdavad viruddhalakṣaṇayā yoga ucyate /
analyzed: yat vā duḥkha saṃyogena viyoge eva śūre kātara śabda vat viruddha lakṣaṇayā yogaḥ ucyate
translated: Or, the word yoga is used in the sense of separation from the conjunction with sorrow, in the sense of the word coward, by the method of contrary characteristics.

original: karmaṇi tu yogaśabdas tadupāyatvād aupacārika eveti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: karmaṇi tu yoga śabdaḥ tad upāya tvāt aupacārikaḥ eva iti bhāvaḥ
translated: But in the case of action, the word yoga is only figurative, because it is a means to that. This is the idea.

original: yasmād evaṃ mahāphalo yogas tasmāt sa eva yatnato 'bhyasanīya ity āha tam iti sārdhena /
analyzed: yasmāt evam mahā phalaḥ yogaḥ tasmāt saḥ eva yatnataḥ bhyasanīyaḥ iti āha tam iti sārdhena
translated: Since yoga is thus of great fruit, therefore, it alone should be practised with effort. This is what is said by the half verse beginning with 'tam'.

original: sa yogo niścayena śāstrācāryopadeśajanitena nirvedarahitena cetasā yoktavyaḥ /
analyzed: sa yogaḥ niścayena śāstra ācārya upadeśa janitena nirveda rahitena cetasā yoktavyaḥ
translated: That yoga should be practised with a mind free from dispassion, born of the instructions of the scriptures and the teacher, with certainty.

original: duḥkhabuddhyā prayatnaśaithilyaṃ nirvedaḥ ////
analyzed: duḥkha buddhyā prayatna śaithilyam nirvedaḥ
translated: Dispassion is the relaxation of effort due to the notion of sorrow.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: evaṃ sāmānyena samādhim uktvā nirodhasamādhiṃ vistareṇa vivarītum ārambhate yatreti /
analyzed: evam sāmānyena samādhim uktvā nirodha samādhim vistareṇa vivarītum ārambhate yatra iti
translated: Having thus stated concentration in general, he begins to elaborate on the concentration of cessation with the words 'yatra', etc.

original: yatra yasmin pariṇāmaviśeṣe yogasevayā yogābhyāsapāṭavena jāte sati niruddham
analyzed: yatra yasmin pariṇāma viśeṣe yoga sevayā yoga abhyāsa pāṭavena jāte sati niruddham
translated: When, in a particular transformation brought about by the practice of yoga, by the skill born from the practice of yoga, having become stopped,

original: ekaviṣayakavṛttipravāharūpām ekāgratāṃ tyaktvā nirindhanāgnivad upaśāmyan nirvṛttikatayā
analyzed: eka viṣayaka vṛtti pravāha rūpām ekāgra tām tyaktvā nirindhana agni vat upaśāmyan nirvṛttika tayā
translated: having ceased like a fire without fuel, by becoming devoid of activity,

original: sarvavṛttinirodharūpeṇa pariṇataṃ bhavati /
analyzed: sarva vṛtti nirodha rūpeṇa pariṇatam bhavati
translated: it becomes transformed into the form of the cessation of all modifications.

original: yatra ca yasmiṃś ca pariṇāme sati ātmanā rajastamo 'nabhibhūtaśuddhasattvamātreṇāntaḥkaraṇenātmānaṃ
analyzed: yatra ca yasmin ca pariṇāme sati ātmanā rajaḥ tamaḥ
translated: And where, in which transformation, when the internal organ, not being overpowered by rajas and tamas, is mere pure sattva,

original: pratyakcaitanyaṃ paramātmābhinnaṃ saccidānandaghanam anantam advitīyaṃ paśyan
translated: seeing the Self, the inner consciousness, as non-different from the Supreme Self, as consisting of existence, knowledge and bliss, as infinite, as without a second,

original: vedāntapramāṇajayā vṛttyā sākṣātkurvann ātmany eva paramānandaghane tuṣyati /
translated: and realizing it through the function of the knowledge of the Vedanta, is satisfied in the Self alone, which is full of supreme bliss,

original: na dehendriyasaṃghāte /
analyzed: na deha indriya saṃghāte
translated: not in the aggregate of body and senses,

original: na vā tadbhogye 'nyatra /
analyzed: na vā tad bhogye nyatra
translated: nor in anything else that is to be enjoyed by that [aggregate],

original: paramātmadarśane saty atuṣṭihetvabhāvāt tuṣyaty eveti vā /
analyzed: paramātma darśane sati atuṣṭi hetu abhāvāt tuṣyati eva iti vā
translated: or it is satisfied because there is no cause for dissatisfaction when the Supreme Self is seen.

original: tam antaḥkaraṇapariṇāmaṃ sarvacittavṛttinirodharūpaṃ
analyzed: tam antaḥkaraṇa pariṇāmam sarva citta vṛtti nirodha rūpam
translated: That transformation of the internal organ, which is of the nature of the cessation of all mental activities,

original: yogaṃ vidyād iti pareṇānvayaḥ /
analyzed: yogam vidyāt iti pareṇa anvayaḥ
translated: one should know to be yoga. This is the connection with the next [verse].

original: yatra kāla iti tu vyākhyānam asādhu tacchabdānanvayāt ////
analyzed: yatra kālaḥ iti tu vyākhyānam asādhu tad śabda ananvayāt
translated: The explanation where there is time is not correct, because the word that is not connected [to anything].

original: ātmany eva toṣe hetum āha sukham iti /
analyzed: ātmani eva toṣe hetum āha sukham iti
translated: He states the reason for satisfaction in the Self alone: bliss.

original: yatra yasminn avasthāviśeṣa ātyantikam anantaṃ niratiśayaṃ brahmasvarūpam atīndriyaṃ
analyzed: yatra yasmin avasthā viśeṣe ātyantikam anantam niratiśayam brahma svarūpam atīndriyam
translated: Where, in which particular state, the absolute, infinite, unsurpassed Brahman-nature, which is beyond the senses,

original: viṣayendriyasaṃyogānabhivyaṅgyaṃ buddhigrāhyaṃ buddhyaiva rajastamomalarahitayā
analyzed: viṣaya indriya saṃyoga anabhivyaṅgyam buddhi grāhyam buddhyā eva rajaḥ tamaḥ mala rahitayā
translated: The happiness which the yogi experiences is that which is not manifested by the contact of the sense organs with their objects, which is to be grasped by the intellect, which is to be grasped only by the intellect free from the impurities of rajas and tamas,

original: sattvamātravāhinyā grāhyaṃ sukhaṃ yogī vetti anubhavati /
analyzed: sattva mātra vāhinyā grāhyam sukham yogī vetti anubhavati
translated: which flows only in sattva.

original: yatra ca sthito 'yaṃ vidvāṃs tattvata ātmasvarūpān naiva calati /
analyzed: yatra ca sthitaḥ yam vidvān tattvataḥ ātma svarūpāt na eva calati
translated: And in which, when the learned one abides, he does not move away from the true nature of the Self.

original: taṃ yogasaṃjñitaṃ vidyād iti pareṇānvayaḥ samānaḥ /🔽atrātyantikam iti brahmasukhasvarūpakathanam /
analyzed: tam yoga saṃjñitam vidyāt iti pareṇa anvayaḥ samānaḥ  atra ātyantikam iti brahma sukha svarūpa kathanam
translated: The connection with the following sentence is the same: One should know that to be called yoga.🔽Here, the word eternal indicates the nature of Brahman's bliss.

original: atīndriyam iti viṣayasukhavyāvṛttiḥ /
translated: The word supersensible excludes worldly happiness.

original: tasya viṣayendriyasaṃyogasāpekṣatvāt /
analyzed: tasya viṣaya indriya saṃyoga sāpekṣa tvāt
translated: Because that [worldly happiness] depends on the contact of the sense organs with their objects.

original: buddhigrāhyam iti sauṣuptasukhavyāvṛttiḥ suṣuptau buddher līnatvāt /
analyzed: buddhi grāhyam iti sauṣupta sukha vyāvṛttiḥ suṣuptau buddheḥ līna tvāt
translated: The phrase to be grasped by the intellect excludes the happiness of deep sleep, because in deep sleep the intellect is merged.

original: samādhau nirvṛttikāyās tasyāḥ sattvāt /
analyzed: samādhau nirvṛttikāyāḥ tasyāḥ sattvāt
translated: Because in samadhi, the intellect is inactive.

original: tad uktaṃ gauḍapādaiḥ līyate tu suṣuptau tan nigṛhītaṃ na līyate iti /
analyzed: tat uktam gauḍapādaiḥ līyate tu suṣuptau tat nigṛhītam na līyate iti
translated: This is stated by Gaudapada: But in deep sleep it merges; when restrained, it does not merge.

original: tathā ca śrūyate 🔽samādhinirdhūtamalasya cetaso
analyzed: tathā ca śrūyate  samādhi nirdhūta malasya
translated: And this is heard:🔽The bliss that would be when the mind, cleansed by samadhi,

original: niveśitasyātmani yat sukhaṃ bhavet /
analyzed: niveśitasya ātmani yat sukham bhavet
translated: is placed in the Self,

original: na śakyate varṇayituṃ girā tadā
analyzed: na śakyate varṇayitum girā tadā
translated: cannot be described in words at that time.

original: yad etad antaḥkaraṇena gṛhyate // iti /
analyzed: yat etat antaḥkaraṇena gṛhyate iti
translated: That which is grasped by the internal organ.

original: antaḥkaraṇena niruddhasarvavṛttikenety arthaḥ /
analyzed: antaḥkaraṇena niruddha sarva vṛttikena iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: by the internal organ with all its modifications ceased.

original: vṛttyā tu sukhāsvādanaṃ gauḍācāryais tatra pratiṣiddham nāsvādayet sukhaṃ tatra niḥsaṅgaṃ prajñayā bhavet iti /
analyzed: vṛttyā tu sukha āsvādanam gauḍa ācāryaiḥ tatra pratiṣiddham na āsvādayet sukham tatra niḥsaṅgam prajñayā bhavet iti
translated: But the enjoyment of pleasure by means of modification has been prohibited by the teachers of the Gauḍa school: One should not enjoy pleasure there, one should be free from attachment with wisdom.

original: mahad idaṃ samādhau sukham anubhavāmīti savikalpavṛttirūpā prajñā sukhāsvādaḥ /
analyzed: mahat idam samādhau sukham anubhavāmi iti sa vikalpa vṛtti rūpā prajñā sukha āsvādaḥ
translated: The enjoyment of pleasure is the wisdom in the form of conceptual modification, thinking I am experiencing this great pleasure in concentration.

original: taṃ vyutthānarūpatvena samādhivirodhitvād yogī na kuryāt /
analyzed: tam vyutthāna rūpa tvena samādhi virodhi tvāt yogī na kuryāt
translated: The yogi should not do that, because it is in the form of emergence and is therefore opposed to concentration.

original: ataevaitādṛśyā prajñayā saha saṅgaṃ parityajet tāṃ nirundhyād ity arthaḥ /🔽nirvṛttikena tu cittena svarūpasukhānubhavas taiḥ pratipāditaḥ /
analyzed: ataeva etādṛśyā prajñayā saha saṅgam parityajet tām nirundhyāt iti arthaḥ  nirvṛttikena tu cittena sva rūpa sukha anubhavaḥ taiḥ pratipāditaḥ
translated: For this very reason, one should abandon attachment with that kind of wisdom. The meaning is: one should cease it.🔽But the experience of the bliss of one's own nature with a mind free from modification has been taught by them.

original: svasthaṃ śāntaṃ sanirvāṇakathyaṃ sukham uttamam iti spaṣṭaṃ caitad upariṣṭhāt kariṣyate ////🔽yatra na caivāyaṃ sthitaś calati tattvata ity uktam upapādayati yaṃ labdhveti /
analyzed: svastham śāntam sa nirvāṇa kathyam sukham uttamam iti spaṣṭam ca etat upariṣṭhāt kariṣyate 🔽yatra na ca eva ayam sthitaḥ calati tattvataḥ iti uktam upapādayati yam labdhvā iti
translated: The bliss that is natural, tranquil, and called nirvana is supreme. This will be clearly explained later.

original: yaṃ ca niratiśayātmakasukhavyañjakaṃ nirvṛttikacittāvasthāviśeṣaṃ labdhvā santatābhyāsaparipākena sampādyāparaṃ lābhaṃ tato 'dhikaṃ na 🔽manyate /
analyzed: yam ca niratiśaya ātmaka sukha vyañjakam nirvṛttika citta avasthā viśeṣam labdhvā santata abhyāsa paripākena sampādya aparam lābham tatas dhikam na  manyate
translated: And having attained that state of mind which is beyond all comparison, which is the manifester of bliss, which is free from all operations, and which is accomplished by the perfection of continuous practice, he does not consider any other gain to be superior to it.

original: kṛtaṃ kṛtyaṃ prāptaṃ prāpaṇīyam ity ātmalābhāc ca paraṃ vidyate iti smṛteḥ /
analyzed: kṛtam kṛtyam prāptam prāpaṇīyam iti ātmalābhāt ca param vidyate iti smṛteḥ
translated: He thinks, The duty has been done, the goal has been reached. Thus, because of the attainment of the self, there is nothing superior to it.

original: evaṃ viṣayabhogavāsanayā samādher vicalanaṃ nāstīty uktvā śītavātamaśakādyupadravanivāraṇārtham
analyzed: evam viṣaya bhoga vāsanayā samādheḥ vicalanam nā asti iti uktvā śīta vāta maśaka ādi upadrava nivāraṇa artham
translated: Thus, having said that there is no wavering from concentration due to the impressions of sensual enjoyment, he says that

original: api tan nāstīty āha yasmin paramātmasukhamaye nirvṛttikacittāvasthāviśeṣe sthito
analyzed: api tat na asti iti āha yasmin paramātma sukha maye nirvṛttika citta avasthā viśeṣe
translated: even that does not exist in that state of mind which is free from all operations, which is the manifester of the bliss of the supreme self,

original: yogī guruṇā mahatā śastranipātādinimittena mahatāpi duḥkhena na vicālyate kim uta
analyzed: yogī guruṇā mahatā śastra nipāta ādi nimittena mahatā api duḥkhena na vicālyate kim uta
translated: and in which the yogi, when abiding, is not shaken even by a great pain caused by the guru's striking with a great weapon, much less

original: kṣudreṇety arthaḥ // //🔽yatroparamata ity ārabhya bahubhir viśeṣaṇair yo nivṛttikaḥ paramānandābhivyañjakaś
analyzed: kṣudreṇa iti arthaḥ  yatra uparamate iti ārabhya bahubhiḥ viśeṣaṇaiḥ yaḥ nivṛttikaḥ paramānanda abhivyañjakaḥ
translated: by a small one. This is the meaning.

original: cittāvasthāviśeṣa uktas taṃ cittavṛttinirodhaṃ cittavṛttimayasarvaduḥkhavirodhitvena
analyzed: citta avasthā viśeṣaḥ uktaḥ tam citta vṛtti nirodham citta vṛtti maya sarva duḥkha virodhi tvena
translated: The state of mind which is free from all operations, which manifests supreme bliss, and in which one rests, as stated by many qualifications beginning with where one rests, that cessation of mental fluctuations, which is opposed to all suffering consisting of mental fluctuations,🔽is called yoga.

original: duḥkhaviyogam eva santaṃ yogasaṃjñitaṃ viyogaśabdārtham api virodhilakṣaṇayā
analyzed: duḥkha viyogam eva santam yoga saṃjñitam viyoga śabda artham api virodhi lakṣaṇayā
translated: The separation from suffering itself, which is called yoga, should be known as having the meaning of the word 'separation', but is also denoted by the word 'yoga' through contradiction.

original: yogaśabdavācyaṃ vidyāj jānīyāc ca tu yogaśabdānurodhāt kaṃcit sambandhaṃ pratipadyetety arthaḥ /
analyzed: yoga śabda vācyam vidyāt jānīyāt ca tu yoga śabda anurodhāt kaṃcid sambandham pratipadyeta iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that one should understand and know it as having some connection in accordance with the word 'yoga'.

original: tathā ca bhagavān patañjalir asūtrayat yogaś cittavṛttinirodhaḥ YogaS / iti /
analyzed: tathā ca bhagavān patañjaliḥ asūtrayat yogaḥ citta vṛtti nirodhaḥ yogaḥ iti
translated: And thus the Blessed Lord Patañjali formulated: 'Yoga is the cessation of the fluctuations of consciousness. Yoga is.'

original: yogo bhavati duḥkhahā / iti yat prāg uktaṃ tad etad upasaṃhṛtam /
analyzed: yogaḥ bhavati duḥkha hā iti yat prāk uktam tat etat upasaṃhṛtam
translated: What was said earlier, 'Yoga becomes the destroyer of suffering,' is summarized here.

original: evaṃbhūte yoge niścayānirvedayoḥ sādhanatvavidhānāyāha sa niścayeneti / sa
analyzed: evaṃbhūte yoge niścaya anirvedayoḥ sādhana tva vidhānāya āha sa niścayena iti sa
translated: In this way, in order to prescribe the means of certainty and non-discouragement in such yoga, he says 'That should be practiced with certainty.'

original: yathoktaphalo yogo niścayena śāstrācāryavacanatātparyaviṣayo 'rthaḥ satya evety adhvayasāyena yoktavyo 'bhyasanīyaḥ /
analyzed: yathā ukta phalaḥ yogaḥ niścayena śāstra ācārya vacana tātparya viṣayaḥ rthaḥ satyaḥ eva iti adhvayasāyena yoktavyaḥ bhyasanīyaḥ
translated: That yoga, which has the aforementioned result, should be practiced, should be cultivated, with certainty, with the conviction that the meaning which is the intended object of the statements of scripture and the teacher is indeed true.

original: anirviṇṇacetasā etāvatāpi kālena yogo na siddhaḥ kim ataḥ paraṃ kaṣṭam ity anutāpo nirvedas tadrahitena cetasā /
analyzed: anirviṇṇa cetasā etāvatā api kālena yogaḥ na siddhaḥ kim atas param kaṣṭam iti anutāpaḥ nirvedaḥ tad rahitena cetasā
translated: With a mind free from discouragement, thinking 'Even after this much time, yoga has not been accomplished, what is more difficult than this?' is discouragement. With a mind free from that.

original: iha janmani janmāntare vā setsyati kiṃ tvarayety evaṃ dhairyam uktena manasety arthaḥ /
analyzed: iha janmani janmāntare vā setsyati kim tvarayā iti evam dhairyam uktena manasā iti arthaḥ
translated: In this life or in another life it will be accomplished. Why be in a hurry? The meaning is that one should have patience as stated.

original: tad etad gauḍapādā udājahruḥ
analyzed: tat etat gauḍapādāḥ udājahruḥ
translated: This has been stated by Gauḍapāda:

original: utseka udadher yadvat kuśāgreāikabindunā /
analyzed: utsekaḥ udadheḥ yadvat
translated: Just as the ocean can be filled by a single drop of water on the tip of a blade of grass,

original: manaso nigrahas tadvad bhaved aparikhedataḥ // iti /
analyzed: manasaḥ nigrahaḥ tadvat bhavet a parikhedataḥ iti
translated: in the same way, the mind can be controlled without fatigue.

original: utseka utsecanaṃ śoṣaṇādhvasyāyena jaloddharaṇam iti yāvat /
analyzed: utsekaḥ utsecanam jala uddharaṇam iti yāvat
translated: Filling means drying up, by the method of drawing out water.

original: atra sampradāyavida ākhyāyikām ācakṣate /🔽kasyacit kila pakṣiṇo 'ṇḍāni tīrasthāni taraṅgavegena sumudro 'pajahāra /
analyzed: atra sampradāya vidaḥ ākhyāyikām ācakṣate  kasyacid kila pakṣiṇaḥ ṇḍāni tīra sthāni taraṅga vegena sumudraḥ upajahāra
translated: Here, those who know the tradition tell a story.🔽It is said that the water of the ocean carried away the eggs of a certain bird that were on the shore with the force of the waves.

original: sa ca samudraṃ śoṣayiṣāmy eveti pravṛttaḥ svamukhāgreṇaikaikaṃ jalabindum upari pracikṣepa /
analyzed: sa ca samudram śoṣayiṣāmi eva iti pravṛttaḥ sva mukha agreṇa ekaikam jala bindum upari pracikṣepa
translated: And he started out, thinking, I will dry up the ocean, and threw up each drop of water with the tip of his beak.

original: tadā ca bahubhiḥ pakṣibhir bandhuvargair vāryamāṇo 'pi naivopararāma /
analyzed: tadā ca bahubhiḥ pakṣibhiḥ bandhu vargaiḥ vāryamāṇaḥ na eva upararāma
translated: And even though he was being prevented by many birds and his relatives, he did not stop at all.

original: yadṛcchayā ca tatrāgatena nāradena nivārito 'py asmin janmani janmāntare vā yena kenāpy upāyena samudraṃ śoṣayiṣyāmy eveti pratijajñe /
analyzed: yadṛcchayā ca tatra āgatena nāradena asmin janmani janmāntare vā yena kena api upāyena samudram śoṣayiṣyāmi eva iti pratijajñe
translated: And even though he was stopped by Nārada, who had come there by chance, he vowed, By some means or other, in this life or in another life, I will dry up the ocean.

original: tataś ca daivānukūlyāt kṛpālur nārado garuḍaṃ tatsāhāyyāya preṣayāmāsa /
analyzed: tatas ca daiva ānukūlyāt kṛpāluḥ nāradaḥ garuḍam tad sāhāyyāya preṣayāmāsa
