translated: And then, by the favor of fate, the compassionate Nārada sent Garuḍa to assist him.

original: samudras tvajjñātidroheṇa tvām avamanyata iti vacanena /
analyzed: samudraḥ tvad jñāti droheṇa tvām avamanyate iti vacanena
translated: By the statement, The ocean disrespected you by treachery against your kinsmen.

original: tato garuḍapakṣavātena śuṣyan samudro bhītas tāny aṇḍāni tasmai pakṣiṇe pradadāv iti /
analyzed: tatas garuḍa pakṣa vātena śuṣyan samudraḥ bhītaḥ tāni aṇḍāni tasmai pakṣiṇe pradadau iti
translated: Then, the ocean, drying up by the wind of Garuḍa's wings, frightened, gave those eggs to that bird.

original: evam akhedena manonirodhe paramadharme pravartamānaṃ yoginam
analyzed: evam akhedena manaḥ nirodhe parama dharme pravartamānam yoginam
translated: Thus, when the yogi's mind is restrained without fatigue, engaged in the highest Dharma,

original: īśvaro 'nugṛhṇāti /
analyzed: īśvaraḥ nugṛhṇāti
translated: the Lord favors him.

original: tataś ca pakṣiṇa iva tasyābhimataṃ sidhyatīti bhāvaḥ ////
analyzed: tatas ca pakṣiṇaḥ iva tasya abhimatam sidhyati iti bhāvaḥ
translated: And then, like birds, his desired goal is accomplished. This is the meaning.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Viśvanātha.

original: nātyaśnatas tu yogo 'stīty ādau yogaśabdena samādhir uktaḥ /
analyzed: na atyaśnataḥ tu yogaḥ sti iti ādau yoga śabdena samādhiḥ uktaḥ
translated: In the beginning of But there is no yoga for one who eats too much, the word yoga refers to concentration.

original: sa ca saṃprajñāto 'saṃprajñātaś ca /
analyzed: sa ca saṃprajñātaḥ saṃprajñātaḥ ca
translated: And that is samprajñāta (with thought) and asamprajñāta (without thought).

original: savitarkasavicārabhedāt saṃprajñāto bahuvidhaḥ /
analyzed: sa vitarka sa vicāra bhedāt saṃprajñātaḥ bahuvidhaḥ
translated: Samprajñāta is of many kinds due to the division of savitarka (with discursive thought) and savicāra (with investigation).

original: asaṃprajñātasamādhirūpo yogaḥ kīdṛśa ity apekṣāyām āha yatretyādisārdhais tribhiḥ /
analyzed: asaṃprajñāta samādhi rūpaḥ yogaḥ kīdṛśaḥ iti apekṣāyām āha yatra ityādi sārdhaiḥ tribhiḥ
translated: When there is expectation of what kind of yoga is the form of asamprajñāta samādhi, it is said with three and a half verses beginning with yatra.

original: yatra samādhau sati cittam uparamate vastumātram eva na spṛśatīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: yatra samādhau sati cittam uparamate vastu mātram eva na spṛśati iti arthaḥ
translated: When there is that samādhi, the mind ceases, the meaning is that it does not touch mere objects.

original: tatra hetuḥ niruddham iti /
analyzed: tatra hetuḥ niruddham iti
translated: The reason for that is nirodham (cessation).

original: tathā ca pātañjalasūtram yogaś cittavṛttinirodhaḥ YogaS / iti /
analyzed: tathā ca pātañjala sūtram yogaḥ citta vṛtti nirodhaḥ yogaḥ iti
translated: And so the aphorism of Patañjali: Yoga is the cessation of the modifications of the mind. Yoga is.

original: yatretyādipadānāṃ yogasaṃjñitaṃ vidyād iti caturthenānvayaḥ /
analyzed: yatra ityādi padānām yoga saṃjñitam vidyāt iti caturthena anvayaḥ
translated: The connection of the words beginning with 'where' is with the fourth, 'one should know as having the name yoga'.

original: ātmanā paramātmākārāntaḥkaraṇenātmānaṃ paśyan tasmin tuṣyati /
analyzed: ātmanā paramātma ākāra antaḥkaraṇena ātmānam paśyan tasmin tuṣyati
translated: Seeing the Self with the Self, i.e. with the internal organ in the form of the Supreme Self, one is satisfied in that.

original: tatratyaṃ sukhaṃ prāpnoti /
analyzed: tatratyam sukham prāpnoti
translated: One obtains the happiness there.

original: yad ātyantikaṃ sukhaṃ prasiddham /
analyzed: yat ātyantikam sukham prasiddham
translated: That is the well-known ultimate happiness.

original: atīndriyaṃ viṣayendriyasamparkarahitam /
analyzed: atīndriyam viṣaya indriya samparka rahitam
translated: It is beyond the senses, devoid of contact with objects and senses.

original: ataeva yatra sthitaḥ san tattvata ātmasvarūpān naiva calati /
analyzed: ataeva yatra sthitaḥ san tattvataḥ ātma svarūpāt na eva calati
translated: And therefore, while remaining in that, one does not move away from the true nature of one's own Self.

original: ataeva yaṃ lābhaṃ labdhvā tataḥ sakāśād aparaṃ lābham
analyzed: ataeva yam lābham labdhvā tatas sakāśāt aparam lābham
translated: And therefore, having obtained that gain, one does not consider any other gain

original: adhikaṃ na manyate /
analyzed: adhikam na manyate
translated: greater than that.

original: duḥkhasya saṃyogena sparśamātreṇāpi viyogo yasmin taṃ yogasaṃjñtaṃ yogasaṃjñāṃ prāptaṃ samādhiṃ vidyāt /
analyzed: duḥkhasya saṃyogena sparśa mātreṇa api viyogaḥ yasmin tam yoga saṃjñtam yoga saṃjñām prāptam samādhim vidyāt
translated: One should know that concentration, which has the name yoga, as having attained the name yoga, where there is separation even by mere contact with suffering.

original: yadyapi śīghraṃ na sidhyati tad apy ayaṃ me yogaḥ saṃsetsyaty eveti yo niścayas tena /
analyzed: yadi api śīghram na sidhyati tat api ayam me yogaḥ saṃsetsyati eva iti yaḥ niścayaḥ tena
translated: Even if it is not quickly accomplished, one should know that this yoga of mine will certainly be successful.

original: anirviṇṇacetasaitāvatāpi kālena yogo na siddhaḥ /
analyzed: anirviṇṇa cetasā etāvatā api kālena yogaḥ na siddhaḥ
translated: With an undistracted mind, even in this much time, yoga is not accomplished.

original: kim ataḥ paraṃ kaṣṭenety anutāpo nirvedas tadrahitena cetasā /
analyzed: kim atas param kaṣṭena iti anutāpaḥ nirvedaḥ tad rahitena cetasā
translated: What is the use of further suffering? Disgust is the absence of that. And with a mind free from that,

original: iha janmani janmāntare vā sidhyatu /
analyzed: iha janmani janmāntare vā sidhyatu
translated: whether it is accomplished in this life or in another life,

original: kiṃ me tvarayeti dhairyayuktena manasety arthaḥ /
analyzed: kim me tvarayā iti dhairya yuktena manasā iti arthaḥ
translated: what is the hurry for me? The meaning is: with a mind endowed with patience.

original: tad etad gauḍapādā udājahruḥ
analyzed: tat etat gauḍapādāḥ udājahruḥ
translated: This was stated by Gauḍapāda:

original: utseka udadher yadvat kuśāgreāikabindunā /
analyzed: utsekaḥ udadheḥ yadvat
translated: Just as the ocean is filled by a single drop of water on the tip of a blade of kuśa grass,

original: manaso nigrahas tadvad bhaved aparikhedataḥ // iti /
analyzed: manasaḥ nigrahaḥ tadvat bhavet a parikhedataḥ iti
translated: in the same way, the mind is controlled without fatigue.

original: utseka utsecanam /
analyzed: utsekaḥ utsecanam
translated: Filling means filling up.

original: śoṣaṇādhyavasāyena jaloddharaṇam iti yāvat /
analyzed: śoṣaṇa adhyavasāyena jala uddharaṇam iti yāvat
translated: The meaning is: with the determination to dry up, water is drawn out.

original: atra kācid ākhyāyikāsti /
analyzed: atra kācid ākhyāyikā asti
translated: Here there is a story.

original: kasyacit kila pakṣiṇo 'ṇḍāni tīrasthitāni taraṅgavegena sumudro jahāra /
analyzed: kasyacid kila pakṣiṇaḥ ṇḍāni tīra sthitāni taraṅga vegena sumudraḥ jahāra
translated: It is said that the eggs of a certain bird, which were on the shore, were carried away by the force of the waves by Sumudrā.

original: sa ca samudraṃ śoṣayiṣāmīty eveti pratijñāya svamukhāgreṇaikaikaṃ jalabindum upari pracikṣepa /
analyzed: sa ca samudram śoṣayiṣāmi iti eva iti pratijñāya sva mukha agreṇa ekaikam jala bindum upari pracikṣepa
translated: And he, thinking I will dry up the ocean, having made a vow, threw up each drop of water with the tip of his beak.

original: taṃ ca bahubhiḥ pakṣibhir bandhubhir yuktyā vāryamāṇo 'pi naivopararāma /
analyzed: tam ca bahubhiḥ pakṣibhiḥ bandhubhiḥ yuktyā vāryamāṇaḥ na eva upararāma
translated: And although he was dissuaded by many birds, his relatives, with reason, he did not stop at all.

original: yadṛcchayā ca tatrāgatena nāradena nivārito 'py asmin janmani janmāntare vā samudraṃ śoṣayiṣyāmy eveti tadagre 'pi punaḥ pratijajñe /
analyzed: yadṛcchayā ca tatra āgatena nāradena asmin janmani janmāntare vā samudram śoṣayiṣyāmi eva iti tad agre pi punar pratijajñe
translated: And although he was dissuaded by Nārada, who happened to come there, he vowed again in his presence, “I will dry up the ocean in this birth or in the next.”

original: tataś ca daivānukūlyāt kṛpālur nārado garuḍaṃ tatsāhāyyāya preṣayāmāsa /
analyzed: tatas ca daiva ānukūlyāt kṛpāluḥ nāradaḥ garuḍam tad sāhāyyāya preṣayāmāsa
translated: Then, due to the favor of fate, the compassionate Nārada sent Garuḍa to assist him.

original: samudras tvadīyajñātidroheṇa tvām avamanyata iti vākyena /
analyzed: samudraḥ tvadīya jñāti droheṇa tvām avamanyate iti vākyena
translated: With the words, The ocean has insulted you by betraying your kinsmen.

original: tato garuḍapakṣavātena śuṣyan samudro 'tibhītas tāny aṇḍāni tasmai pakṣiṇe dadāv iti /
analyzed: tatas garuḍa pakṣa vātena śuṣyan samudraḥ ti bhītaḥ tāni aṇḍāni tasmai pakṣiṇe dadau iti
translated: Then, as the ocean was drying up by the wind of Garuḍa's wings, it became extremely frightened and gave those eggs to that bird.

original: evam eva śāstravacanāstikyena yoge jñāne bhaktau vā pravartamānam utsāhavantam adhyavasāyinaṃ janaṃ bhagavān evānugṛhṇātīti niścetavyam ////
analyzed: evam eva śāstra vaca nāstikyena yoge jñāne bhaktau vā pravartamānam utsāhavantam adhyavasāyinam janam bhagavān eva anugṛhṇāti iti niścetavyam
translated: In the same way, it should be ascertained that the Lord himself favors the person who engages in yoga, knowledge, or devotion with faith in the scriptures, who is enthusiastic and determined.

original: baladevaḥ / nātyaśnata ity ādau yogaśabdenoktaṃ samādhiṃ svarūpataḥ phalataś ca lakṣayati yatretyādisārdhatrayeṇa /
translated: Balarāma. In the passage beginning with not eating too much, he defines the concentration mentioned by the word yoga in terms of its nature and result with the next three and a half verses.

original: yacchabdānāṃ taṃ vidyād yogasaṃjñitam ity uttareṇānvayaḥ /
analyzed: yat śabdānām tam vidyāt yoga saṃjñitam iti uttareṇa anvayaḥ
translated: The word that is connected with the following sentence one should know that to be called yoga.

original: yogaysa sevayābhyāsena niruddhaṃ nivṛttetaravṛttikaṃ cittaṃ yatroparamate mahat sukham etad iti sajjati /
analyzed: sevayā abhyāsena niruddham nivṛtta itara vṛttikam cittam yatra uparamate mahat sukham etat iti sajjati
translated: The mind, when restrained by the practice of yoga, when it ceases from all other activities, becomes absorbed in that great bliss.

original: na tu dehādi paśyan viṣayeṣv iti cittavṛttinirodhena svarūpeṇeṣṭaprāptilakṣaṇena phalena ca yogo darśitaḥ /
analyzed: na tu deha ādi paśyan viṣayeṣu iti citta vṛtti nirodhena svarūpeṇa iṣṭa prāpti lakṣaṇena phalena ca yogaḥ darśitaḥ
translated: But not when it sees the body etc. and the objects. Thus, by the cessation of the activities of the mind, yoga is shown both in its own nature and in its result, which is the attainment of the desired object.

original: sukham iti /
analyzed: sukham iti
translated: As to bliss.

original: yatra samādhau yat tat prasiddham ātyantikaṃ nityaṃ sukhaṃ vetty anubhavati /
analyzed: yatra samādhau yat tat prasiddham ātyantikam nityam sukham vetti anubhavati
translated: In that samādhi, one experiences that well-known, ultimate, eternal bliss.

original: atīndriyaṃ viṣayendriyasambandharahitaṃ /
analyzed: atīndriyam viṣaya indriya sambandha rahitam
translated: It is beyond the senses, devoid of contact with objects and sense organs.

original: buddhyātmākārayā grāhyam /
analyzed: buddhi ātma ākārayā grāhyam
translated: It is to be grasped by the form of the intellect-self.

original: ataeva yatra sthitas tattvata ātmasvarūpān naiva calati /
analyzed: ataeva yatra sthitaḥ tattvataḥ ātma svarūpāt na eva calati
translated: And for that very reason, one who abides in it never moves away from the true nature of the self.

original: yaṃ yogaṃ labdhvaiva tato 'paraṃ lābham adhikaṃ na manyate /
analyzed: yam yogam labdhvā eva param lābham adhikam na manyate
translated: Having attained that yoga, one does not consider any other gain to be superior.

original: guruṇā guṇavat putravicchedādinā na vicāyate tam iti /🔽duḥkhasaṃyogasya viyogaḥ pradhvaṃso yatra taṃ yogasaṃjñtaṃ
analyzed: guruṇā guṇavat putra viccheda ādinā na vicāyate tam iti  duḥkha saṃyogasya viyogaḥ pradhvaṃsaḥ yatra tam yoga saṃjñtam
translated: One is not shaken by the guru, by the loss of a virtuous son, etc. That is called yoga.

original: samādhim ////
analyzed: samādhim
translated: The destruction of the union with sorrow, that is called samādhi, yoga.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: saṃkalpaprabhavān kāmāṃs tyaktvā sarvān aśeṣataḥ /
analyzed: saṃkalpa prabhavān kāmān tyaktvā sarvān aśeṣatas
translated: Having renounced all desires, which arise from conceptualization, without exception,

original: manasaivendriyagrāmaṃ viniyamya samantataḥ ////🔽śrīdharaḥ / kiṃ ca saṅkalpeti /
analyzed: manasā evā indriya grāmam viniyamya samantataḥ    ca
translated: By restraining the group of senses on all sides with the mind alone,

original: saṃkalpāt prabhavo yeṣāṃ tān yogapratikūlān sarvān kāmān aśeṣataḥ savāsanāṃs tyaktvā manasaiva viṣayadoṣadarśinā sarvataḥ prasarantam indriyasamūhaṃ
analyzed: saṃkalpāt prabhavaḥ yeṣām tān yoga pratikūlān sarvān kāmān aśeṣatas sa vāsanān tyaktvā manasā eva viṣaya doṣa darśinā sarvatas prasarantam indriya samūham
translated: Śrīdhara: What's more, by renouncing all desires, which arise from imagination, that are adverse to yoga, along with their impressions, by seeing the faults of objects with the mind alone, and by restraining the group of senses that spreads out in every direction,

original: viśeṣeṇa niyamya /
analyzed: viśeṣeṇa niyamya
translated: in particular.

original: yogo yoktavya iti pūrveṇānvayaḥ ////
analyzed: yogaḥ yoktavyaḥ iti pūrveṇa anvayaḥ
translated: The connection is with the previous sentence that yoga should be practiced.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusūdana:

original: kiṃ ca kṛtvā yogo 'bhyasnīyaḥ /
analyzed: kim ca kṛtvā yogaḥ bhyasnīyaḥ
translated: What should be done before yoga is practiced?

original: saṅkalpo duṣṭeṣv api viṣayeṣv aśobhanatvādarśanena śobhanādhyāsaḥ /
analyzed: saṅkalpaḥ duṣṭeṣu api viṣayeṣu aśobhana tva adarśanena śobhana adhyāsaḥ
translated: Imagination is the superimposition of beauty on even bad objects by not seeing their ugliness.

original: tasmāc ca saṅkalpād idaṃ me syād idaṃ me syād ity evaṃrūpāḥ kāmāḥ prabhavanti /
analyzed: tasmāt ca saṅkalpāt idam me syāt idam me syāt iti evaṃrūpāḥ kāmāḥ prabhavanti
translated: And from that imagination, desires in the form of May this be mine, may this be mine arise.

original: tān śobhanādhyāsaprabhavān viṣayābhilāṣān vicārajanyāśobhanatvaniścayena śobhanādhyāsabādhād
analyzed: tān śobhana adhyāsa prabhavān viṣaya abhilāṣān vicāra janya aśobhana tva niścayena śobhana adhyāsa bādhāt
translated: Those desires, which arise from the superimposition of beauty, should be renounced by the ascertainment of their ugliness, which arises from reflection, by negating the superimposition of beauty,🔽in both seen objects like garlands, sandalwood, women, etc., and unseen objects like Indra's world, the heavenly tree, celestial nymphs, etc.,

original: dṛṣṭeṣu srakcandanavanitādiṣv adṛṣṭeṣu cendralokapārijātāpsaraḥprabhṛtiṣu śvavāntapāyasavat
analyzed: dṛṣṭeṣu sraj candana vanitā ādiṣu a dṛṣṭeṣu ca indra loka pārijāta apsaraḥ prabhṛtiṣu śva vānta pāyasa vat
translated: like dog's vomit and rice pudding.

original: svata eva sarvān brahmalokaparyantān aśeṣato niravaśeṣān savāsanāṃs tyaktvā /🔽ataeva kāmapūrvakatvād indiryapravṛttes tadapāye sati vivekayuktena manasaivendriyaprāptaṃ
analyzed: svatas eva sarvān brahma loka paryantān aśeṣatas niravaśeṣān sa vāsanān tyaktvā  ataeva kāma pūrvaka tvāt indirya pravṛtteḥ tad apāye sati viveka yuktena manasā eva indriya prāptam
translated: Having given up all, without exception, up to the world of Brahman, along with their latent impressions, by himself alone.🔽And for this very reason, since the activity of the senses is preceded by desire, when that is removed, having restrained the group of sense organs such as the eyes,

original: cakṣurādikaraṇasamūhaṃ viniyamya samantataḥ sarvebhyo viṣayebhyaḥ pratyāhṛtya
analyzed: cakṣuḥ ādi karaṇa samūham viniyamya samantataḥ sarvebhyaḥ viṣayebhyaḥ pratyāhṛtya
translated: having withdrawn them completely from all objects, with a mind endowed with discrimination,

original: śanaiḥ śanair uparamed ity anvayaḥ // //
analyzed: śanais śanais uparamet iti anvayaḥ
translated: one should gradually cease. The sequence is this.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha:

original: etādṛśayogābhyāse pravṛttasya prāthamikaṃ kṛtyam antyaṃ ca kṛtyam āha saṅkalpeti dvābhyām /
analyzed: etādṛśa yoga abhyāse pravṛttasya prāthamikam kṛtyam antyam ca kṛtyam āha saṅkalpa iti dvābhyām
translated: For one engaged in such practice of yoga, the first duty and the last duty are stated by the two verses beginning with sankalpa.

original: kāmāṃs tyaktveti prāthamikaṃ kṛtyam /
analyzed: kāmān tyaktvā iti prāthamikam kṛtyam
translated: Having given up desires is the first duty.

original: na kiṃcid api cintayed ity antyaṃ kṛtyam ////
analyzed: na kiṃcid api cintayet iti antyam kṛtyam
translated: One should not think of anything at all is the last duty.

original: baladevaḥ / sa yogaḥ prārambhadaśāyāṃ niścayena prayatne kṛte saṃsetsyaty evety adhyavasāyena yoktavyo 'nuṣṭheyaḥ /
analyzed: baladevaḥ sa yogaḥ prārambha daśāyām niścayena prayatne kṛte saṃsetsyati eva iti adhyavasāyena yoktavyaḥ nuṣṭheyaḥ
translated: Baladeva: That yoga should be undertaken, should be performed, with the resolve that it will certainly succeed when effort is made in the initial stage.

original: ātmany ayogatvamananaṃ nirvedas tadrahitena cetasā hṛtāṇḍārṇavaśoṣakatpakṣivat sotsāhenety arthaḥ /
analyzed: ātmani ayoga tva mananam nirvedaḥ tad rahitena cetasā hṛta aṇḍa arṇava śoṣa kad pakṣi vat sa utsāhena iti arthaḥ
translated: With a mind free from disinclination, which is the lack of fitness in the self, i.e. with enthusiasm like the bird Garuda, the drier of the oceans of the eggs of serpents.

original: etādṛśaṃ yogam ārabhamāṇasya prāthamikaṃ kṛtyam āha saṅkalpeti /
analyzed: etādṛśam yogam ārabhamāṇasya prāthamikam kṛtyam āha saṅkalpa iti
translated: The first duty of one who has begun this kind of yoga is stated by the word 'renouncing' (in the verse).

original: saṅkalpāt prabhavo yeṣāṃ tān yogavirodhinaḥ kāmān viṣayān aśeṣataḥ savāsanāṃs tyaktvā /
analyzed: saṅkalpāt prabhavaḥ yeṣām tān yoga virodhinaḥ kāmān viṣayān aśeṣatas sa vāsanān tyaktvā
translated: Renouncing all those desires and objects of sense which are hostile to yoga and which originate from the mind, along with their impressions.

original: sphuṭam anyat /
analyzed: sphuṭam anyat
translated: The rest is clear.

original: manasā viṣayadoṣadarśinā ////🔽BhG /
analyzed: manasā viṣaya doṣa darśinā  bhg
translated: With the mind perceiving the faults of the objects of sense,

original: śanaiḥ śanair uparamed buddhyā dhṛtigṛhītayā /
analyzed: śanais śanais uparamet buddhyā dhṛti gṛhītayā
translated: (one should) gradually withdraw (the mind) by the intellect held fast by patience.

original: ātmasaṃsthaṃ manaḥ kṛtvā na kiṃcid api cintayet ////
analyzed: ātma saṃstham manaḥ kṛtvā na kiṃcid api cintayet
translated: Having fixed the mind in the Self, one should think of nothing at all.

original: śrīdharaḥ / yadi tu prāktanakarmasaṃskāreṇa mano vicalet tarhi dhāraṇayā sthirīkuryād ity āha śanair iti /
translated: (Sri Sankaracharya). If, however, the mind should waver due to the impressions of past karma, then one should stabilize it by concentration. This is stated by (the words) 'gradually' etc.

original: dhṛtir dhāraṇā /
analyzed: dhṛtiḥ dhāraṇā
translated: Patience is concentration.

original: tayā gṛhītayā vaśīkṛtayā buddhyā /
analyzed: tayā gṛhītayā vaśīkṛtayā buddhyā
translated: By the intellect held fast by that, i.e. controlled.

original: ātmasaṃstham ātmany eva samyak sthitaṃ niścalaṃ manaḥ kṛtvoparamet /
analyzed: ātma saṃstham ātmani eva samyak sthitam niścalam manaḥ kṛtvā uparamet
translated: Having fixed the mind in the Self itself, in perfect stillness, one should withdraw (the mind).

original: tac ca śanaiḥ śanair abhyāsakrameṇa /
analyzed: tat ca śanais śanais abhyāsa krameṇa
translated: And that should be done gradually, by the practice of stages.

original: na tu sahasā /
analyzed: na tu sahasā
translated: But not suddenly.

original: uparamasvarūpam āha na kiṃcid api cintayet /
analyzed: uparama svarūpam āha na kiṃcid api cintayet
translated: The nature of withdrawal is stated by (the words) 'one should think of nothing at all'.

original: niścale manasi svayam eva prakāśamānaparamānandasvarūpo bhūtvātmadhyānād api nivartetety arthaḥ ////
analyzed: niścale manasi svayam eva prakāśamāna paramānanda svarūpaḥ bhūtvā ātma dhyānāt api nivarteta iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that when the mind is steady, one becomes of the nature of the highest bliss shining forth by itself, and one turns away even from the meditation on the Self.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: bhūmikājayakrameṇa śanaiḥ śanair uparamet /
analyzed: bhūmikā jaya krameṇa śanais śanais uparamet
translated: One should gradually cease by the process of conquering the stages.

original: dhṛtidhairyam akhinnatā tayā gṛhītā yā buddhir avaśyakartavyatāniścayarūpā tayā
analyzed: dhṛti dhairyam akhinna tā tayā gṛhītā yā buddhiḥ avaśya kartavya tā niścaya rūpā tayā
translated: The intellect that is grasped by steadfastness, patience, and indefatigability, which is in the form of the determination of what must be done,

original: yadā kadācid avaśyaṃ bhaviṣyaty eva yogaḥ kiṃ tvarayety evaṃrūpayā śanaiḥ śanair
analyzed: yadā kadācid avaśyam bhaviṣyati eva yogaḥ kim tvarayā iti evaṃrūpayā śanais śanais
translated: one should gradually, with the thought Yoga will certainly happen sometime or other, so what is the hurry?

original: gurūpadiṣṭamārgeṇa mano nirundhyāt /
analyzed: guru upadiṣṭa mārgeṇa manaḥ nirundhyāt
translated: one should restrain the mind by the path taught by the teacher.

original: etenānirvedaniścayau prāg uktau darśitau /
analyzed: etena anirveda niścayau prāk uktau darśitau
translated: By this, indefatigability and determination, which were mentioned earlier, are shown.

original: tathā ca śrutiḥ
analyzed: tathā ca śrutiḥ
translated: And so says the Shruti:

original: yacched vāṅmanasī prājñas
analyzed: yacchet vāc manasī prājñaḥ
translated: The wise one should restrain speech and mind,

original: tad yacchej jñāna ātmani /
analyzed: tat yacchet jñāne ātmani
translated: he should restrain that in the Self through knowledge.

original: jñānam ātmani mahati niyacchet
analyzed: jñānam ātmani mahati niyacchet
translated: One should restrain knowledge in the great Self,

original: tad yacchec chānta ātmani // KaṭhU / / iti /
analyzed: tat yacchet śānte ātmani kaṭhu iti
translated: he should restrain that in the tranquil Self. Katha.

original: vāg iti vācaṃ laukikīṃ vaidikīṃ ca manasi vyāpāravati niyacchet /
analyzed: vāc iti vācam laukikīm vaidikīm ca manasi vyāpāravati niyacchet
translated: Speech means one should restrain speech, both worldly and Vedic, in the active mind.

original: nānudhyāyād bahūn śabdān vāco viglāpanaṃ hi tat BAU / / iti śruteḥ /
analyzed: na anudhyāyāt bahūn śabdān vācaḥ viglāpanam hi tat iti śruteḥ
translated: One should not think of many words, for that is distraction of speech. As stated in the Shruti.

original: vāgvṛttinirodhena manovṛttimātraśeṣo bhaved ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: vāc vṛtti nirodhena manaḥ vṛtti mātra śeṣaḥ bhavet iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that one should be left with only the activities of the mind by restraining the activities of speech.

original: cakṣurādinirodho 'py etasyāṃ bhūmau draṣṭavyaḥ /
analyzed: cakṣuḥ ādi nirodhaḥ pi etasyām bhūmau draṣṭavyaḥ
translated: The restraint of the eye and other senses should also be seen in this stage.

original: manasīti cchāndasaṃ dairghyam /
analyzed: manasi iti chāndasam dairghyam
translated: And the lengthening in manasi is Vedic.🔽That mind, which is the instrument for accomplishing the various alternatives in cooperation with the organs of action and knowledge, one should restrain in the self, in the ego, which is the limiting adjunct of the knower.

original: tan manaḥ karmedriyajñānendriyasahakāri nanavidhavikalpasādhanaṃ karaṇaṃ jñāne jānātīti jñānam iti vyutpattyā jñātary ātmani jñātṛtvopādhāv 🔽ahaṅkāre niyacchet /
analyzed: tat manaḥ karmedriya jñānendriya sahakāri nanavidha vikalpa sādhanam karaṇam jñāne jānāti iti jñānam iti vyutpattyā jñātari ātmani jñātṛ tva upādhau  ahaṅkāre niyacchet
translated: Jñāna is derived as jñāne jānāti, meaning knowledge.

original: manovyāpārān parityajyāhaṅkāramātraṃ pariśeṣayet /
analyzed: manaḥ vyāpārān parityajya ahaṅkāra mātram pariśeṣayet
translated: One should abandon the activities of the mind and retain only the ego.

original: tac ca jñānaṃ jñātṛtvopādhim ahaṅkāram ātmani mahati mahattattve sarvavyāpake niyacchet /
analyzed: tat ca jñānam jñātṛ tva upādhim ahaṅkāram ātmani mahati mahat tattve sarva vyāpake niyacchet
translated: And that knowledge, which is the limiting adjunct of the knower, the ego, one should restrain in the self, in the great principle, which is all-pervading.

original: dvividho hy ahaṅkāro viśeṣarūpaḥ sāmānyarūpaś ceti /
analyzed: dvividhaḥ hi ahaṅkāraḥ viśeṣa rūpaḥ sāmānya rūpaḥ ca iti
translated: For the ego is of two kinds: of a particular form and of a general form.

original: ayam aham etasya putra ity evaṃ vyaktam abhimanyamāno viśeṣarūpo vyaṣṭyahaṅkāraḥ /🔽asmīty etāvanmātram
analyzed: ayam aham etasya putraḥ iti evam vyaktam abhimanyamānaḥ viśeṣa rūpaḥ vyaṣṭi ahaṅkāraḥ  asmi iti etāvat mātram
translated: The ego of a particular form, the individual ego, is that which conceives of itself as I am this, the son of that.

original: abhimanyamānaḥ sāmānyarūpaḥ samaṣṭyahaṅkāraḥ /
analyzed: abhimanyamānaḥ sāmānya rūpaḥ samaṣṭi ahaṅkāraḥ
translated: The ego of a general form, the universal ego, is that which conceives of itself merely as I am.

original: sa ca hiraṇyagarbho mahān ātmeti ca sarvānusyūtatvād ucyate /
analyzed: sa ca hiraṇya garbhaḥ mahān ātmā iti ca sarva anusyūta tvāt ucyate
translated: And that is called Hiranyagarbha, the great Self, because it pervades everything.

original: tābhyām ahaṅkārābhyāṃ vivikto nirupādhikaḥ śāntātmā sarvāntaś cidekarasas tasmin mahāntam ātmānaṃ samaṣṭibuddhiṃ niyacchet /
analyzed: tābhyām ahaṅkārābhyām viviktaḥ nirupādhikaḥ śānta ātmā sarva antaḥ cit ekarasaḥ tasmin mahāntam ātmānam samaṣṭi buddhim niyacchet
translated: He should withdraw the great Self, which is the universal intellect, into that which is free from the two kinds of egoism, which is free from limiting adjuncts, which is the tranquil Self, which is of the nature of pure consciousness alone.

original: evaṃ tatkāraṇam avyaktam api niyacchet /
analyzed: evam tad kāraṇam avyaktam api niyacchet
translated: In the same way, he should withdraw its cause, the unmanifest, also.

original: tato nirupādhikas tvaṃpadalakṣyaḥ śuddha ātmā sākṣātkṛtau bhavati /
analyzed: tatas nirupādhikaḥ tvaṃpada lakṣyaḥ śuddhaḥ ātmā sākṣātkṛtau bhavati
translated: Then, the pure Self, which is the object denoted by the word 'thou' and is free from limiting adjuncts, becomes realized.

original: śuddhe hi cidekarase pratyagātmani jaḍaśaktirūpam anirvācyam avyaktaṃ prakṛtir upādhiḥ /
analyzed: śuddhe hi cit ekarase pratyagātmani jaḍa śakti rūpam anirvācyam avyaktam prakṛtiḥ upādhiḥ
translated: For, in the pure, which is of the nature of pure consciousness alone, the internal Self, the unmanifest, which is of the nature of inert potency and is indescribable, is the limiting adjunct.

original: sā ca prathamaṃ sāmānyāhaṅkārarūpaṃ mahat tattvaṃ nāma dhṛtvā vyaktībhavati /
analyzed: sā ca prathamam sāmānya ahaṅkāra rūpam mahat tattvam nāma dhṛtvā vyaktībhavati
translated: And that, first taking the form of the universal egoism, becomes manifest in the form of the principle of Mahat.

original: tato bahir viśeṣāhaṅkārarūpeṇa /
analyzed: tatas bahis viśeṣa ahaṅkāra rūpeṇa
translated: Then, externally, in the form of particular egoism.

original: tato bahir manorūpeṇa /
analyzed: tatas bahis manaḥ rūpeṇa
translated: Then, externally, in the form of the mind.

original: tato bahir vāgādīn indriyarūpeṇa /
analyzed: tatas bahis vāc ādīn indriya rūpeṇa
translated: Then, externally, in the form of the sense organs such as speech and so on.

original: tad etac chrutyābhihitam
analyzed: tat etat śrutyā abhihitam
translated: This has been stated by the Śruti:

original: indriyebhyaḥ parā hy arthā arthebhyaś ca paraṃ manaḥ /
analyzed: indriyebhyaḥ parāḥ hi arthāḥ arthebhyaḥ ca param manaḥ
translated: The objects are indeed higher than the sense organs, and the mind is higher than the objects.

original: manasas tu parā buddhir buddher ātmā mahān paraḥ //
analyzed: manasaḥ tu parā buddhiḥ buddheḥ ātmā mahān paraḥ
translated: But the intellect is higher than the mind, and the great Self is higher than the intellect.

original: mahataḥ paramavyaktam avyaktāt puruṣaḥ paraḥ /
analyzed: mahataḥ param avyaktam avyaktāt puruṣaḥ paraḥ
translated: The unmanifest is higher than the great, and the Puruṣa is higher than the unmanifest.

original: puruṣān na paraṃ kiṃcit sā kāṣṭhā sā parā gatiḥ // KaṭhU / / iti /
analyzed: puruṣāt na param kiṃcid sā kāṣṭhā sā parā gatiḥ kaṭhu iti
translated: There is nothing higher than the Puruṣa; that is the ultimate, that is the supreme goal. [Kaṭha Upaniṣad]

original: tatra gavādiṣv iva vāṅnirodhaḥ prathamā bhūmiḥ /
analyzed: tatra gavā ādiṣu iva vāc nirodhaḥ prathamā bhūmiḥ
translated: There, like in cows etc., the cessation of speech is the first stage.

original: bālamugdhādiṣv iva nirmanastvaṃ dvitīyā /
analyzed: bāla mugdha ādiṣu iva nirmanaḥ tvam dvitīyā
translated: Like in children, fools etc., the absence of mind is the second.

original: tandryām ivāhaṅkārarāhityaṃ tṛtīyā /
analyzed: tandryām iva ahaṅkāra rāhityam tṛtīyā
translated: Like in drowsiness, the absence of ego is the third.

original: suṣuptāv iva mahattattvaśāntātmanor madhye mahattattvopādānam avyākṛtākhyaṃ tattvaṃ śrutyodāhāri /
analyzed: suṣuptau iva mahat tattva śānta ātmanoḥ madhye mahat tattva upādānam avyākṛta ākhyam tattvam śrutyā udāhāri
translated: Like in deep sleep, the principle called unmanifest, which is the substratum of the tranquil self and the great principle, is mentioned by the Śrutis.

original: tathāpi tatra mahattattvasya niyamanaṃ nābhyadhāyi /
analyzed: tathā api tatra mahat tattvasya niyamanam na abhyadhāyi
translated: Nevertheless, the restriction of the great principle there was not stated.

original: suṣuptāv iva svarūpalayaprasaṅgāt /
analyzed: suṣuptau iva svarūpa laya prasaṅgāt
translated: Because of the possibility of the dissolution of its own nature like in deep sleep.

original: tasya ca karmakṣaye sati puruṣaprayatnam antareṇa svata eva siddhatvāt tattvadarśanānupayogitvāc ca /
analyzed: tasya ca karma kṣaye sati puruṣa prayatnam antareṇa svatas eva siddha tvāt tattva darśana anupayogi tvāt ca
translated: And that, when there is the destruction of karma, is accomplished by itself without human effort and is not useful for the realization of truth.

original: dṛśyate tvam agrayā buddhyā sūkṣmayā sūkṣmadarśibhiḥ iti pūrvam abhidhāya sūkṣmatvasiddhaye nirodhasamādher abhidhānāt /
analyzed: dṛśyate tvam agrayā buddhyā sūkṣmayā sūkṣma darśibhiḥ iti pūrvam abhidhāya sūkṣma tva siddhaye nirodha samādheḥ abhidhānāt
translated: Having said earlier, But you are seen by those who see the subtle with the most subtle intellect, in order to establish subtlety, the cessation-concentration is mentioned.

original: sa ca tattvadidṛkṣor darśanasādhanatvena dṛṣṭatattvasya ca jīvanmuktirūpakleśakṣayāyāpekṣitaḥ /
analyzed: sa ca tattva didṛkṣoḥ darśana sādhana tvena dṛṣṭa tattvasya ca jīvanmukti rūpa kleśa kṣayāya apekṣitaḥ
translated: And that is required for one who desires to see reality as a means of seeing, and for one who has seen reality, for the destruction of the affliction in the form of living liberation.

original: nanu śāntātmany avaruddhasya cittasya vṛttirahitatvena suṣuptivan na darśanahetutvam iti cet / na /
analyzed: nanu śānta ātmani avaruddhasya cittasya vṛtti rahita tvena suṣupti vat na darśana hetu tvam iti ced na
translated: But if it be said that the mind, which is confined to the tranquil Self, cannot be the cause of perception, because it is devoid of modifications, like the mind in deep sleep, [we reply:] No.

original: svataḥsiddhasya darśanasya nivārayitum aśakyatvāt / tad uktaṃ
analyzed: svatas siddhasya darśanasya nivārayitum aśakya tvāt tat uktam
translated: For the perception, which is self-established, cannot be prevented. This has been said:

original: ātmānātmākāraṃ svabhāvato 'sthitaṃ sadā cittam /
analyzed: ātma an ātma ākāram svabhāvataḥ sthitam sadā cittam
translated: The mind, which is of the nature of the Self and the non-Self, is always unestablished.

original: ātmaikākāratayā tiraskṛtānātmadṛṣṭiṃ vidadhīta //
analyzed: ātma eka ākāra tayā tiraskṛta anātma dṛṣṭim vidadhīta
translated: One should direct the mind to the vision of the non-Self, which is obscured by the vision of the Self alone.

original: yathā ghaṭa utpadyamānaḥ svato viyatpūrṇaṃ evotpadyate /
analyzed: yathā ghaṭaḥ utpadyamānaḥ svatas viyat pūrṇam eva utpadyate
translated: Just as a pot, when being produced, is produced as filled with space by its own nature.

original: jalataṇḍulādipūraṇaṃ tūtpanne ghaṭe paścāt puruṣaprayatnena bhavati /
analyzed: jala taṇḍula ādi pūraṇam tu utpanne ghaṭe paścāt puruṣa prayatnena bhavati
translated: But the filling with water, rice grains, etc. occurs later, after the pot is produced, by human effort.

original: tatra jalādau niḥsārite 'pi viyanniḥsārayituṃ na śakyate /
analyzed: tatra jala ādau niḥsārite viyat niḥsārayitum na śakyate
translated: There, even when the water, etc. are removed, space cannot be removed.

original: mukhapidhāne 'py antarviyad avatiṣṭhata eva tathā cittam utpadyamānaṃ caitanyapūrṇam evotpadyate /
analyzed: mukha pidhāne pi antar viyat avatiṣṭhate eva tathā cittam utpadyamānam caitanya pūrṇam eva utpadyate
translated: Even when the mouth is closed, the space inside remains. In the same way, the mind, when being produced, is produced as filled with consciousness.

original: utpanne tu tasmin mūṣāniṣiktadrutatāmravad ghaṭaduḥkhādirūpatvaṃ bhogahetudharmādharmasahakṛtasāmagrīvaśād bhavati /
analyzed: utpanne tu tasmin mūṣā niṣikta druta tāmra vat ghaṭa duḥkha ādi rūpa tvam bhoga hetu dharma adharma sahakṛta sāmagrī vaśāt bhavati
translated: But when it is produced, it becomes of the nature of a pot, suffering, etc., like molten copper poured into a mold, by the power of the totality of conditions consisting of Dharma and Adharma, which are the causes of experience.

original: tatra ghaṭaduḥkhādyanātmākāre virāmapratyayābhyāsena nivārite 'pi nirnimittaś cidākāro vārayituṃ na śakyate /
analyzed: tatra ghaṭa duḥkha ādi anātma ākāre virāma pratyaya abhyāsena nivārite nirnimittaḥ cit ākāraḥ vārayitum na śakyate
translated: There, even when the forms of the non-self such as pot, pain, etc. are prevented by the practice of the notion of cessation, the form of consciousness without any cause cannot be prevented.

original: tato nirodhasamādhinā nirvṛttikena cittena saṃskāramātraśeṣatayātisūkṣmatvena nirupādhikacidātmamātrābhimukhatvād vṛttiṃ vinaiva nirvighnam
analyzed: tatas nirodha samādhinā nirvṛttikena cittena saṃskāra mātra śeṣatayā ati sūkṣma tvena nirupādhika cit ātma mātra abhimukha tvāt vṛttim vinā eva nirvighnam
translated: Then, by the cessation-trance which is without operation, the mind becomes extremely subtle by the mere residue of impressions, and being turned towards the unconditioned consciousness-self alone, without any obstruction,

original: ātmānubhūyate /
analyzed: ātmā anubhūyate
translated: the self is experienced.

original: tad etad āha ātmasaṃsthaṃ manaḥ kṛtvā na kiṃcid api cintayed iti / ātmani
analyzed: tat etat āha ātma saṃstham manaḥ kṛtvā na kiṃcid api cintayet iti ātmani
translated: This is said: Having fixed the mind in the self, one should think of nothing at all. The mind which has its end, i.e. completion, in the self,

original: nirupādhike pratīci saṃsthā samāptir yasya tadātmasaṃsthaṃ sarvaprakāravṛttiśūnyaṃ
analyzed: nirupādhike pratīci saṃsthā samāptiḥ yasya tad ātma saṃstham sarva prakāra vṛtti śūnyam
translated: which is free from limiting adjuncts, which is turned inward, which is devoid of all kinds of operations,

original: svabhāvasiddhātmākāramātraviśiṣṭaṃ manaḥ kṛtvā dhṛtigṛhītayā vivekabuddhyā sampādyāsaṃprajñātasamādhisthaḥ
analyzed: svabhāva siddha ātma ākāra mātra viśiṣṭam manaḥ kṛtvā dhṛti gṛhītayā viveka buddhyā sampādya asaṃprajñāta samādhi sthaḥ
translated: which is distinguished only by the form of the self established by nature, having made it so by the discriminating knowledge held by steadfastness, being established in the trance without definite form,

original: san kiṃcid api anātmānam ātmānaṃ vā na cintayet /
analyzed: san kiṃcid api anātmānam ātmānam vā na cintayet
translated: one should not think of anything at all, either the non-self or the self.

original: na vṛttyā viṣayīkuryāt /
analyzed: na vṛttyā viṣayīkuryāt
translated: One should not make it an object by operation.

original: anātmākāravṛttau hi vyutthānam eva syāt /
analyzed: anātma ākāra vṛttau hi vyutthānam eva syāt
translated: For if there were an operation in the form of the non-self, it would be mere distraction.

original: ātmākāravṛttau ca samprajñātaḥ samādhir ity asamprajñātasamādhisthairyāya kām api cittavṛttiṃ notpādayed ity arthaḥ ////
analyzed: ātma ākāra vṛttau ca samprajñātaḥ samādhiḥ iti asamprajñāta samādhi sthairyāya kām api citta vṛttim na utpādayet iti arthaḥ
translated: And when the mind is fixed on the form of the Self, it is concentration with awareness. The meaning is that one should not produce any mental modification for the stability of concentration without awareness.

original: viśvanāthaḥ / See BhG / /
analyzed: viśvanāthaḥ see bhg
translated: Viśvanātha: See BhG

original: baladevaḥ / antimaṃ kṛtyam āha dhṛtigṛhītayā dhāraṇāvaśīkṛtyā buddhyā mana ātmasaṃsthaṃ kṛtvātmānaṃ dhyātvā samādhāv uparameta tiṣṭhet /
analyzed: baladevaḥ antimam kṛtyam āha dhṛti gṛhītayā dhāraṇā vaśīkṛtyā buddhyā manaḥ ātma saṃstham kṛtvā ātmānam dhyātvā samādhau uparameta tiṣṭhet
translated: Balarāma: The last duty is stated: Having made the mind fixed in the Self by the intellect controlled by steadiness, having meditated on the Self, one should cease, i.e. remain, in concentration.

original: ātmano 'nyat kiṃcid api na cintayet /
analyzed: ātmanaḥ nyat kiṃcid api na cintayet
translated: One should not think of anything else at all.

original: etac ca śanaiḥ śanair abhyāsakrameṇa /
analyzed: etat ca śanais śanais abhyāsa krameṇa
translated: And this should be done gradually, by the practice of concentration.

original: na tu haṭhena ////
analyzed: na tu haṭhena
translated: But not forcibly.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG

original: yato yato niścarati manaś cañcalam asthiram /
analyzed: yatas yatas niścarati manaḥ cañcalam asthiram
translated: From whatever direction the fickle, unsteady mind wanders,

original: tatas tato niyamyaitad ātmany eva vaśaṃ nayet ////
analyzed: tatas tatas niyamya etat ātmani eva vaśam nayet
translated: from that very direction one should restrain it and bring it under control in the Self alone.

original: śrīdharaḥ / evam api rajoguṇavaśād yadi manaḥ pracalet tarhi punaḥ pratyāhāreṇa vaśīkuryād ity āha yato yata iti /
translated: Śrīdhara: Even so, if the mind were to move due to the influence of the quality of rajas, then one should again control it by withdrawal. This is stated by From whatever direction etc.

original: svabhāvataś cañcalaṃ dhāryamāṇam apy asthiraṃ mano yaṃ yaṃ viṣayaṃ prati nirgacchati /
analyzed: svabhāvataḥ cañcalam dhāryamāṇam api asthiram manaḥ yam yam viṣayam prati nirgacchati
translated: The mind, which is naturally fickle and unsteady even when held, wanders towards this and that object.

original: tatas tataḥ pratyāhṛtyātmany eva sthiraṃ kuryāt ////
analyzed: tatas tatas pratyāhṛtya ātmani eva sthiram kuryāt
translated: Then, having withdrawn it from here and there, he should make it steady in the Self itself.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: evaṃ nirodhasamādhiṃ kurvan yogī śabdādīnāṃ cittavikṣepahetūnāṃ madhye yato yato🔽yasmād yasmān nimittāc chabdāder viṣayād rāgadveṣādeś ca cañcalaṃ vikṣepābhimukhaṃ
analyzed: evam nirodha samādhim kurvan yogī śabda ādīnām citta vikṣepa hetūnām madhye yatas yatas  yasmāt yasmāt nimittāt śabda ādeḥ viṣayāt rāga dveṣa ādeḥ ca cañcalam vikṣepa abhimukham
translated: Thus, the yogi, practicing the meditation of cessation, from among the causes of distraction of the mind such as sound etc.,🔽from whatever cause,

original: san mano niścarati vikṣiptaṃ sad viṣayābhimukhīṃ pramāṇaviparyayavikalpasmṛtīnām
analyzed: sat manaḥ niścarati vikṣiptam sat viṣaya abhimukhīm pramāṇa viparyaya vikalpa smṛtīnām
translated: from whatever object such as sound etc. and attachment, aversion etc., the fickle mind, inclined towards distraction,

original: anyatamām api samādhivirodhinīṃ vṛttim utpādayati /
analyzed: anyatamām api samādhi virodhinīm vṛttim utpādayati
translated: moving out, being distracted, produces one or other modification opposed to concentration,🔽such as valid cognition, erroneous cognition, imagination, memory etc.,🔽facing the objects.

original: tathā layahetūnāṃ nidrāśeṣabahvaśanaśramādīnāṃ madhye yato yato nimittād asthiraṃ layābhimukhaṃ san mano niścarati līnaṃ sat samādhivirodhinīṃ
analyzed: tathā laya hetūnām nidrā śeṣa bahu aśana śrama ādīnām madhye yatas yatas nimittāt asthiram laya abhimukham sat manaḥ niścarati līnam sat samādhi virodhinīm
translated: Similarly, from among the causes of dullness such as sleep, excess food, fatigue etc., from whatever cause, the unsteady mind, inclined towards dullness, moving out, being absorbed, produces a modification opposed to concentration,

original: nidrākhyāṃ vṛttim utpādayati /
analyzed: nidrā ākhyām vṛttim utpādayati
translated: called sleep.

original: tatas tato vikṣepanimittāl layanimittāc ca niyamyaitan mano nirvṛttikaṃ kṛtvātmany eva svaprakāśaparamānandaghane vaśaṃ nayen nirundhyāt
analyzed: tatas tatas vikṣepa nimittāt laya nimittāt ca niyamya etat manaḥ nirvṛttikam kṛtvā ātmani eva sva prakāśa parama ānanda ghane vaśam nayet nirundhyāt
translated: Then, having restrained this mind from those causes of distraction and dullness, having made it free from modifications, he should bring it under control, should restrain it, in the Self itself, which is full of self-luminous supreme bliss.

original: yathā na vikṣipyeta na vā līyeteti /
analyzed: yathā na vikṣipyeta na vā līyeta iti
translated: So that it is not distracted or absorbed.

original: evakāro 'nātmagocaratvaṃ samādher vārayati /
analyzed: eva kāraḥ na ātma gocara tvam samādheḥ vārayati
translated: The word only prevents the concentration from having a non-self object.

original: etac ca vivṛtaṃ gauḍācāryapādaiḥ
analyzed: etat ca vivṛtam gauḍa ācārya pādaiḥ
translated: And this has been explained by the venerable master Gauḍapāda:

original: upāyena nigṛhṇīyād vikṣiptaṃ kāmabhogayoḥ /
analyzed: upāyena nigṛhṇīyāt vikṣiptam kāma bhogayoḥ
translated: One should restrain the distracted mind with a means in regard to the enjoyment of sensual pleasures.

original: suprasannaṃ laye caiva yathā kāmo layas tathā //
analyzed: su prasannam laye ca eva yathā kāmaḥ layaḥ tathā
translated: And the well-pleased one in absorption, just as absorption is in sensual pleasures.

original: duḥkhaṃ sarvam anusmṛtya kāmabhogān nivartayet /
analyzed: duḥkham sarvam anusmṛtya kāma bhogān nivartayet
translated: Remembering all suffering, one should turn away from the enjoyment of sensual pleasures.

original: ajaṃ sarvam anusmṛtya jātaṃ naiva tu paśyati //🔽laye sambodhayec cittaṃ vikṣiptaṃ śamayet punaḥ /
analyzed: ajam sarvam anusmṛtya jātam na eva tu paśyati
translated: Remembering all as unborn, one does not see anything born.🔽One should arouse the mind in absorption, and again calm the distracted one.

original: sakaṣāyaṃ vijānīyāt samaprāptaṃ na cālayet //
analyzed: sa kaṣāyam vijānīyāt sama prāptam na cālayet
translated: One should know the mind with defilements, and not move the mind that has attained equanimity.

original: nāsvādayet sukhaṃ tatra niḥsaṅgaḥ prajñayā bhavet /
analyzed: na āsvādayet sukham tatra niḥsaṅgaḥ prajñayā bhavet
translated: One should not taste the pleasure there, being detached through wisdom.

original: niścalaṃ nicśarac cittam ekīkuryāt prayatnataḥ //
analyzed: niścalam cittam ekīkuryāt prayatnataḥ
translated: One should carefully unify the mind that is unmoving and free from thought.

original: yadā na līyate cittaṃ na ca vikṣipyate punaḥ /
analyzed: yadā na līyate cittam na ca vikṣipyate punar
translated: When the mind is neither absorbed nor again distracted,

original: aniṅganam anābhāsaṃ niṣpannaṃ brahma tat tadā //
analyzed: an iṅganam an ābhāsam niṣpannam brahma tat tadā
translated: Then that is the accomplished Brahman, without support and without appearance.

original: iti pañcabhiḥ ślokaiḥ /
analyzed: iti pañcabhiḥ ślokaiḥ
translated: Thus with five verses.

original: upāyena vakṣyamāṇena vairāgyābhyāsena kāmabhogayor vikṣiptaṃ pramāṇaviparyayavikalpasmṛtīnām anyatamayāpi vṛttyā pariṇataṃ mano nigṛhṇīyān
analyzed: upāyena vakṣyamāṇena vairāgya abhyāsena kāma bhogayoḥ vikṣiptam pramāṇa viparyaya vikalpa smṛtīnām anyatamayā api vṛttyā pariṇatam manaḥ nigṛhṇīyān
translated: One should restrain the mind, which is distracted by either desire for sensual enjoyment or by the fluctuations of the mind such as valid cognition, error, imagination, or memory, by the means of detachment which will be mentioned later, by practice.

original: nirundhyād ātmany evety arthaḥ /
analyzed: nirundhyāt ātmani eva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: one should restrain it in the self alone.

original: kāmabhogayor iti cintyamānāvasthābhujyamānāvasthābhedena dvivacanam /
analyzed: kāma bhogayoḥ iti cintyamāna avasthā bhujyamāna avasthā bhedena dvivacanam
translated: The dual number in desire for sensual enjoyment is used to distinguish the two states: the state of being thought about and the state of being enjoyed.

original: tathā līyate 'sminn iti layaḥ suṣuptaṃ tasmin suprasannam āyāsavarjitam api mano nigṛhṇīyād eva /
analyzed: tathā līyate smin iti layaḥ suṣuptam tasmin su prasannam āyāsa varjitam api manaḥ nigṛhṇīyāt eva
translated: One should also restrain the mind, which is very tranquil and free from distress, in that [state] called deep sleep, where it merges.

original: suprasannaṃ cet kuto nigṛhyate /
analyzed: su prasannam ced kutas nigṛhyate
translated: If it is very tranquil, how can it be restrained?

original: tatrāha yathā kāmo viṣayagocarapramāṇādivṛttyutpādanena samādhivirodhī tathā layo 'pi nidrākhyavṛttyutpādanena samādhivirodhī /
analyzed: tatra āha yathā kāmaḥ viṣaya gocara pramāṇa ādi vṛtti utpādanena samādhi virodhī tathā layaḥ pi nidrā ākhya vṛtti utpādanena samādhi virodhī
translated: In that regard, he says: Just as desire, by producing the fluctuations of the mind such as valid cognition that has the object as its domain, is opposed to concentration, so too is merging, by producing the fluctuation called sleep, opposed to concentration.

original: sarvavṛttinirodho hi samādhiḥ /
analyzed: sarva vṛtti nirodhaḥ hi samādhiḥ
translated: For concentration is the cessation of all fluctuations.

original: ataḥ kāmādikṛtavikṣepād iva śramādikṛtalayād api mano niroddhavyam ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: atas kāma ādi kṛta vikṣepāt iva śrama ādi kṛta layāt api manaḥ niroddhavyam iti arthaḥ
translated: Therefore, just as from distraction caused by desire and so on, so also from merging caused by fatigue and so on, the mind should be restrained. This is the meaning.

original: upāyena nigṛhṇīyāt kena /
analyzed: upāyena nigṛhṇīyāt kena
translated: By what means should one restrain it?

original: ity ucyate sarvaṃ dvaitam avidyāvijṛmbhitam alpaṃ duḥkham evety anusmṛtya yo vai bhūmā tat sukhaṃ /
analyzed: iti ucyate sarvam dvaitam avidyā vijṛmbhitam alpam duḥkham eva iti anusmṛtya yaḥ vai bhūmā tat sukham
translated: Thus, it is said that all duality is the manifestation of ignorance, and it is but little and only misery. Remembering this, he who is the all-pervading, that is bliss.

original: nālpe sukham asti /
analyzed: na alpe sukham asti
translated: There is no bliss in the little.🔽Chāndogya.

original: ChāU / / atha yad alpaṃ tan martyaṃ ChāU / / tad duḥkham iti śrutyarthaṃ
analyzed: atha yat alpam tat martyam chāu tat duḥkham iti śruti artham
translated: Now, what is little, that is mortal, Chāndogya. That is misery. This is the meaning of the Śruti.

original: gurūpadeśād anu paścāt paryālocya kāmāṃś cintyamānāvasthān viṣayān bhogān bhujyamānāvasthāṃś
analyzed: guru upadeśāt anu paścāt paryālocya kāmān cintyamāna avasthān viṣayān bhogān bhujyamāna avasthān
translated: Having reflected on the objects of desire in the state of being thought of and the objects of enjoyment in the state of being enjoyed,

original: ca viṣayān nivartayet /
analyzed: ca viṣayān nivartayet
translated: he should turn away the mind from them.

original: manasaḥ sakāśād iti śeṣaḥ /
analyzed: manasaḥ sakāśāt iti śeṣaḥ
translated: The rest is from the mind.

original: kāmaś ca bhogaś ca kāmabhogaṃ tasmān mano nivartayed iti vā /
analyzed: kāmaḥ ca bhogaḥ ca kāma bhogam tasmāt manaḥ nivartayet iti vā
translated: Or, he should turn away the mind from desire and enjoyment.

original: evaṃ dvaitasmaraṇakāle vairāgyabhāvanopāya ity arthaḥ /🔽dvaitavismaraṇaṃ tu paramopāya ity āha ajaṃ brahma sarvaṃ na tato 'tiriktaṃ kiṃcid astīti śāstrācāryopadeśād anantaram anusmṛtya tadviparītaṃ
analyzed: evam dvaita smaraṇa kāle vairāgya bhāvanā upāyaḥ iti arthaḥ  dvaita vismaraṇam tu parama upāyaḥ iti āha ajam brahma sarvam na tatas tiriktam kiṃcid asti iti śāstra ācārya upadeśāt anantaram anusmṛtya tad viparītam
translated: Thus, at the time of remembering duality, this is the means of cultivating non-attachment.🔽But the forgetting of duality is the highest means. Therefore, he says: Having remembered that the unborn Brahman is all and there is nothing apart from it, after the instruction of the scriptures and the teacher, he does not see that duality which is contrary to that,

original: dvaitajātaṃ na paśyaty eva /
analyzed: dvaita jātam na paśyati eva
translated: at all.

original: adhiṣṭhāne jñāne kalpitasyābhāvāt /
analyzed: adhiṣṭhāne jñāne kalpitasya abhāvāt
translated: Because what is imagined does not exist in the knowledge of the substratum.

original: pūrvopāyāpekṣayā vailakṣaṇyasūcanārthas
translated: In order to indicate the difference from the previous means,

original: tuśabdaḥ /
analyzed: tuśabdaḥ
translated: The word 'tu' (but).

original: evaṃ vairāgyabhāvanātattvadarśanābhyāṃ viṣayebhyo nivartyamānaṃ cittaṃ yadi dainandinalayābhyāsavaśāl🔽layābhimukhaṃ bhavet tadā nidrāśeṣājīrṇabahvaśanaśramāṇāṃ layakāraṇānāṃ nirodhena
analyzed: evam vairāgya bhāvanā tattva darśanābhyām viṣayebhyaḥ nivartyamānam cittam yadi  laya abhimukham bhavet tadā nidrā śeṣa ajīrṇa bahu aśana śramāṇām laya kāraṇānām nirodhena
translated: Thus, the mind, which is being turned away from objects by the cultivation of detachment and the realization of reality, if it becomes inclined towards inertia due to the habit of daily inertia,

original: cittaṃ samyak prabodhayed utthānaprayatnena /
analyzed: cittam samyak prabodhayet utthāna prayatnena
translated: then one should properly awaken the mind with the effort of rising, by stopping the causes of inertia such as sleep, indigestion, overeating, and exertion.

original: yadi punar evaṃ prabodhyamānaṃ dainandinaprabodhābhyāsavaśāt kāmabhogayor vikṣiptaṃ syāt tadā vairāgyabhāvanayā tattvasākṣātkāreṇa ca 🔽punaḥ śamayet /
analyzed: yadi punar evam prabodhyamānam kāma bhogayoḥ vikṣiptam syāt tadā vairāgya bhāvanayā tattva sākṣātkāreṇa ca  punar śamayet
translated: But if the mind, being thus awakened, becomes distracted towards sensual pleasures due to the habit of daily awakening, then one should again pacify it by the cultivation of detachment and the direct realization of reality.

original: evaṃ punaḥ punar abhyasyato layāt sambodhitaṃ viṣayebhyaś ca vyāvartitam /
analyzed: evam punar punar abhyasyataḥ layāt sambodhitam viṣayebhyaḥ ca vyāvartitam
translated: Thus, the mind, which is repeatedly practiced in this way, is awakened from inertia and turned away from objects.

original: nāpi samaprāptam antarālāvasthaṃ cittaṃ stabdhībhūtaṃ /
analyzed: na api sama prāptam antarāla avastham cittam stabdhībhūtam
translated: Nor should one consider the mind in the intermediate state, which is neither fully awakened nor fully turned away, to be dull.

original: sakaṣāyaṃ rāgadveṣādiprabalavāsanāvaśena stabdhībhāvākhyena kaṣāyeṇa doṣeṇa yuktaṃ vijānīyāt samāhitāc cittād vivekena jānīyāt /
analyzed: sa kaṣāyam rāga dveṣa ādi prabala vāsanā vaśena stabdhībhāva ākhyena kaṣāyeṇa doṣeṇa yuktam vijānīyāt samāhitāt cittāt vivekena jānīyāt
translated: One should know with discrimination from the concentrated mind that it is tainted, endowed with the fault called dullness, due to the strong impressions of passion, hatred, and so on.

original: tataś ca nedaṃ samāhitam ity avagamya layavikṣepābhyām iva kaṣāyād api cittaṃ nirundhyāt /
analyzed: tatas ca na idam samāhitam iti avagamya laya vikṣepābhyām iva kaṣāyāt api cittam nirundhyāt
translated: Then, understanding that this is not concentrated, he should restrain the mind from defilement, as if from languor and distraction.

original: tataś ca layavikṣepakaṣāyeṣu parihṛteṣu pariśeṣāc cittena samaṃ brahma prāpyate /
analyzed: tatas ca laya vikṣepa kaṣāyeṣu parihṛteṣu pariśeṣāt cittena samam brahma prāpyate
translated: And then, when languor, distraction and defilement have been removed, the Brahman is attained along with the mind, by elimination of the rest.

original: tac ca samaprāptaṃ cittaṃ kaṣāyalayabhrāntyā na cālayet /
analyzed: tat ca sama prāptam cittam kaṣāya laya bhrāntyā na cālayet
translated: And that mind which has been attained equally should not be moved by the error of languor and defilement.

original: viṣayābhimukhaṃ na kuryāt /
analyzed: viṣaya abhimukham na kuryāt
translated: It should not be made to face objects.

original: kintu dhṛtigṛhītayā buddhyā layakaṣāyaprāpter vivicya tasyām eva samaprāptāv atiyatnena sthāpayet /
analyzed: kintu dhṛti gṛhītayā buddhyā laya kaṣāya prāpteḥ vivicya tasyām eva samaprāptau atiyatnena sthāpayet
translated: But by the intellect held firm, he should, by discriminating the attainment of languor and defilement, establish it with great effort in that very attainment of equality.

original: tatra samādhau paramasukhavyañjake 'pi sukhaṃ nāsvādayet /
analyzed: tatra samādhau parama sukha vyañjake sukham na āsvādayet
translated: In that concentration, even though it manifests supreme bliss, he should not enjoy the bliss.

original: etāvantaṃ kālam ahaṃ sukhīti sukhāsvādarūpāṃ vṛttiṃ na kuryāt samādhibhaṅgaprasaṅgāt iti prāg eva kṛtavyākhyānam /
analyzed: etāvantam kālam aham sukhī iti sukha āsvāda rūpām vṛttim na kuryāt samādhi bhaṅga prasaṅgāt iti prāk eva kṛta vyākhyānam
translated: For so long I have been happy - he should not perform the function of enjoying bliss, because it would lead to the breaking of concentration. This has already been explained before.

original: prajñayā yad upalabhyate sukhaṃ tad apy avidyāparikalpitaṃ mṛṣaivety evaṃbhāvanayā niḥsaṅgo nispṛhaḥ sarvasukheṣu bhavet /
analyzed: prajñayā yat upalabhyate sukham tat api avidyā parikalpitam mṛṣā eva iti evaṃbhāvanayā niḥsaṅgaḥ nispṛhaḥ sarva sukheṣu bhavet
translated: By the contemplation that even that bliss which is perceived by wisdom is false, imagined by ignorance, he should be detached, desireless, in all kinds of bliss.

original: athavā prajñayā savikalpasukhākāravṛttirūpayā saha saṅgaṃ parityajet /
analyzed: athavā prajñayā sa vikalpa sukha ākāra vṛtti rūpayā saha saṅgam parityajet
translated: Or else, one should abandon attachment along with wisdom, which has the form of functioning with conceptualized pleasant aspects.

original: na tu svarūpasukham api nirvṛttikena cittena nānubhavet svabhāvaprāptasya tasya vārayitum aśakyatvāt /
analyzed: na tu sva rūpa sukham api nirvṛttikena cittena nā anubhavet svabhāva prāptasya tasya vārayitum aśakya tvāt
translated: But one should not even not experience the bliss of one's own nature with a mind free from activity, because that which is attained by nature cannot be prevented.

original: evaṃ sarvato nivartya niścalaṃ prayatnavaśena kṛtaṃ cittaṃ svabhāvacāñcalyād viṣayābhimukhatayā niścarad bahir nirgacchad ekīkuryāt prayatnataḥ /
analyzed: evam sarvatas nivartya niścalam prayatna vaśena kṛtam cittam svabhāva cāñcalyāt viṣaya abhimukha tayā niścarat bahis nirgacchat ekīkuryāt prayatnataḥ
translated: Having thus turned away from everything, the mind, which has been made motionless by the power of effort, should be made one, as it tends to move outward, facing objects due to its naturally restless nature.

original: nirodhaprayatnena same brahmaṇy ekatāṃ nayet /
analyzed: nirodha prayatnena same brahmaṇi eka tām nayet
translated: With the effort of cessation, one should lead it to unity in the Brahman, which is even.

original: samaprāptaṃ cittaṃ kīdṛśam /
analyzed: sama prāptam cittam kīdṛśam
translated: And what is the mind that has attained evenness like?

original: ity ucyate yadā na līyate nāpi stabdhībhavati tāmasatvasāmyena layaśabdenaiva stabdhībhāvasyopalakṣaṇāt /
analyzed: iti ucyate yadā na līyate na api stabdhībhavati tāmasa tva sāmyena laya śabdena eva stabdhībhāvasya upalakṣaṇāt
translated: This is said: When it neither dissolves nor becomes dull, due to the equality of tamas, as dullness is indicated by the word dissolution itself.

original: na ca vikṣipyate punaḥ /
analyzed: na ca vikṣipyate punar
translated: And it is not distracted again.

original: na śabdādyākāravṛttim anubhavati /
analyzed: na śabda ādi ākāra vṛttim anubhavati
translated: It does not experience functioning in the form of sound and so on.

original: nāpi sukham āsvādayati /
analyzed: na api sukham āsvādayati
translated: Nor does it enjoy bliss.

original: rājasatvasāmyena sukhāsvādasyāpi vikṣepaśabdenopalakṣaṇāt /
analyzed: rājasa tva sāmyena sukha āsvādasya api vikṣepa śabdena upalakṣaṇāt
translated: As the enjoyment of bliss is also indicated by the word distraction due to the equality of rajas.

original: pūrvaṃ bhedanirdeśas tu pṛthakprayatnakaraṇāya /
analyzed: pūrvam bheda nirdeśaḥ tu pṛthak prayatna karaṇāya
translated: The teaching of difference earlier is for making effort separately.

original: evaṃ layakaṣāyābhyāṃ vikṣepasukhāsvādābhyāṃ ca rahitam aniṅganam iṅganaṃ calanaṃ savātapradīpaval layābhimukhyarūpaṃ tadrahitaṃ nivātapradīpakalpam
analyzed: evam laya kaṣāyābhyām vikṣepa sukha āsvādābhyām ca rahitam aniṅganam iṅganam calanam sa vāta pradīpa vat laya ābhimukhya rūpam tad rahitam nivāta pradīpa kalpam
translated: Thus, free from dullness, excitement, the taste of distraction and pleasure, it is unmoving. Moving means shaking, like a lamp in the wind. Free from that, it is like a lamp in a windless place.

original: anābhāsaṃ na kenacid viṣayākāreṇābhāsata ity etat /
analyzed: anābhāsam na kenacid viṣaya ākāreṇa ābhāsate iti etat
translated: It is non-manifest, meaning it does not appear in any form of objects.

original: kaṣāyasukhāsvādayor ubhayāntarbhāva ukta eva /
analyzed: kaṣāya sukha āsvādayoḥ ubhaya antarbhāvaḥ uktaḥ eva
translated: The inclusion of both dullness and the taste of pleasure has already been explained.

original: yadaivaṃ doṣacatuṣṭayarahitaṃ cittaṃ bhavati tadā tac cittaṃ brahma niṣpannaṃ samaṃ brahma prāptaṃ bhavatīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: yadā evam doṣa catuṣṭaya rahitam cittam bhavati tadā tat cittam brahma niṣpannam samam brahma prāptam bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: When the mind becomes free from these four faults in this way, then that mind becomes accomplished Brahman, it attains equality with Brahman, is the meaning.

original: etādṛśaś ca yogaḥ śrutyā pratipāditaḥ
analyzed: etādṛśaḥ ca yogaḥ śrutyā pratipāditaḥ
translated: And this kind of yoga has been taught by the Vedas:

original: yadā pañcāvatiṣṭhante jñānāni manasā saha /
analyzed: yadā pañca avatiṣṭhante jñānāni manasā saha
translated: When the five [sense perceptions] and the mind abide,

original: buddhiś ca na viceṣṭeta tām āhuḥ paramāṃ gatim //
analyzed: buddhiḥ ca na viceṣṭeta tām āhuḥ paramām gatim
translated: and the intellect does not move, they call that the highest goal.

original: tāṃ yogam iti manyante sthirām indriyadhāraṇām /
analyzed: tām yogam iti manyante sthirām indriya dhāraṇām
translated: They consider that to be yoga, the firm control of the senses.

original: apramattas tadā bhavati yogo hi prabhavāpyayau // KaṭhU / / iti /
analyzed: apramattaḥ tadā bhavati yogaḥ hi prabhava apyayau kaṭhu iti
translated: Then one becomes heedful, for yoga is the origin and end of both. [Katha Upanishad]

original: etanmūlakam eva ca yogaś cittavṛttinirodhaḥ YogaS / iti sūtram /
analyzed: etad mūlakam eva ca yogaḥ citta vṛtti nirodhaḥ yogaḥ iti sūtram
translated: And the aphorism Yoga is the cessation of the fluctuations of the mind has this [Vedic teaching] as its basis.

original: tasmād yuktaṃ tatas tato niyamyaitad ātmany evaṃ vaśaṃ nayed iti ////
analyzed: tasmāt yuktam tatas tatas niyamya etat ātmani evam vaśam nayet iti
translated: Therefore, it is proper that one should thus bring this (mind) under control from here and there and bring it under control in the Self.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha:

original: yadi ca prāktanadoṣodgamavaśād rajoguṇaspṛṣṭaṃ manaś cañcalaṃ syāt /
analyzed: yadi ca prāktana doṣa udgama vaśāt rajaḥ guṇa spṛṣṭam manaḥ cañcalam syāt
translated: If the mind, touched by the quality of rajas, becomes unsteady due to the arising of past faults,

original: tadā punar yogam abhyased ity āha yato yata iti ////
analyzed: tadā punar yogam abhyaset iti āha yatas yatas iti
translated: then one should practice yoga again. Thus it is said, 'from whatever' etc.

original: baladevaḥ / yadi kadācit prāktanasūkṣmadoṣān manaḥ pracalet tadā tat pratyāhared ity āha yata iti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ yadi kadācid prāktana sūkṣma doṣāt manaḥ pracalet tadā tat pratyāharet iti āha yatas iti
translated: Balarama: If the mind sometimes becomes unsteady due to past subtle faults, then one should withdraw it. Thus it is said, 'from whatever' etc.

original: yaṃ yaṃ viṣayaṃ prati mano nirgacchati /
analyzed: yam yam viṣayam prati manaḥ nirgacchati
translated: Wherever the mind goes out towards an object,

original: tatas tata etan mano niyamya pratyāhṛtyātmany eva niratiśayasukhatvabhāvanayā vaśaṃ kuryāt ////
analyzed: tatas tatas etat manaḥ niyamya pratyāhṛtya ātmani eva niratiśaya sukha tva bhāvanayā vaśam kuryāt
translated: from there, from that, one should control this mind, withdraw it, and bring it under control in the Self alone by contemplating on it as having supreme bliss.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: Bhagavad Gita

original: praśāntamanasaṃ hy enaṃ yoginaṃ sukham uttamam /
analyzed: praśānta manasam hi enam yoginam sukham uttamam
translated: For the mind of that yogi who is tranquil, supreme bliss

original: upaiti śāntarajasaṃ brahmabhūtam akalmaṣam ////
analyzed: upaiti śānta rajasam brahma bhūtam akalmaṣam
translated: approaches, he who is free from rajas, who is identified with Brahman, and who is sinless.

original: śrīdharaḥ / evaṃ pratyāhārādibhiḥ punaḥ punar mano vaśīkurvan rajoguṇakṣaye sati yogasukhaṃ prāpnotīty āha praśānteti /
translated: Sridhar: Thus, repeatedly controlling the mind through pratyahara and other means, when the quality of rajas is destroyed, one attains the bliss of yoga. This is said by 'prashanta' etc.

original: evam uktaprakāreṇa śāntaṃ rajo yasya tam /
analyzed: evam ukta prakāreṇa śāntam rajaḥ yasya tam
translated: He who has tranquility of rajas in the manner described.

original: ataeva praśāntaṃ mano yasya tam enaṃ niṣkalmaṣam brahmatvaṃ prāptaṃ yoginaṃ uttamam sukhaṃ samādhisukhaṃ svayam evopaiti prāpnoti ////
analyzed: ataeva praśāntam manaḥ yasya tam enam niṣkalmaṣam brahma tvam prāptam yoginam uttamam sukham samādhi sukham svayam eva upaiti prāpnoti
translated: Therefore, the highest bliss, the bliss of concentration, comes of itself to him, the yogi, who has attained the state of Brahman, who is free from impurities, and whose mind is tranquil.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: evaṃ yogābhyāsabalād ātmany eva yoginaḥ praśāmyati manaḥ /
analyzed: evam yoga abhyāsa balāt ātmani eva yoginaḥ praśāmyati manaḥ
translated: Thus, by the power of the practice of yoga, the mind of the yogis becomes tranquil in the Self alone.

original: tataś ca praśānteti /
analyzed: tatas ca praśāntā iti
translated: And therefore, he whose mind is tranquil, etc.

original: prakarṣeṇa śāntaṃ nirvṛttikatayā niruddhaṃ saṃskāramātraśeṣaṃ mano yasya taṃ praśāntamanasaṃ vṛttiśūnyatayā nirmanaskam /
analyzed: prakarṣeṇa śāntam nirvṛttikatayā niruddham saṃskāra mātra śeṣam manaḥ yasya tam praśānta manasam vṛtti śūnya tayā nirmanaskam
translated: He whose mind is completely tranquil, stopped by the absence of modifications, and has only impressions remaining, is one whose mind is tranquil. He who is free from modifications is one whose mind is tranquil.

original: nirmanaskatve hetugarbhaṃ viśeṣaṇadvayaṃ śāntarajasaṃ akalmaṣam iti /
analyzed: nirmanaska tve hetu garbham viśeṣaṇa dvayam śānta rajasam akalmaṣam iti
translated: The two qualifications, which contain the reason, are: free from passion and free from impurities.

original: śāntaṃ vikṣepakaṃ rajo yasya taṃ vikṣepaśūnyam /
analyzed: śāntam vikṣepakam rajaḥ yasya tam vikṣepa śūnyam
translated: He who is free from passion that causes distraction is free from distraction.

original: tathā na vidyate kalmaṣam layahetus tamo yasya tam akalmaṣam layaśūnyam /
analyzed: tathā na vidyate kalmaṣam laya hetuḥ tamaḥ yasya tam akalmaṣam laya śūnyam
translated: Similarly, he who is free from impurities, i.e., free from the darkness that causes dullness, is free from dullness.

original: śāntarajasam ity anenaiva tamoguṇopalakṣaṇe ' kalmaṣam saṃsārahetudharmādharmādivarjitam iti vā /
analyzed: śānta rajasam iti anena eva tamaḥ guṇa upalakṣaṇe kalmaṣam saṃsāra hetu dharma adharma ādi varjitam iti vā
translated: By the phrase free from passion, the quality of darkness is also indicated. Free from impurities means free from dharma, adharma, etc., which are the causes of worldly existence.

original: brahmabhūtaṃ brahmaiva sarvam iti niścayena samaṃ brahma prāptaṃ jīvanmuktam enaṃ yoginam /
analyzed: brahma bhūtam brahma eva sarvam iti niścayena samam brahma prāptam jīvanmuktam enam yoginam
translated: He, the yogi, who has attained Brahman, who is liberated while living, has attained Brahman along with the conviction that Brahman alone is all.

original: evam uktena prakāreṇeti śrīdharaḥ /
analyzed: evam uktena prakāreṇa iti śrīdharaḥ
translated: Sri Sridhara says, In the manner stated thus.

original: uttamaṃ niratiśayaṃ sukham upaity upagacchati /🔽manas tadvṛttyor abhāve suṣuptau svarūpasukhāvirbhāvaprasiddhiṃ
analyzed: uttamam niratiśayam sukham upaiti upagacchati  manaḥ tad vṛttyoḥ abhāve suṣuptau svarūpa sukha āvirbhāva prasiddhim
translated: He attains, reaches, the highest, unsurpassed, bliss.

original: dyotayati hiśabdaḥ /
analyzed: dyotayati hi śabdaḥ
translated: The word hi (for) indicates the well-known manifestation of the bliss of one's own nature in deep sleep when there is absence of the mind and its modifications.

original: tathā ca prāgvyākhyātaṃ sukham ātyantikaṃ yat tad ity atra ////
analyzed: tathā ca prāc vyākhyātam sukham ātyantikam yat tat iti atra
translated: And thus it is explained earlier in That is the absolute bliss.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: tataś ca pūrvavad eva tasya samādhisukhaṃ syād ity āha praśānteti /
analyzed: tatas ca pūrvavat eva tasya samādhi sukham syāt iti āha praśānta iti
translated: And therefore, just as before, his bliss of samadhi would be. Thus he says with prasantam etc.

original: sukhaṃ kartṛ yoginam upaiti prāpnoti /
analyzed: sukham kartṛ yoginam upaiti prāpnoti
translated: The bliss reaches, attains, the yogi, the agent.

original: baladevaḥ / evaṃ prayatamānasya pūrvavad eva samādhisukhaṃ syād ity āha praśānteti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ evam prayatamānasya pūrvavat eva samādhi sukham syāt iti āha praśānta iti
translated: Balarama. Thus, for one striving thus, the bliss of samadhi would be just as before. Thus he says with prasantam etc.

original: praśāntam ātmany acalaṃ mano yasya tam /
analyzed: praśāntam ātmani acalam manaḥ yasya tam
translated: He, in whom the mind is tranquil, unmoving in the Self.

original: ataevākalmaṣaṃ dagdhaprāktanasūkṣmadoṣam /
analyzed: ataeva akalmaṣam dagdha prāktana sūkṣma doṣam
translated: And therefore, it is stainless, with the previous subtle faults burnt away.

original: ataeva śāntarajasam /
analyzed: atas eva śānta rajasam
translated: And therefore, it is with the rajas calmed.

original: brahmabhūtaṃ sākṣātkṛtaviviktāvirbhāvitāṣṭaguṇakātmasvarūpaṃ yoginaṃ praty uttamam ātmānubhavarūpaṃ mahat sukhaṃ kartā svayam evopaiti
analyzed: brahma bhūtam sākṣātkṛta vivikta āvirbhāvita aṣṭaguṇaka ātma svarūpam yoginam prati uttamam ātma anubhava rūpam mahat sukham kartā svayam eva upaiti
translated: The yogi who has realized the Brahman, whose nature is the manifestation of the eight qualities that were not manifest before, attains by himself the great bliss which is the highest form of self-experience.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: yuñjann evaṃ sadātmānaṃ yogī vigatakalmaṣaḥ /
analyzed: yuñjan evam sadā ātmānam yogī vigata kalmaṣaḥ
translated: The yogi who thus always concentrates his mind, being free from sin,

original: sukhena brahmasaṃsparśam atyantaṃ sukham aśnute ////
analyzed: sukhena brahma saṃsparśam atyantam sukham aśnute
translated: experiences the touch of Brahman with ease, the highest bliss.

original: śrīdharaḥ / tataś ca kṛtārtho bhavatīty āha yuñjann iti /
translated: And then he becomes successful - this is what is said by 'yunjan' etc.

original: evam anena prakāreṇa sarvadātmānaṃ mano yuñjan vaśīkurvan /
analyzed: evam anena prakāreṇa sarvadā ātmānam manaḥ yuñjan vaśīkurvan
translated: Thus, in this way, always concentrating the mind, controlling it,

original: viśeṣeṇa sarvātmanā /
analyzed: viśeṣeṇa sarva ātmanā
translated: in particular, with the whole self,

original: vigataṃ kalmaṣaṃ yasya saḥ /
analyzed: vigatam kalmaṣam yasya saḥ
translated: he who is free from sin,

original: yogī sukhenānāyāsena brahmaṇaḥ saṃsparśo 'vidyānivartakaḥ sākṣātkāras tad evātyantaṃ sukham aśnute /
analyzed: yogī sukhena anāyāsena brahmaṇaḥ saṃsparśaḥ vidyā nivartakaḥ sākṣātkāraḥ tat eva atyantam sukham aśnute
translated: the yogi, with ease, without difficulty, experiences the touch of Brahman, the realization that removes ignorance, which is the highest bliss.

original: jīvanmukto bhavatīty arthaḥ ////
analyzed: jīvanmuktaḥ bhavati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: he becomes liberated while living.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: uktaṃ sukhaṃ yoginaḥ sphuṭīkaroti yuñjann iti /
analyzed: uktam sukham yoginaḥ sphuṭīkaroti yuñjan iti
translated: He clarifies the bliss of the yogi mentioned earlier by 'yunjan' etc.

original: evam manasaivendriyagrāmam ity ādyuktakrameṇātmānaṃ manaḥ sadā yuñjan samādadhad
analyzed: evam manasā eva indriya grāmam iti ādi ukta krameṇa ātmānam manaḥ sadā yuñjan samādadhat
translated: Thus, always concentrating the mind, fixing it, in the manner described earlier by 'manasāivendriyagrāmam' etc.,

original: yogī yogena nityasambandhī vigatakalmaṣo vigatamalaḥ saṃsārahetudharmādharmarahitaḥ
analyzed: yogī yogena nitya sambandhī vigata kalmaṣaḥ vigata malaḥ saṃsāra hetu dharma adharma rahitaḥ
translated: The yogi, who is always connected through yoga, free from sin, free from impurity, devoid of dharma and adharma, which are the causes of worldly existence,

original: sukhenānāyāseneśvarapraṇidhānāt sarvāntarāyanivṛttyā brahmasaṃsparśaṃ samyaktvena
analyzed: sukhena anāyāsena īśvara praṇidhānāt sarva antarāya nivṛttyā brahma saṃsparśam samyaktvena
translated: experiences the touch of Brahman, which is the same as Brahman, along with the non-touch of objects, through the cessation of all obstacles by the devotion to God with ease, without effort, through the contact of the self with Brahman, which is free from the touch of objects,

original: viṣayāsparśena saha brahmaṇaḥ sparśas tādātmyaṃ yasmiṃs tadviṣayāsaṃsparśi brahmasvarūpam ity etat /
analyzed: viṣaya asparśena saha brahmaṇaḥ sparśaḥ tādātmyam yasmin tad viṣaya asaṃsparśi brahma svarūpam iti etat
translated: which is the identity with Brahman, through the contact of the self with Brahman, which is free from the touch of objects, which is the identity with Brahman,

original: atyantaṃ sarvānantān paricchedān atikrāntaṃ niratiśayaṃ sukham ānandam aśnute vyāpnoti /
analyzed: atyantam sarva anantān paricchedān atikrāntam niratiśayam sukham ānandam aśnute vyāpnoti
translated: he experiences, pervades, the highest, unlimited, incomparable bliss, which transcends all limitations, which is infinite.

original: sarvatonirvṛttikena cittena layavikṣepavilakṣaṇam anubhavati /
analyzed: sarvatonirvṛttikena cittena laya vikṣepa vilakṣaṇam anubhavati
translated: He experiences it with a mind that is completely inactive, unlike in states of absorption or distraction.

original: vikṣepe vṛttisattvāt /
analyzed: vikṣepe vṛtti sattvāt
translated: Because in distraction, there is the presence of fluctuations.

original: laye ca manaso 'pi svarūpeṇāsattvāt /
analyzed: laye ca manasaḥ api sva rūpeṇa asattvāt
translated: And in absorption, the mind does not exist in its own form.

original: sarvavṛttiśūnyena sūkṣmeṇa manasā sukhānubhavaḥ samādhāv evety arthaḥ /
analyzed: sarva vṛtti śūnyena sūkṣmeṇa manasā sukha anubhavaḥ samādhau eva iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that the experience of bliss is only in samadhi, with a subtle mind devoid of all fluctuations.

original: atra cānāyāsenety antarāyanivṛttir uktā /
analyzed: atra ca anāyāsena iti antarāya nivṛttiḥ uktā
translated: And here, the cessation of obstacles is stated by without effort.

original: te cāntarāyā darśitā yogasūtreṇa vyādhistyānasaṃśayapramādālasyāviratibhrāntidarśanālabdhabhūmikatvānavasthitatvāni cittavikṣepās
analyzed: te ca antarāyāḥ darśitāḥ yogasūtreṇa
translated: And those obstacles are shown by the Yoga Sutra as disease, languor, doubt, negligence, laziness, non-detachment, false vision, non-attainment of the stage, and instability, which are distractions of the mind.

original: te 'ntarāyāḥ YogaS / /
analyzed: te ntarāyāḥ yogas
translated: Those are the obstacles to yoga.

original: cittaṃ vikṣipanti yogād apanayantīti cittavikṣepā yogapratipakṣāḥ /
analyzed: cittam vikṣipanti yogāt apanayanti iti citta vikṣepāḥ yoga pratipakṣāḥ
translated: They distract the mind from yoga and take it away, so they are distractions of the mind and opponents to yoga.

original: saṃśayabhrāntidarśane tāvad vṛttirūpatayā vṛttinirodhasya sākṣātpratipakṣau /
analyzed: saṃśaya bhrānti darśane tāvat vṛtti rūpa tayā vṛtti nirodhasya sākṣāt pratipakṣau
translated: Doubt and false vision are indeed the direct opponents of the cessation of fluctuations, because they are in the form of fluctuations.

original: vyādhyādayas tu sapta vṛttisahacaritatayā tatpratipakṣā ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: vyādhi ādayaḥ tu sapta vṛtti sahacarita tayā tad pratipakṣāḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: But the other seven, disease and so on, are opponents of that [cessation of fluctuations] because they accompany fluctuations.

original: vyādhir dhātuvaiṣamyanimitto vikāro jvarādiḥ /
analyzed: vyādhiḥ dhātu vaiṣamya nimittaḥ vikāraḥ jvara ādiḥ
translated: Disease is a change caused by an imbalance of the elements, such as fever.

original: styānam akarmaṇyatā guruṇā śikṣyamāṇasyāpy āsanādikarmānarhateti yāvat /
analyzed: styānam akarmaṇya tā guruṇā śikṣyamāṇasya api āsana ādi karma anarha tā iti yāvat
translated: Languor is unserviceability, meaning one is not fit to perform actions such as sitting, even when instructed by a teacher.

original: yogaḥ sādhanīyo na vety ubhayakoṭispṛgvijñānaṃ saṃśayaḥ /
analyzed: yogaḥ sādhanīyaḥ na vā iti ubhaya koṭi spṛś vijñānam saṃśayaḥ
translated: Doubt is the cognition that touches both ends, wondering whether yoga should be practiced or not.

original: sa cātadrūpapratiṣṭhatvena viparyayāntargato 'pi sann ubhayakoṭisparśitvaikakoṭisparśitvarūpāvāntaraviśeṣavivakṣayātra viparyayād
analyzed: sa ca a tad rūpa pratiṣṭha tvena viparyaya antargataḥ san ubhaya koṭi sparśi tva eka koṭi sparśi tva rūpa avāntara viśeṣa vivakṣayā atra viparyayāt
translated: And although it is included in error because it is established in a form that is not that [object], it is mentioned separately from error here with the intention of expressing the internal distinctions of touching both ends and touching one end.

original: pramādaḥ samādhisādhanānām anuṣṭhānasāmarthye 'py ananuṣṭhānaśīlatā viṣayāntara vyāpratatayā yogasādhaneṣv audāsīnyam iti yāvat /
analyzed: pramādaḥ samādhi sādhanānām anuṣṭhāna sāmarthye an anuṣṭhāna śīla tā yoga sādhaneṣu audāsīnyam iti yāvat
translated: Negligence is the habit of not practicing even when one is capable of practicing the means of concentration, that is, indifference to the means of yoga due to being engaged in other objects.

original: ālasyaṃ satyām apy audāsīnyapracyutau kaphādinā tamasā ca kāyacittayor gurutvam /
analyzed: ālasyam satyām api audāsīnya pracyutau kapha ādinā tamasā ca kāya cittayoḥ guru tvam
translated: Laziness is the heaviness of body and mind due to phlegm etc. and tamas, even when there is no falling away from indifference.

original: tac ca vyādhitvenāprasiddham api yogaviṣaye pravṛttivirodhi /
analyzed: tat ca vyādhi tvena aprasiddham api yoga viṣaye pravṛtti virodhi
translated: And that, although not known as a disease, is an obstruction to engagement in the domain of yoga.

original: aviratiś cittasya viṣayaviśeṣa aikāntiko 'bhilāṣaḥ /
analyzed: aviratiḥ cittasya viṣaya viśeṣaḥ aikāntikaḥ bhilāṣaḥ
translated: Non-cessation is the one-sided desire of the mind for a particular object.

original: bhrāntidarśanaṃ yogāsādhane 'pi tatsādhanatvabuddhis tathā tatsādhane 'piy asādhanatvabuddhiḥ /
analyzed: bhrānti darśanam yoga asādhane tad sādhana tva buddhiḥ tathā asādhana tva buddhiḥ
translated: Erroneous perception is the cognition of what is not a means of yoga as a means of yoga, and likewise the cognition of what is a means of yoga as not a means of yoga.

original: alabdhabhūmikatvaṃ samādhibhūmer ekāgratāyā alābhaḥ /
analyzed: alabdha bhūmika tvam samādhi bhūmeḥ ekāgra tāyāḥ alābhaḥ
