translated: And those impressions of friendliness, etc., have been formulated by the Blessed Lord Patañjali earlier, and though briefly explained, are being explained again.

original: cittaṃ hi rāgadveṣapuṇyapāpaiḥ kaluṣīkriyate /
analyzed: cittam hi rāga dveṣa puṇya pāpaiḥ kaluṣīkriyate
translated: For the mind is defiled by passion, hatred, merit, and demerit.

original: tatra sukhānuśayī rāgaḥ YogaS / /
analyzed: tatra sukha anuśayī rāgaḥ yogaḥ
translated: Among them, passion is the attachment to pleasure.

original: mohād anubhūyamānaṃ sukham anuśete kaścid dhīvṛttiviśeṣo rājasaḥ sarvaṃ sukhajātīyaṃ me bhūyād iti /
analyzed: mohāt anubhūyamānam sukham anuśete kaścid dhī vṛtti viśeṣaḥ rājasaḥ sarvam sukha jātīyam me bhūyāt iti
translated: A certain mental modification, which is of the nature of passion, lies latent in the pleasure experienced through delusion, thinking 'May everything of the nature of pleasure be mine.'

original: tac ca dṛṣṭādṛṣṭasāmagryabhāvāt sampādayitum aśakyam /
analyzed: tat ca dṛṣṭa adṛṣṭa sāmagrī abhāvāt sampādayitum aśakyam
translated: And that cannot be accomplished because the necessary conditions, seen and unseen, are absent.

original: ataḥ sa rāgaś cittaṃ kaluṣīkaroti /
analyzed: atas sa rāgaḥ cittam kaluṣīkaroti
translated: Therefore that attachment defiles the mind.

original: yadā tu sukhiu prāṇiṣv ayaṃ maitrīṃ bhāvayet sarve 'py ete sukhino madīyā iti tadā tat sukhaṃ svakīyam eva sampannam iti bhāvayatas tatra rāgo
analyzed: yadā tu prāṇiṣu ayam maitrīm bhāvayet sarve pi ete sukhinaḥ madīyāḥ iti tadā tat sukham svakīyam eva sampannam iti bhāvayataḥ tatra rāgaḥ
translated: But when one cultivates friendliness towards happy beings, thinking All these are mine, happy, then, contemplating that their happiness is indeed one's own, attachment to them

original: nivartate /
analyzed: nivartate
translated: ceases.

original: yathā svasya rājyanivṛttāv api putrādirājyam eva svakīyaṃ rājyaṃ tadvat /
analyzed: yathā svasya rājya nivṛttau api putra ādi rājyam eva svakīyam rājyam tadvat
translated: Just as one's own kingdom, even when relinquished, is one's own kingdom through one's son and other rulers.

original: nivṛtte ca rāge varṣāvyapāye jalam iva cittaṃ prasīdati /🔽tathā duḥkhānuśayī dveṣaḥ YogaS / duḥkham anuśete kaścd dhīvṛttiviśeṣas tamo 'nugatarajaḥpariṇāma īdṛśaṃ sarvaṃ duḥkhaṃ sarvadā me
analyzed: nivṛtte ca rāge varṣā vyapāye jalam iva cittam prasīdati  tathā duḥkha anuśayī dveṣaḥ yogaḥ duḥkham anuśete kaścd dhī vṛtti viśeṣaḥ tamaḥ nugata rajaḥ pariṇāmaḥ īdṛśam sarvam duḥkham sarvadā me
translated: And when attachment ceases, like water at the end of the rainy season, the mind becomes clear.

original: mā bhūd iti / tac ca
analyzed: mā bhūt iti tat ca
translated: Similarly, aversion that persists in suffering is yoga. A particular mental function that persists in suffering, a transformation of tamas and rajas, thinks May all this suffering never be mine at any time. And that

original: śatruvyāghrādiṣu satsya na nivārayituṃ śakyam /
analyzed: śatru vyāghra ādiṣu satsya na nivārayitum śakyam
translated: cannot be prevented from arising towards enemies, tigers, etc.

original: na ca sarve te duḥkhahetavo hantuṃ śakyante /
analyzed: na ca sarve te duḥkha hetavaḥ hantum śakyante
translated: And all of them cannot be killed, being the causes of suffering.

original: ataḥ sa dveṣaḥ sadā hṛdayaṃ dahati /
analyzed: atas sa dveṣaḥ sadā hṛdayam dahati
translated: Therefore that aversion always burns the heart.

original: yadā tu svasyeva pareṣāṃ sarveṣām api duḥkham mā bhūd iti karuṇāṃ duḥkhiṣu bhāvayet tadā vairyādidveṣanivṛttau cittaṃ prasīdati /
analyzed: yadā tu svasya iva pareṣām sarveṣām api duḥkham mā bhūt iti karuṇām duḥkhiṣu bhāvayet tadā vairya ādi dveṣa nivṛttau cittam prasīdati
translated: But when one cultivates compassion towards the suffering of others, just as towards one's own, then, when hatred and enmity cease, the mind becomes serene.

original: tathā ca smaryate
analyzed: tathā ca smaryate
translated: And it is remembered thus:

original: prāṇā yathātmano 'bhīṣṭā bhūtānām api te tathā /
analyzed: prāṇāḥ yathā ātmanaḥ bhīṣṭāḥ bhūtānām api te tathā
translated: As life is desired by oneself, so it is by all beings.

original: ātmaupamyena bhūteṣu dayāṃ kurvanti sādhavaḥ // iti /
analyzed: ātma aupamyena bhūteṣu dayām kurvanti sādhavaḥ iti
translated: The virtuous cultivate compassion towards beings by considering them as equal to oneself.

original: etad evehāpy uktam ātmaupamyena sarvatrety ādi /
analyzed: etat eva iha api uktam ātma aupamyena sarvatra iti ādi
translated: This is stated here also: By considering all as equal to oneself... and so on.

original: tathā prāṇinaḥ svabhāvata eva puṇyaṃ nānutiṣṭhanti pāpaṃ tv anutiṣṭhanti / tad āhuḥ
analyzed: tathā prāṇinaḥ svabhāvataḥ eva puṇyam na anutiṣṭhanti pāpam tu anutiṣṭhanti tat āhuḥ
translated: Similarly, living beings naturally do not perform meritorious deeds, but they do perform sinful deeds. It is said:

original: puṇyasya phalam icchanti puṇyaṃ necchanti mānavāḥ /
analyzed: puṇyasya phalam icchanti puṇyam na icchanti mānavāḥ
translated: Men desire the fruit of merit, but they do not desire merit.

original: na pāpaphalam icchanti pāpaṃ kurvanti yatnataḥ // iti /
analyzed: na pāpa phalam icchanti pāpam kurvanti yatnataḥ iti
translated: They do not desire the fruit of sin, but they diligently commit sin.

original: te ca puṇyapāpe akriyamāṇakriyamāṇe paścāttāpaṃ janayataḥ /
analyzed: te ca puṇya pāpe a kriyamāṇa kriyamāṇe paścāttāpam janayataḥ
translated: And those meritorious and sinful deeds, whether done or not done, give rise to remorse.

original: sa ca śrutyānūditaḥ kim ahaṃ sādhu nākaravaṃ kim ahaṃ pāpam akaravam iti /
analyzed: sa ca śrutyā anūditaḥ kim aham sādhu na akaravam kim aham pāpam akaravam iti
translated: And that is stated in the scriptures: What good have I not done? What evil have I done?

original: yady asau puṇyapuruṣeṣu muditāṃ bhāvayet tadā tadvāsanāvān svayam evāpramatto 'śuklakṛṣṇe puṇye pravartate /
analyzed: yadi asau puṇya puruṣeṣu muditām bhāvayet tadā tad vāsanāvān svayam eva apramattaḥ śukla kṛṣṇe puṇye pravartate
translated: If he cultivates joy towards meritorious persons, then he himself, possessing that disposition, becomes diligent in performing meritorious actions that are neither white nor black.

original: tad uktaṃ karmāśuklakṛṣṇaṃ yoginas trividham itareṣām ayogināṃ trividhaṃ śuklaṃ śubhaṃ kṛṣṇam aśubhaṃ śuklakṛṣṇaṃ śubhāśubham iti /
analyzed: tat uktam karma a śukla kṛṣṇam yoginaḥ trividham itareṣām ayoginām trividham śuklam śubham kṛṣṇam aśubham śukla kṛṣṇam śubha aśubham iti
translated: It is said that for yogis, action is of three kinds: neither white nor black, for others who are not yogis, it is of three kinds: white, which is good, black, which is bad, and white and black, which is both good and bad.

original: tathā pāpapuruṣeṣūpekṣāṃ bhāvayan svayam api tadvāsanāvān pāpān nivartate /
analyzed: tathā pāpa puruṣeṣu upekṣām bhāvayan svayam api tad vāsanāvān pāpāt nivartate
translated: Similarly, cultivating equanimity towards sinful persons, he himself, possessing that disposition, turns away from sin.

original: tataś ca puṇyākaraṇapāpakaraṇanimittasya paścāttāpasyābhāve cittaṃ prasīdati /
analyzed: tatas ca puṇya akaraṇa pāpa karaṇa nimittasya paścāttāpasya abhāve cittam prasīdati
translated: And then, in the absence of regret for not performing meritorious actions and for performing sinful actions, the mind becomes serene.

original: evaṃ sukhiṣu maitrīṃ bhāvayato na kevalaṃ rāgo nivartate kiṃtv asūyerṣyādayo 'pi nivartante /
analyzed: evam sukhiṣu maitrīm bhāvayataḥ na kevalam rāgaḥ nivartate kiṃtu asūyā īrṣyā ādayaḥ api nivartante
translated: Thus, when cultivating friendliness towards the happy, not only does passion cease, but also malice, envy, and so on cease.

original: paraguṇeṣu doṣāviṣkaraṇam asūyā /
analyzed: para guṇeṣu doṣa āviṣkaraṇam asūyā
translated: Malice is the disclosure of faults in the good qualities of others.

original: paraguṇānām asahanam īrṣyā /
analyzed: para guṇānām a sahanam īrṣyā
translated: Envy is the inability to bear the good qualities of others.

original: yadā maitrīvaśāt parasukhaṃ svīyam eva sampannaṃ tadā paraguṇeṣu katham asūyādikaṃ sambhavet /
analyzed: yadā maitrī vaśāt para sukham svīyam eva sampannam tadā para guṇeṣu katham asūyā ādikam sambhavet
translated: When, due to friendliness, the happiness of others becomes one's own, how can malice and so on arise towards the good qualities of others?

original: tathā duḥkhiṣu karuṇāṃ bhāvayataḥ śatruvadhādikaro dveṣo yadā nivartate tadā duḥkhitvapratiyogikasvasukhitvaprayuktadarpo 'pi nivartate
analyzed: tathā duḥkhiṣu karuṇām bhāvayataḥ śatru vadha ādi karaḥ dveṣaḥ yadā nivartate tadā duḥkhi tva pratiyogika sva sukhi tva prayukta darpaḥ pi nivartate
translated: Similarly, when hatred, which causes the killing of enemies etc., ceases for one who cultivates compassion towards the suffering, then the pride based on one's own happiness opposed to the suffering of others also ceases.

original: evaṃ doṣāntaranivṛttir apy ūhanīyā vāsiṣṭharāmāyaṇādiṣu /
analyzed: evam doṣa antara nivṛttiḥ api ūhanīyā vāsiṣṭha rāmāyaṇa ādiṣu
translated: In the same way, the cessation of other faults should be inferred from the Vasistha Ramayana and other texts.

original: tad evaṃ tattvajñānaṃ manonāśo vāsanākṣayaś ceti trayam abhyasanīyam /
analyzed: tat evam tattva jñānam manaḥ nāśaḥ vāsanā kṣayaḥ ca iti trayam abhyasanīyam
translated: Thus, the three - knowledge of reality, destruction of the mind, and destruction of latent impressions - should be practiced.

original: tatra kenāpi dvāreṇa punaḥ punas tattvānusmaraṇaṃ tattvajñānābhyāsaḥ / tad uktam
analyzed: tatra kena api dvāreṇa punar punar tattva anusmaraṇam tattva jñāna abhyāsaḥ tat uktam
translated: Among them, the practice of the knowledge of reality is the repeated recollection of reality through any means. It is said:

original: taccintanaṃ tatkathanam anyonyaṃ tatprabodhanam /
analyzed: tad cintanam tad kathanam anyonyam tad prabodhanam
translated: Thinking of it, speaking of it, mutually enlightening each other about it,

original: etad ekaparatvaṃ ca brahmābhyāsaṃ vidur budhāḥ //
analyzed: etat eka para tvam ca brahma abhyāsam viduḥ budhāḥ
translated: and being solely devoted to it - the wise know this to be the practice of Brahman.

original: sargādāv eva notpannaṃ dṛśyaṃ nāsty eva tat sadā /
analyzed: sarga ādau eva na utpannam dṛśyam na asti eva tat sadā
translated: The manifest, which did not arise even at the beginning of creation, never exists.

original: idaṃ jagad ahaṃ ceti bodhābhyāsaṃ viduḥ param // iti /
analyzed: idam jagat aham ca iti bodha abhyāsam viduḥ param iti
translated: The supreme practice of knowledge is to think this world and I in this way.

original: dṛśyāvabhāsavirodhiyogābhyāso manonirodhābhyāsaḥ / tad uktam
translated: The practice of yoga, which is opposed to the appearance of the manifest, is the practice of the cessation of the mind. It is said:

original: atyantābhāvasampattau jñātur jñeyasya vastunaḥ /
analyzed: atyanta abhāva sampattau jñātuḥ jñeyasya vastunaḥ
translated: When the knower and the object of knowledge become absolutely non-existent,

original: yuktyā śāstrair yatante ye te 'py atrābhyāsinaḥ sthitāḥ // iti /
analyzed: yuktyā śāstraiḥ yatante ye te pi atra abhyāsinaḥ sthitāḥ iti
translated: Those who strive by reasoning and scriptures are also established as practitioners here.

original: jñātṛjñeyor mithyātvadhīrabhāvasampattiḥ /
translated: The understanding of the falsity of the knower and the known is the attainment of non-existence.

original: svarūpeṇāpy apratītir atyantābhāvasampattis tadartham /
translated: The non-apprehension even by one's own nature is the attainment of absolute non-existence, for that purpose.

original: yuktyā yogena /
analyzed: yuktyā yogena
translated: By reasoning, by yoga.

original: dṛśyāsambhavabodhena rāgadveṣāditānave /
analyzed: dṛśya asambhava bodhena rāga dveṣa ādi tānave
translated: By the understanding of the impossibility of the visible, by the absence of attachment, aversion, etc.,

original: ratir ghanoditā yāsau brahmābhyāsaḥ sa ucyate //
analyzed: ratiḥ ghana uditā yā asau brahma abhyāsaḥ saḥ ucyate
translated: That delight which is greatly arisen is said to be the practice of Brahman.

original: iti rāgadveṣādikṣīṇatārūpavāsanākṣayābhyāsa uktaḥ /
analyzed: iti rāga dveṣa ādi kṣīṇa tā rūpa vāsanā kṣaya abhyāsaḥ uktaḥ
translated: Thus, the practice of the destruction of the impressions in the form of the exhaustion of attachment, aversion, etc. is stated.

original: tasmād upapannam etat tattvajñānābhyāsena manonāśābhyāsena vāsanākṣayābhyāsena
analyzed: tasmāt upapannam etat tattva jñāna abhyāsena manaḥ nāśa abhyāsena vāsanā kṣaya abhyāsena
translated: Therefore, this is reasonable: by the practice of the knowledge of reality, by the practice of the destruction of the mind, by the practice of the destruction of impressions,

original: ca rāgadveṣaśūnyatayā yaḥ svaparasukhaduḥkhādiṣu samadṛṣṭiḥ sa paramo yogī
analyzed: ca rāga dveṣa śūnya tayā yaḥ sva para sukha duḥkha ādiṣu sama dṛṣṭiḥ sa paramaḥ yogī
translated: and by the absence of attachment and aversion, one who has an equal vision towards one's own and others' happiness, sorrow, etc. is the supreme yogi.

original: mato yas tu viṣamadṛṣṭiḥ sa tattvajñānavān apy aparamo yogīti // //
analyzed: mataḥ yaḥ tu viṣama dṛṣṭiḥ sa tattva jñānavān api aparamaḥ yogī iti
translated: But one who has an unequal vision, even though possessing the knowledge of reality, is not the supreme yogi.

original: viśvanāthaḥ / kiṃ ca /
analyzed: viśvanāthaḥ kim ca
translated: Visvanatha. Moreover,

original: sādhanadaśāyāṃ yogī sarvatra samaḥ syād ity uktam /
analyzed: sādhana daśāyām yogī sarvatra samaḥ syāt iti uktam
translated: it has been said that a yogi should be equal everywhere during the stage of practice.

original: tatra mukhyaṃ sāmyaṃ vyacaṣṭe ātmaupamyeneti /
analyzed: tatra mukhyam sāmyam vyacaṣṭe ātma aupamyena iti
translated: There, he describes the principal equality by saying by considering oneself as equal to others.

original: sukhaṃ vā duḥkhaṃ veti yathā mama sukhaṃ priyaṃ duḥkham apriyaṃ /
analyzed: sukham vā duḥkham vā iti yathā mama sukham priyam duḥkham apriyam
translated: Whether it is happiness or suffering, just as my happiness is dear and suffering is not dear,

original: tathaivānyeṣām apīti sarvatra samaṃ paśyan sukham eva sarveṣāṃ yo vāñchati /
analyzed: tathā eva anyeṣām api iti sarvatra samam paśyan sukham eva sarveṣām yaḥ vāñchati
translated: so it is for others as well. Seeing equality everywhere, he desires only happiness for all.

original: na tu kasyāpi duḥkham /
analyzed: na tu kasya api duḥkham
translated: But not suffering for anyone.

original: sa yogī śreṣṭho mamābhimataḥ ////
analyzed: sa yogī śreṣṭhaḥ mama abhimataḥ
translated: That yogi is the best, he is dear to me.

original: baladevaḥ / sarvabhūtahite rataḥ iti yat prāg uktaṃ /
analyzed: baladevaḥ sarva bhūta hite rataḥ iti yat prāk uktam
translated: Balarama. What was said earlier, delighting in the welfare of all beings,

original: tad viśadayati ātmaupamyeneti /
analyzed: tat viśadayati ātma aupamyena iti
translated: he clarifies with by considering others as oneself.

original: vyutthānadaśāyām ātmaupamyena svasādṛśyena sukhaṃ duḥkhaṃ ca yaḥ sarvatra samaṃ paśyati /
analyzed: vyutthāna daśāyām ātma aupamyena sva sādṛśyena sukham duḥkham ca yaḥ sarvatra samam paśyati
translated: In the state of emergence, he who sees happiness and suffering everywhere equally by considering others as similar to himself,

original: svasyeva parasya sukham evecchati /
analyzed: svasya iva parasya sukham eva icchati
translated: he desires only the happiness of others, just as of himself.

original: na tu duḥkham /
analyzed: na tu duḥkham
translated: But not their suffering.

original: sa svaparasukhaduḥkhasamadṛṣṭiḥ sarvānukampī yogī mama paramaḥ śreṣṭho 'bhimataḥ /🔽tadviṣamadṛṣṭis tu tattvajño 'py aparamayogīti bhāvaḥ ////
analyzed: sa sva para sukha duḥkha sama dṛṣṭiḥ sarva anukampī yogī mama paramaḥ śreṣṭhaḥ bhimataḥ  tad viṣama dṛṣṭiḥ tu aparama yogī iti bhāvaḥ
translated: That yogi who sees the equality of his own and others' happiness and suffering, who has compassion for all, is the highest, the best, he is dear to me.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: But one who has an unequal view, even though he knows the truth, is not the highest yogi. This is the meaning.

original: arjuna uvāca
analyzed: arjunaḥ uvāca
translated: Arjuna said:

original: yo 'yaṃ yogas tvayā proktaḥ sāmyena madhusūdana /
analyzed: yaḥ yam yogaḥ tvayā proktaḥ sāmyena madhusūdana
translated: This yoga that has been taught by you, O slayer of Madhu,

original: etasyāhaṃ na paśyāmi cañcalatvāt sthitiṃ sthirām ////
analyzed: etasya aham na paśyāmi cañcala tvāt sthitim sthirām
translated: I do not see its stability, due to the restlessness of the mind.

original: śrīdharaḥ / uktalakṣaṇasya yogasyāsambhavaṃ manvāno 'rjuna uvāca yo 'yam iti /
analyzed: uvāca     iti
translated: Śrīdhara: Arjuna, thinking that the yoga described is impossible, said This yoga...

original: sāmyena manaso layavikṣepaśūnyatayā kevalātmākārāvasthānena /
analyzed: sāmyena manasaḥ laya vikṣepa śūnya tayā kevala ātma ākāra avasthānena
translated: By sameness, by the mind remaining in the form of the Self alone, devoid of absorption and distraction.

original: yo 'yaṃ yogas tvayā proktaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ yam yogaḥ tvayā proktaḥ
translated: This yoga that has been taught by you.

original: etasya sthirāṃ dīrghakālāṃ sthitiṃ na paśyāmi /
analyzed: etasya sthirām dīrgha kālām sthitim na paśyāmi
translated: I do not see its stable, long-lasting continuance.

original: manasaś cañcalatvāt ////
analyzed: manasaḥ cañcala tvāt
translated: Because the mind is fickle.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusūdana:

original: uktam artham ākṣipan arjuna uvāca yo 'yam iti /
analyzed: uktam artham ākṣipan arjunaḥ uvāca yaḥ yam iti
translated: Arjuna, objecting to the stated meaning, said This yoga...

original: yo 'yaṃ sarvatra samaṣṭilakṣaṇaḥ paramo yogaḥ sāmyena samatvena cittagatānāṃ rāgadveṣādīnāṃ viṣamadṛṣṭihetūnāṃ nirākaraṇena tvayā sarvajñeneśvareṇoktaḥ
analyzed: yaḥ yam sarvatra samaṣṭi lakṣaṇaḥ paramaḥ yogaḥ sāmyena samatvena citta gatānām rāga dveṣa ādīnām viṣama dṛṣṭi hetūnām nirākaraṇena tvayā sarvajñena īśvareṇa uktaḥ
translated: This supreme yoga, characterized by sameness everywhere, which has been taught by you, O omniscient Lord, by the removal of attachment, aversion, etc., the causes of uneven vision, that exist in the mind,

original: he madhusūdana /
analyzed: he madhusūdana
translated: O Madhusūdana.

original: sarvavaidikasampradāyapravartaka /🔽etasya tvaduktasya sarvamanovṛttinirodhalakṣaṇasya yogasya sthitiṃ vidyamānatāṃ
analyzed: etasya tvad uktasya sarva manaḥ vṛtti nirodha lakṣaṇasya yogasya sthitim vidyamāna tām
translated: O propagator of the entire Vedic tradition.🔽I do not see the existence, the presence,🔽of the stable, long-lasting continuance of this yoga, characterized by the cessation of all mental activities, which has been taught by you.

original: sthirāṃ dīrghakālānuvartinīṃ na paśyāmi na sambhāvayāmi aham asmadvidho 'nyo vā
analyzed: sthirām dīrgha kāla anuvartinīm na paśyāmi na sambhāvayāmi aham asmadvidhaḥ nyaḥ vā
translated: I, or anyone like me,

original: yogābhyāsanipuṇaḥ /
translated: who is skilled in the practice of yoga.

original: kasmān na sambhāvayasi tatrāha cañcalatvāt /
analyzed: kasmāt na sambhāvayasi tatra āha cañcala tvāt
translated: Why do you not consider it possible? He says: because of the fickleness.

original: manasa iti śeṣaḥ ////
analyzed: manasaḥ iti śeṣaḥ
translated: Of the mind, the rest.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: bhagavaduktalakṣaṇasya sāmyasya duṣkaratvam ālakṣyovāca yo 'yam iti /
analyzed: bhagavat ukta lakṣaṇasya sāmyasya duṣkara tvam ālakṣya uvāca yaḥ yam iti
translated: Seeing the difficulty of equality, which is described by the Lord, he says: This.

original: etasya sāmyena prāptasya yogasya sthirāṃ sārvadikīṃ sthitiṃ na paśyāmi /
analyzed: etasya sāmyena prāptasya yogasya sthirām sārvadikīm sthitim na paśyāmi
translated: I do not see a stable, always present state of yoga, which is attained by this equality.

original: eṣa yogaḥ sarvadā na tiṣṭhati kintu tricaturadināny evety arthaḥ /
analyzed: eṣa yogaḥ sarvadā na tiṣṭhati kintu tri catura dināni eva iti arthaḥ
translated: This yoga does not always remain, but only for three or four days, is the meaning.

original: kutaḥ / cañcalatvāt /
analyzed: kutas cañcala tvāt
translated: Why? Because of fickleness.

original: tathā hy ātmaduḥkhasukhasamam eva sarvajagadvartijanānāṃ sukhaduḥkhaṃ paśyed iti sāmyam uktam /
analyzed: tathā hi ātma duḥkha sukha samam eva sarva jagat varti janānām sukha duḥkham paśyet iti sāmyam uktam
translated: For thus, it is said that one should see the happiness and sorrow of all people in the world as equal to one's own happiness and sorrow.

original: tatra ye bandhavas taṭasthāś ca teṣu sāmyaṃ bhaved api /
analyzed: tatra ye bandhavaḥ taṭa sthāḥ ca teṣu sāmyam bhavet api
translated: In that case, equality may be possible with regard to relatives and neutral people.

original: ye ripavo ghātakā dveṣṭāro nindakāś ca teṣu na sambhaved eva /
analyzed: ye ripavaḥ ghātakāḥ dveṣṭāraḥ nindakāḥ ca teṣu na sambhavet eva
translated: But it cannot be possible with regard to enemies, murderers, haters, and revilers.

original: na hi mayā svasya yudhiṣṭhirasya duryodhanasya ca sukhaduḥkhe sarvathā tulye draṣṭuṃ śakyete /
analyzed: na hi mayā svasya yudhiṣṭhirasya duryodhanasya ca sukha duḥkhe sarvathā tulye draṣṭum śakyete
translated: For I cannot see the happiness and sorrow of my own Yudhishthira and Duryodhana as equal in every way.

original: yadi ca svasya svaripūṇāṃ ca jīvātmaparamātmaprāṇendriyadaihikabhūtāni samāny eveti vivekena prabalasyāticañcalasya manaso nigrahaṇāśakyatvāt
analyzed: yadi ca svasya sva ripūṇām ca jīvātma paramātma prāṇa indriya daihika bhūtāni samāni eva iti vivekena prabalasya ati cañcalasya manasaḥ nigrahaṇa aśakya tvāt
translated: And if the individual souls, the supreme soul, the life-breaths, the senses, the bodily elements, and the gross elements are all the same for one's own self and for one's enemies, then, due to the impossibility of controlling the very powerful and extremely fickle mind through discrimination,

original: pratyuta viṣayāsaktena tena manasaiva vivekasya grasyamānatvadarśanād
analyzed: pratyuta viṣaya āsaktena tena manasā eva vivekasya grasyamāna tva darśanāt
translated: and moreover, seeing that discrimination itself is swallowed up by that very mind attached to objects,

original: iti ////🔽baladevaḥ / uktam ākṣipann arjuna uvāca yo 'yam iti /
analyzed: iti  baladevaḥ uktam ākṣipan arjunaḥ uvāca yaḥ yam iti
translated: thus...

original: sāmyena svaparasukhaduḥkhataulyena yo 'yaṃ yogas tvayā sarvajñena proktas tasya sthirāṃ sārvadikīṃ sthitiṃ niṣṭhām apy ahaṃ na paśyāmi /
analyzed: sāmyena sva para sukha duḥkha taulyena yaḥ yam yogaḥ tvayā sarvajñena proktaḥ tasya sthirām sārvadikīm sthitim niṣṭhām api aham na paśyāmi
translated: [Arjuna] said: This yoga that you, the omniscient one, have taught, which is the equality of one's own and others' happiness and sorrow, I do not see its stable, constant state, its perfection.

original: kintu dvitrāṇy eva dinānīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: kintu dvitrāṇi eva dināni iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: but only two or three days.

original: kutaḥ / cañcalatvāt /
analyzed: kutas cañcala tvāt
translated: Why? Because of fickleness.

original: ayam arthaḥ bandhuṣu udāsīneṣu ca tat sāmyaṃ kadācit syāt /
analyzed: ayam arthaḥ bandhuṣu udāsīneṣu ca tat sāmyam kadācid syāt
translated: This is the meaning: That equality may sometimes be with relatives and neutral persons.

original: na ca śatruṣu nindakeṣu ca kadācid api /
analyzed: na ca śatruṣu nindakeṣu ca kadācid api
translated: And it is never with enemies and those who speak ill.

original: yadi paramātmādhiṣṭhānatvaṃ sarvatrāviśeṣam iti vivekena tad grāhyaṃ /
analyzed: yadi paramātma adhiṣṭhāna tvam sarvatra aviśeṣam iti vivekena tat grāhyam
translated: If the fact that it is based on the supreme Self is to be grasped through discrimination without distinction everywhere,

original: tarhi na tat sārvadikaṃ aticapalasya baliṣṭhasya ca manasas tena vivekena nigrahītum aśakyatvād iti ////
analyzed: tarhi na tat sārvadikam ati capalasya baliṣṭhasya ca manasaḥ tena vivekena nigrahītum aśakya tvāt iti
translated: Then, it is not universal, because the very fickle and powerful mind cannot be controlled by that discrimination.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: Bhagavad Gita

original: cañcalaṃ hi manaḥ kṛṣṇa pramāthi balavad dṛḍham /
analyzed: cañcalam hi manaḥ kṛṣṇa pramāthi balavat dṛḍham
translated: O Krishna, the mind is fickle, violent, powerful and firm.

original: tasyāhaṃ nigrahaṃ manye vāyor iva suduṣkaram ////
analyzed: tasya aham nigraham manye vāyoḥ iva su duṣkaram
translated: I think its control is as difficult as that of the wind.

original: śrīdharaḥ / etaṃ sphuṭayati cañcalam iti /
translated: Sridhar: He clarifies this with fickle etc.

original: cañcalaṃ svabhāvenaiva capalam /
analyzed: cañcalam svabhāvena eva capalam
translated: It is fickle, naturally restless.

original: kiṃ ca pramāthi pramathanaśīlam /
analyzed: kim ca pramāthi pramathana śīlam
translated: Moreover, it is violent, prone to destruction.

original: dehendriyakṣobhakaram ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: deha indriya kṣobha karam iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it causes disturbance to the body and senses.

original: kiṃ ca balavad vicāreṇāpi jetum aśakyam /
analyzed: kim ca balavat vicāreṇa api jetum aśakyam
translated: Moreover, it is powerful, incapable of being conquered even by reasoning.

original: kiṃ ca dṛḍhaṃ viṣayavāsanānubaddhatayā durbhedam /
analyzed: kim ca dṛḍham viṣaya vāsanā anubaddha tayā durbhedam
translated: Moreover, it is firm, difficult to penetrate due to being attached to the impressions of objects.

original: ato yathākāśe dodhūyamānasya vāyoḥ kumbhādiṣu nirodhanam aśakyaṃ tathāhaṃ tasya manaso nigrahaṃ nirodhaṃ suduṣkaraṃ sarvathā kartum aśakyaṃ
analyzed: atas yathā ākāśe dodhūyamānasya vāyoḥ kumbha ādiṣu nirodhanam aśakyam tathā aham tasya manasaḥ nigraham nirodham su duṣkaram sarvathā kartum aśakyam
translated: Therefore, just as it is impossible to restrain the wind blowing in the sky in pots etc., so I think the control, the restraint, of that mind is very difficult, impossible in any way.

original: manye ////
analyzed: manye
translated: I think.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana:

original: sarvalokaprasiddhatvena tad eva cañcalatvam upapādayati cañcalaṃ hīti /
analyzed: sarva loka prasiddha tvena tat eva cañcala tvam upapādayati cañcalam hi iti
translated: To explain its fickleness, well-known to all, he says fickle etc.

original: cañcalam atyarthaṃ calaṃ sadā calanasvabhāvaṃ manaḥ /
analyzed: cañcalam atyartham calam sadā calana svabhāvam manaḥ
translated: The mind is very unsteady, always moving, having the nature of constant motion.

original: hi prasiddham evaitat /🔽bhaktānāṃ pāpādidoṣān sarvathā nivārayitum aśakyān api kṛṣati nivārayati teṣām eva sarvathā prāptum aśayān api puruṣārthān ākarṣati prāpayatīti
analyzed: hi prasiddham eva etat  bhaktānām pāpa ādi doṣān sarvathā nivārayitum aśakyān api kṛṣati nivārayati teṣām eva sarvathā prāptum aśayān api puruṣa arthān ākarṣati prāpayati iti
translated: This is well known.

original: vā kṛṣṇaḥ /
analyzed: vā kṛṣṇaḥ
translated: Krishna is he who attracts, i.e., removes, the sins and other faults of the devotees, which cannot be removed at all, and attracts, i.e., brings, to them the human goals which cannot be attained at all.

original: tena rūpeṇa sambodhayan durnivāram api cittacāñcalyaṃ nivārya duṣprāpam api samādhisukhaṃ tvam eva prāpayituṃ śaknoṣīti sūcayati /
analyzed: tena rūpeṇa sambodhayan durnivāram api citta cāñcalyam nivārya duṣprāpam api samādhi sukham tvam eva prāpayitum śaknoṣi iti sūcayati
translated: By that form, addressing [the mind], you can remove even the very difficult unsteadiness of the mind and bring about even the difficult to attain bliss of concentration. This is the indication.

original: na kevalam atyarthaṃ cañcalaṃ kintu pramāthi śarīram indriyāṇi ca pramathituṃ kṣobhayituṃ śīlaṃ yasya tat /
analyzed: na kevalam atyartham cañcalam kintu pramāthi śarīram indriyāṇi ca pramathitum kṣobhayitum śīlam yasya tat
translated: Not only very unsteady, but also destructive, having the tendency to destroy the body and senses.

original: kṣobhakatayā śarīrendriyasaṃghātasya vivaśatāhetur ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: kṣobhaka tayā śarīra indriya saṃghātasya vivaśa tā hetuḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that by being a disturber, it is the cause of the helplessness of the aggregate of body and senses.

original: kiṃ ca balavat /
analyzed: kim ca balavat
translated: And what is powerful?

original: abhipretād viṣayāt kenāpy upāyena nivārayitum aśakyam /🔽kiṃ ca / dṛḍhaṃ viṣayavāsanāsahasrānusyūtatayā
analyzed: abhipretāt viṣayāt kena api upāyena nivārayitum aśakyam  kim ca dṛḍham viṣaya vāsanā sahasra anusyūta tayā
translated: It cannot be prevented from its intended object by any means.🔽And what is firm?

original: bhettum aśakyam /
analyzed: bhettum aśakyam
translated: It cannot be pierced by being sewn with thousands of desires for objects.

original: tantunāgavad acchedyam iti bhāṣye /
analyzed: tantu nāga vat acchedyam iti bhāṣye
translated: As it is said in the commentary: It is indivisible like a rope of fibers.

original: tantunāgo nāgapāśaḥ /
analyzed: tantunāgaḥ nāgapāśaḥ
translated: A nāga rope is a rope made of fibers.

original: tāntanīti gurjarādau prasiddho mahāhradanivāsī jantuviśeṣo vā /🔽tasyātidṛḍhatayā balavato balavattayā pramāthinaḥ pramāthitayāticañcalasya mahāmattavanagajasya
analyzed: tāntanī iti gurjara ādau prasiddhaḥ mahāhrada nivāsī jantu viśeṣaḥ vā  tasya ati dṛḍha tayā balavataḥ balavat tayā pramāthinaḥ pramāthi tayā ati cañcalasya mahā matta vana gajasya
translated: Or it may refer to a particular creature well-known in Gujarat and other places as tāntana, living in a large lake.

original: nigrahaṃ nirodhaṃ nirvṛttikatayāvasthānaṃ suduṣkaraṃ sarvathā kartum aśakyam ahaṃ manye /
analyzed: nigraham nirodham nirvṛttika tayā avasthānam su duṣkaram sarvathā kartum aśakyam aham manye
translated: I think it is extremely difficult to control, to stop, to make it remain inactive, in every way impossible to make it so,

original: vāyor iva /
analyzed: vāyoḥ iva
translated: like the wind.

original: yathākāśe dodhūyamānasya vāyor niścalatvaṃ sampādya nirodhanam aśakyaṃ tadvad ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: yathā ākāśe dodhūyamānasya vāyoḥ niścala tvam sampādya nirodhanam aśakyam tadvat iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is: just as it is impossible to make the wind blowing in the sky motionless and stop it, so is it with the mind.

original: ayaṃ bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: ayam bhāvaḥ
translated: This is the idea:

original: jāte 'pi tattvajñāne prārabdhakarmabhogāya jīvataḥ puruṣasya kartṛtvabhoktṛtvasukhaduḥkharāgadveṣādilakṣaṇaś
analyzed: jāte pi tattva jñāne prārabdha karma bhogāya jīvataḥ puruṣasya kartṛ tva bhoktṛ tva sukha duḥkha rāga dveṣa ādi lakṣaṇaḥ
translated: Even after the knowledge of reality has arisen, for a person who continues to experience the results of past actions, the mental state characterized by agency, enjoyment, pleasure, pain, attachment, aversion, etc.,

original: cittadharmaḥ kleśahetutvād bādhitānuvṛttyāpi bandho bhavati /
analyzed: citta dharmaḥ kleśa hetu tvāt bādhita anuvṛttyā api bandhaḥ bhavati
translated: becomes bondage even through the persistence of what has been suppressed, because it is the cause of afflictions.

original: cittavṛttinirodharūpeṇa tu yogena tasya nivāraṇaṃ jīvanmuktir ity ucyate /
analyzed: citta vṛtti nirodha rūpeṇa tu yogena tasya nivāraṇam jīvanmuktiḥ iti ucyate
translated: But its prevention through yoga in the form of the cessation of mental activity is said to be liberation while still alive.

original: yasyāḥ sampādanena sa yogī paramo mata ity uktam /
analyzed: yasyāḥ sampādanena sa yogī paramaḥ mataḥ iti uktam
translated: It has been said that by accomplishing that, the yogi is considered supreme.

original: tatredam ucyate /
analyzed: tatra idam ucyate
translated: Regarding that, this is said:

original: bandhaḥ kiṃ sākṣiṇo nivāryate kiṃ vā cittāt /
analyzed: bandhaḥ kim sākṣiṇaḥ nivāryate kim vā cittāt
translated: Is bondage prevented from the witness or from the mind?

original: nādyas tattvajñānenaiva sākṣiṇo bandhasya nivāritatvāt /
analyzed: na ādyaḥ tattva jñānena eva sākṣiṇaḥ bandhasya nivārita tvāt
translated: Not the first, because bondage is prevented by the witness itself through the knowledge of reality.

original: na dvitīyaḥ svabhāvaviparyayāyogāt /
analyzed: na dvitīyaḥ svabhāva viparyaya ayogāt
translated: Not the second, because it is not possible for the nature of something to be reversed.

original: virodhisadbhāvāc ca /
analyzed: virodhi sadbhāvāt ca
translated: And because of the existence of what is contrary.

original: na hi jalād ārdratvam agner voṣṇatvaṃ nivārayituṃ śakyate pratikṣaṇapariṇamino hi🔽bhāvā ṛte citiśakteḥ iti nyāyena pratikṣaṇapariṇamasvabhāvatvāc cittasya prārabdhabhogena
analyzed: na hi jalāt ārdra tvam agneḥ vā uṣṇa tvam nivārayitum śakyate pratikṣaṇa pariṇaminaḥ hi  bhāvāḥ ṛte citi śakteḥ iti nyāyena prati kṣaṇa pariṇama svabhāva tvāt cittasya prārabdha bhogena
translated: For the wetness of water or the heat of fire cannot be prevented. Indeed, according to the principle that entities are momentary transformations, except for the power of consciousness,

original: ca karmaṇā kṛtsnāvidyātatkāryanāśane pravṛttasya tattvajñānasyāpi pratibandhaṃ
analyzed: ca karmaṇā kṛtsna avidyā tad kārya nāśane pravṛttasya tattva jñānasya api pratibandham
translated: and because the mind has the nature of momentary transformation, even the knowledge of reality, which is engaged in destroying all ignorance and its effects,

original: kṛtvā svaphaladānāya dehendriyādikam avasthāpitam /
analyzed: kṛtvā sva phala dānāya deha indriya ādikam avasthāpitam
translated: having created an obstruction, establishes the body, senses, and so on in order to give its own fruit.

original: na ca karmaṇā svaphalasukhaduḥkhādibhogaś cittavṛttibhir vinā sampādayituṃ śakyate /
analyzed: na ca karmaṇā sva phala sukha duḥkha ādi bhogaḥ citta vṛttibhiḥ vinā sampādayitum śakyate
translated: And the enjoyment of one's own fruit, such as happiness and suffering, cannot be accomplished by actions without the modifications of the mind.

original: tasmād yadyapi svābhāvikānām api cittapariṇāmānāṃ kathaṃcid yogenābhibhavaḥ śakyeta
analyzed: tasmāt yadi api svābhāvikānām api citta pariṇāmānām kathaṃcid yogena abhibhavaḥ śakyeta
translated: Therefore, although the modifications of the mind, even if natural, can somehow be overcome by yoga,

original: kartuṃ tathāpi tattvajñānād iva yogād api prārabdhaphalasya karmaṇaḥ prābalyād
analyzed: kartum tathā api tattva jñānāt iva yogāt api prārabdha phalasya karmaṇaḥ prābalyāt
translated: Still, due to the strength of the karma that bears fruit, even though one is a knower of reality, one is not liberated from the body.

original: avaśyambhāvini cittasya cāñcalye yogena tannivāraṇam aśakyam ahaṃ svabodhād eva manye /
analyzed: avaśyambhāvini cittasya cāñcalye yogena tad nivāraṇam aśakyam aham sva bodhāt eva manye
translated: Still, I think that when the fickleness of the mind is inevitable, it is impossible to prevent it by Yoga, even as it is impossible to prevent the fruition of a past action by the knowledge of truth.

original: tasmād anupapannam etad ātmaupamyena sarvatra samadarśī paramo yogī mata ity arjunasyākṣepaḥ ///
analyzed: tasmāt anupapannam etat ātma aupamyena sarvatra sama darśī paramaḥ yogī mataḥ iti arjunasya ākṣepaḥ
translated: Therefore, this is not proper: The highest yogī is considered to be one who sees all equally by considering himself as equal to others. This is Arjuna's objection.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Viśvanātha:

original: etad evāha cañcalam iti /
analyzed: etat eva āha cañcalam iti
translated: He says this very thing with fickle (mind).

original: nanu ātmānaṃ rathinaṃ viddhi śarīraṃ ratham eva ca KaṭhU / / ity ādi śruteḥ /🔽āhuḥ śarīraṃ ratham indriyāṇi
analyzed: nanu ātmānam rathinam viddhi śarīram ratham eva ca kaṭhu iti ādi śruteḥ  āhuḥ śarīram ratham indriyāṇi
translated: Know the Self to be the rider, and the body to be the chariot. (BhG 13.2) etc.🔽They call the body a chariot, the senses

original: hayān abhīṣūn mana indriyeśam /
analyzed: hayān abhīṣūn manaḥ indriya īśam
translated: the horses, the mind the charioteer of the senses,

original: vartmāni mātrā dhiṣaṇaṃ ca sūtam BhP / / iti smṛteś ca
analyzed: vartmāni mātrāḥ dhiṣaṇam ca sūtam bhp  iti smṛteḥ ca
translated: the objects of sense the paths, and the intellect the driver. (BhG 5.9)

original: buddher mano niyantṛtvadarśanād vivekavatyā buddhyā mano vaśīkartuṃ śaktyam eveti ced ata āha balavat /
analyzed: buddheḥ manaḥ niyantṛ tva darśanāt vivekavatyā buddhyā manaḥ vaśīkartum eva iti ced atas āha balavat
translated: If it is argued that the mind can be controlled by the discriminating intellect, because the intellect is seen to be the controller of the mind, then he says powerful.

original: svapraśamakam auṣudham api balavān rogo yathā na gaṇayati /
analyzed: sva praśamakam auṣudham api balavān rogaḥ yathā na gaṇayati
translated: Just as a powerful disease does not take into account even the medicine that pacifies itself,

original: tathaiva svabhāvād eva baliṣṭhaṃ mano vivekavatīm api buddhim /🔽kiṃ ca dṛḍham atisūkṣmabuddhisūcyāpi loham iva sahasā bhettum aśakyam /
analyzed: tathā eva svabhāvāt eva baliṣṭham manaḥ vivekavatīm api buddhim  kim ca dṛḍham ati sūkṣma buddhi sūcyā api loham iva sahasā bhettum aśakyam
translated: Similarly, the mind, which is naturally very strong, cannot be pierced suddenly even with a very sharp and strong intellect.

original: vāyor ity ākāśe dodhūyamānasya vāyor nigrahaṃ kumbhakādinā nirodham iva yogenāṣṭāṅgena manaso 'pi nirodhaṃ duṣkaraṃ manye ////
analyzed: vāyoḥ iti ākāśe dodhūyamānasya vāyoḥ nigraham kumbhaka ādinā nirodham iva yogena aṣṭāṅgena nirodham duṣkaram manye
translated: Moreover, it is as difficult to control the mind by yoga with its eight limbs as it is to control the wind by stopping the air with the breath retention etc. in space.

original: baladevaḥ / tad evāha cañcalaṃ hīti /
analyzed: baladevaḥ tat eva āha cañcalam hi iti
translated: Balarama says: He says the same with Because the mind is naturally fickle.

original: manaḥ svabhāvena cañcalam / nanu
analyzed: manaḥ svabhāvena cañcalam nanu
translated: The mind is naturally fickle.

original: ātmānaṃ rathinaṃ viddhi śarīraṃ ratham eva ca /
analyzed: ātmānam rathinam viddhi śarīram ratham eva ca
translated: Know the self to be the traveler, and the body to be the chariot.

original: buddhiṃ tu sārathiṃ viddhi manaḥ pragraham eva ca //
analyzed: buddhim tu sārathim viddhi manaḥ pragraham eva ca
translated: But know the intellect to be the charioteer, and the mind to be the reins.

original: indriyāṇi hayān āhur viṣayāṃs teṣu gocarān /🔽ātmendriyamanoyukto bhoktety āhur manīṣiṇaḥ // KaṭhU / /
analyzed: indriyāṇi hayān āhuḥ viṣayān teṣu gocarān  ātma indriya manaḥ yuktaḥ bhoktā iti āhuḥ manīṣiṇaḥ kaṭhu
translated: The senses are said to be the horses, and the objects are their domain.🔽The wise say that the self, the senses, and the mind together are the enjoyer. Katha Upanishad

original: iti śruter buddhiniyamyaṃ manaḥ śrūyate tato vivekinyāṃ buddhyāṃ śakyaṃ tad vaśīkartum iti cet tatrāha pramāthīti /
analyzed: iti śruteḥ buddhi niyamyam manaḥ śrūyate tatas vivekinyām buddhyām śakyam tat vaśīkartum iti ced tatra āha pramāthi iti
translated: If it is argued that according to this Vedic text, the mind is controlled by the intellect, and therefore it can be subdued by the discriminating intellect, he says The mind is violent etc.

original: tādṛśīm api buddhiṃ pramathati /
analyzed: tādṛśīm api buddhim pramathati
translated: It overpowers even such an intellect.

original: kutaḥ / balavat svapraśamakam apy auṣadhaṃ yathā balavān rogo na gaṇayati / tadvat /
analyzed: kutas balavat sva praśamakam api auṣadham yathā balavān rogaḥ na gaṇayati tadvat
translated: Why? Just as a powerful disease does not care for a powerful medicine that would pacify itself, so it is.

original: kiṃ ca dṛḍham sūcyā lauham iva tādṛśyāpi buddhyā bhettum aśakyam ato yogenāpi tasya nigraham ahaṃ vāyor iva suduṣkaraṃ manye /
analyzed: kim ca dṛḍham sūcyā lauham iva tādṛśyā api buddhyā bhettum aśakyam atas yogena api tasya nigraham aham vāyoḥ iva su duṣkaram manye
translated: Moreover, it is firm, like iron pierced by a needle, and cannot be pierced even by such a strong intellect. Therefore, I think it is very difficult to control it even with yoga, like the wind.

original: na hi vāyor muṣṭinā dhartuṃ śakyate atas tatropāyaṃ brūhīti ////
analyzed: na hi vāyoḥ muṣṭinā dhartum śakyate atas tatra upāyam brūhi iti
translated: For the wind cannot be held with a fist. Therefore, tell me the means for that.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: śrībhagavān uvāca
analyzed: śrī bhagavān uvāca
translated: The Blessed Lord said:

original: asaṃśayaṃ mahābāho mano durṇigrahaṃ calam /
analyzed: asaṃśayam mahā bāho manaḥ durṇigraham calam
translated: Undoubtedly, O mighty-armed one, the mind is difficult to control and unsteady.

original: abhyāsena tu kaunteya vairāgyeṇa ca gṛhyate ////🔽śrīdharaḥ / tad uktaṃ cañcalatvādikam aṅgīkṛtyaiva manonigrahopāyaṃ śrībhagavān uvāca asaṃśayam iti /
analyzed: abhyāsena tu kaunteya vairāgyeṇa ca gṛhyate
translated: But, O son of Kunti, it is grasped by practice and non-attachment.🔽The Blessed Lord said this, accepting the statements about its fickleness etc., as the means to control the mind.

original: cañcalatvādinā mano niroddhum aśakyam iti yad vadasi etan niḥsaṃśayam eva /
analyzed: cañcala tva ādinā manaḥ niroddhum aśakyam iti yat vadasi etat niḥsaṃśayam eva
translated: You say that it is impossible to restrain the mind due to its fickleness etc., this is undoubtedly true.

original: tathāpi tv abhyāsena paramātmākārapratyayā vṛttyā viṣayavaitṛṣṇyena ca gṛhyate /
analyzed: tathā api tu abhyāsena paramātma ākāra pratyayā vṛttyā viṣaya vaitṛṣṇyena ca gṛhyate
translated: Nevertheless, it is grasped by practice, by the function of the idea of the supreme Self, and by non-attachment to objects.

original: abhyāsena layapratibandhād vairāgyeṇa ca vikṣepapratibandhād uparatavṛttikaṃ sat paramātmākāreṇa tiṣṭhatīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: abhyāsena laya pratibandhāt vairāgyeṇa ca vikṣepa pratibandhāt uparata vṛttikam sat paramātma ākāreṇa tiṣṭhati iti arthaḥ
translated: The meaning is that it remains in the form of the supreme Self, having its modifications ceased, by the obstruction of the modifications through practice and by the obstruction of distraction through non-attachment.

original: tad uktaṃ yogaśāstre
analyzed: tat uktam yogaśāstre
translated: That has been stated in the Yoga scriptures:

original: manaso vṛttiśūnyasya brahmākāratayā sthitiḥ /
analyzed: manasaḥ vṛtti śūnyasya brahma ākāra tayā sthitiḥ
translated: The state of the mind devoid of modifications, in the form of Brahman,

original: yāsamprajñātanāmāsau samādhir abhidhīyate // iti ////
analyzed: yā a samprajñāta nāmā asau samādhiḥ abhidhīyate iti
translated: That is called the superconscious concentration, samadhi.

original: madhusūdanaḥ /
analyzed: madhusūdanaḥ
translated: Madhusudana.

original: tam imam ākṣepaṃ pariharan śrībhagavān uvāca asaṃśayam iti /
analyzed: tam imam ākṣepam pariharan śrī bhagavān uvāca asaṃśayam iti
translated: The Blessed Lord, in order to remove this objection, said thus: Asamsayam, without doubt.

original: samyag viditaṃ te cittaceṣṭitaṃ mano nigrahītuṃ śakṣyasīti santoṣeṇa sambodhayati
analyzed: samyak viditam te citta ceṣṭitam manaḥ nigrahītum śakṣyasi iti santoṣeṇa sambodhayati
translated: He addresses him with satisfaction, saying: Samyag viditam, your mind's activities are well known to you; saksyasi, you will be able to; nigrahītum, control; the manah, mind.

original: he mahābāho mahāntau sākṣān mahādevenāpi saha kṛtapraharaṇau bāhū yasyeti niratiśayam utkarṣaṃ sūcayati /
analyzed: he mahābāho mahāntau sākṣāt mahādevena api saha kṛta praharaṇau bāhū yasya iti niratiśayam utkarṣam sūcayati
translated: O mighty-armed one, he whose arms are great, having fought with even Mahadeva himself, thus indicating his unsurpassed excellence.

original: prārabdhakarmaprābalyād asaṃyatātmanā durnigrahaṃ duḥkhenāpi nigrahītum aśakyam /
analyzed: prārabdha karma prābalyāt a saṃyata ātmanā durnigraham duḥkhena api nigrahītum aśakyam
translated: It is dur-nigraham, difficult to control, because of the strength of the prarabdha karma, and is asakantam, incapable of being controlled even with difficulty.

original: pramāthi balavad dṛḍham iti viśeṣaṇatrayaṃ piṇḍīkṛtyaitad uktam /
analyzed: pramāthi balavat dṛḍham iti viśeṣaṇa trayam piṇḍīkṛtya etat uktam
translated: The three adjectives pramathin, balavat and drdham have been combined and this has been said.

original: calaṃ svabhāvacañcalaṃ mana ity asaṃśayaṃ nāsty eva saṃśayo 'tra satyam evaitad bravīṣīty arthaḥ /
analyzed: calam svabhāva cañcalam manaḥ iti asaṃśayam na asti eva satyam eva etat bravīṣi iti arthaḥ
translated: The mind is fickle, naturally unsteady—there is no doubt about it. The meaning is: you are speaking the truth.

original: evaṃ saty api saṃyatātmanā samādhimātropāyena yoginābhyāsena vairāgyeṇa ca gṛhyate nigṛhyate sarvavṛttiśūnyaṃ kriyate tan mana ity arthaḥ
analyzed: evam sati api saṃyata ātmanā samādhi mātra upāyena yoginā abhyāsena vairāgyeṇa ca gṛhyate nigṛhyate sarva vṛtti śūnyam kriyate tat manaḥ iti arthaḥ
translated: Even so, it is grasped, controlled, made devoid of all modifications, by the yogi who has a controlled self, by practice, detachment, and the means of concentration alone. This is the meaning.

original: anigrahītur asaṃyatātmanaḥ sakāśāt saṃyatātmano nigrahītur viśeṣadyotanāya
analyzed: a nigrahītuḥ a saṃyata ātmanaḥ sakāśāt saṃyata ātmanaḥ nigrahītuḥ viśeṣa dyotanāya
translated: The word 'tu' is used to show the difference between one who does not control, who does not have a controlled self, and one who controls, who has a controlled self.

original: tuśabdaḥ / manonigrahe 'bhyāsavairāgyayoḥ samuccayabodhanāya caśabdaḥ /
analyzed: tuśabdaḥ manaḥ nigrahe bhyāsa vairāgyayoḥ samuccaya bodhanāya caśabdaḥ
translated: The word 'ca' is used to indicate the combination of practice and detachment in controlling the mind.

original: he kaunteyeti pitṛṣvasṛputras tvam avaśyaṃ mayā sukhī kartavya iti snehasambandhasūcanenāśvāsayati /
analyzed: he kaunteya iti pitṛṣvasṛ putraḥ tvam avaśyam mayā sukhī kartavyaḥ iti sneha sambandha sūcanena āśvāsayati
translated: O son of Kunti! You are the son of my paternal aunt. I must certainly make you happy. By showing affection and connection, he reassures [Arjuna].

original: atra prathamārdhena cittasya haṭhanigraho na sambhavatīti dvitīyārdhena tu kramanigrahaḥ sambhavatīty uktam /
analyzed: atra prathama ardhena cittasya haṭha nigrahaḥ na sambhavati iti dvitīya ardhena tu krama nigrahaḥ sambhavati iti uktam
translated: Here, by the first half, it is said that forcibly controlling the mind is not possible, but by the second half, gradual control is possible.

original: dvividho hi manaso nigrahaḥ /
analyzed: dvividhaḥ hi manasaḥ nigrahaḥ
translated: For there are two kinds of control of the mind:

original: haṭhena krameṇa ca /
analyzed: haṭhena krameṇa ca
translated: Forcible and gradual.

original: tatra cakṣuḥśrotrādīni jñānendriyāṇi vākpāṇyādīni karmendriyāṇi ca tadgolakamātroparodhena haṭhān nigṛhyante /
analyzed: tatra cakṣuḥ śrotra ādīni jñāna indriyāṇi vāc pāṇi ādīni karmendriyāṇi ca tad golaka mātra uparodhena haṭhāt nigṛhyante
translated: There, the eyes, ears, etc., the organs of knowledge, and the speech, hands, etc., the organs of action, are forcibly restrained by obstructing only their respective cavities.

original: taddṛṣṭāntena mano 'pi haṭhena nigrahīṣyāmīti mūḍhasya bhrāntir bhavati /
analyzed: tad dṛṣṭāntena manaḥ pi haṭhena nigrahīṣyāmi iti mūḍhasya bhrāntiḥ bhavati
translated: The deluded one has the misconception that he will forcibly restrain the mind also by that example.

original: na ca tathā nigrahītuṃ śakyate tadgolakasya hṛdayakamalasya niroddhum aśakyatvāt /
analyzed: na ca tathā nigrahītum śakyate tad golakasya hṛdaya kamalasya niroddhum aśakya tvāt
translated: And it cannot be restrained in that way, because the cavity of the heart-lotus cannot be obstructed.

original: ataeva ca kramanigraha eva yuktas tad etad bhagavān vasiṣṭha āha 🔽upaviśyopaviśyaiva cittajñena muhur muhuḥ /
analyzed: ataeva ca krama nigrahaḥ eva yuktaḥ tat etat bhagavān vasiṣṭhaḥ āha  upaviśya upaviśya eva citta jñena muhur muhur
translated: For this very reason, gradual restraint alone is proper. This has been said by the revered Vasistha:

original: na śakyate mano jetuṃ vinā yuktim aninditām //
analyzed: na śakyate manaḥ jetum vinā yuktim aninditām
translated: Sitting again and again, the one who knows the mind cannot repeatedly conquer the mind without faultless reasoning.

original: aṅkuśena vinā matto yathā duṣṭamataṅgajaḥ /
analyzed: aṅkuśena vinā mattaḥ yathā duṣṭa mataṅga jaḥ
translated: Just as a mad and wicked elephant cannot be controlled without a goad.

original: adhyātmavidyādhigamaḥ sādhusaṅgama eva ca //
analyzed: adhyātma vidyā adhigamaḥ sādhu saṅgamaḥ eva ca
translated: The attainment of the knowledge of the supreme Self, association with the good alone,

original: vāsanāsamparityāgaḥ prāṇaspandanirodhanam /🔽etās tā yuktayaḥ puṣṭāḥ santi cittajaye kila //🔽satīṣu yuktiṣv etāsu haṭhān niyamayanti ye /
analyzed: vāsanā samparityāgaḥ prāṇa spanda nirodhanam  etāḥ tāḥ yuktayaḥ puṣṭāḥ santi citta jaye kila  satīṣu yuktiṣu etāsu haṭhāt niyamayanti ye
translated: the complete abandonment of desires, the restraint of the fluctuations of the vital energy,🔽these are indeed the well-nourished reasonings for the conquest of the mind.🔽Those who forcibly control the mind in the presence of these reasonings,

original: cetas te dīpam utsṛjya vinighnanti tamo 'ñjanaiḥ // iti /
analyzed: cetaḥ te dīpam utsṛjya vinighnanti tamaḥ ñjanaiḥ iti
translated: they are like those who abandon a lamp and try to destroy darkness with collyrium.

original: kramanigrahe cādhyātmavidyādhigama eka upāyaḥ /
analyzed: krama nigrahe ca adhyātma vidyā adhigamaḥ ekaḥ upāyaḥ
translated: And in the control of the sequence, the acquisition of the knowledge of the self is one means.

original: sā hi dṛśyasya mithyātvaṃ dṛgvastunaś ca paramārthasatyaparamānandasvaprakāśatavaṃ bodhayati /
analyzed: sā hi dṛśyasya mithyātvam dṛś vastunaḥ ca paramārtha satya parama ānanda sva prakāśa tavam bodhayati
translated: For that (knowledge) teaches the unreality of the seen and the supreme truth and bliss of the seen object, which is self-luminous.

original: tathā ca saty etan manaḥ svagocareṣu buddhvā nirindhanāgnivat svayam evopaśāmyati /
analyzed: tathā ca sati etat manaḥ sva gocareṣu buddhvā nirindhana agni vat svayam evā upaśāmyati
translated: And when that is so, this mind, having understood (the truth) in its own sphere, becomes calm by itself like a fire without fuel.

original: yas tu bodhitam api tattvaṃ na samyag budhyate yo vā vismarati tayoḥ sādhusaṅgama evopāyaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ tu bodhitam api tattvam na samyak budhyate yaḥ vā vismarati tayoḥ sādhu saṅgamaḥ evā upāyaḥ
translated: But for those two (persons), for whom the truth, though taught, is not fully understood or who forget it, association with the good is itself the means.

original: sādhavo hi punaḥ punar bodhayanti smārayanti ca /
analyzed: sādhavaḥ hi punar punar bodhayanti smārayanti ca
translated: For the good repeatedly teach and remind (the truth).

original: yas tu vidyāmadādidurvāsanayā pīḍyamāno na sādhūn anuvartitum utsahate tasya pūrvoktavivekena vāsanāparityāga evopāyaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ tu vidyā mad ādi durvāsanayā pīḍyamānaḥ na sādhūn anuvartitum utsahate tasya pūrva ukta vivekena vāsanā parityāgaḥ eva upāyaḥ
translated: But for him who, afflicted by bad desires such as the intoxication of knowledge, is not eager to follow the good, the means for him is the abandonment of desires by the discrimination described above.

original: yas tu vāsanānām atiprābalyāt tās tyaktuṃ na śaknoti tasya prāṇaspandanirodha eva upāyaḥ /
analyzed: yaḥ tu vāsanānām ati prābalyāt tāḥ tyaktum na śaknoti tasya prāṇa spanda nirodhaḥ eva upāyaḥ
translated: But for him who, because of the excessive strength of the desires, is unable to abandon them, the means is the cessation of the movement of the vital breath itself.

original: prāṇaspandavāsanayoś cittaprerakatvāt tayor nirodhe cittaśāntir upapadyate /
analyzed: prāṇa spanda vāsanayoḥ citta preraka tvāt tayoḥ nirodhe citta śāntiḥ upapadyate
translated: For the movement of the vital breath and the desires are the impellers of the mind, and when they are stopped, the peace of the mind becomes possible.

original: tad etad āha sa eva
analyzed: tat etat āha saḥ eva
translated: This is said by him (Vyāsa) himself (in the following verse):

original: dve bīje cittavṛkṣasya prāṇaspandanavāsane /
analyzed: dve bīje citta vṛkṣasya prāṇa spandana vāsane
translated: The two seeds of the tree of the mind are the impressions of the movement of the vital breath.

original: ekasmiṃś ca tayoḥ kṣīṇe kṣipraṃ dve api naśyataḥ //🔽prāṇāyāmadṛḍhābhyāsair yuktyā ca gurudattayā /
analyzed: ekasmin ca tayoḥ kṣīṇe kṣipram dve api naśyataḥ  prāṇāyāma dṛḍha abhyāsaiḥ yuktyā ca guru dattayā
translated: When one of them is destroyed, both quickly perish.🔽By firm practice of breath control, by the reasoning given by the teacher,

original: āsanāśanayogena prāṇaspando nirudhyate //
analyzed: āsana aśana yogena prāṇa spandaḥ nirudhyate
translated: By the yoga of posture and diet, the movement of the vital breath is stopped.

original: asaṅgavyavahāritvād bhavabhāvanavarjanāt /
analyzed: asaṅga vyavahāri tvāt bhava bhāvana varjanāt
translated: Because of engaging in non-attachment, because of avoiding the cultivation of existence,

original: śarīranāśadarśitvād vāsanā na pravartate //
analyzed: śarīra nāśa darśi tvāt vāsanā na pravartate
translated: Because of showing the destruction of the body, the impression does not arise.

original: vāsanāsamparityāgāc cittaṃ gacchaty acittatām /
analyzed: vāsanā samparityāgāt cittam gacchati acitta tām
translated: By completely abandoning the impressions, the mind goes to the state of no-mind.

original: prāṇaspandanirodhāc ca yathecchasi tathā kuru //🔽etāvan mātrakaṃ manye rūpaṃ cittasya rāghava /
analyzed: prāṇa spanda nirodhāt ca yathā icchasi tathā kuru  etāvat mātrakam manye rūpam cittasya rāghava
translated: By stopping the movement of the vital breath, do as you wish.🔽I consider this much to be the form of the mind, O Raghava,

original: yad bhāvanaṃ vastuno 'ntarvastutvena rasena ca //
analyzed: yat bhāvanam vastunaḥ ntar vastu tvena rasena ca
translated: That the object is contemplated as an object within the mind and with taste.

original: yadā na bhāvyate kiṃcid dheyopādeyarūpi yat /
analyzed: yadā na bhāvyate kiṃcid dheya upādeya rūpi yat
translated: When nothing is contemplated that is to be accepted or rejected,

original: sthīyate sakalaṃ tyaktvā tadā cittaṃ na jāyate //
analyzed: sthīyate sakalam tyaktvā tadā cittam na jāyate
translated: When everything is abandoned and one abides, then the mind does not arise.

original: avāsanatvāt satataṃ yadā na manute manaḥ /
analyzed: avāsana tvāt satatam yadā na manute manaḥ
translated: When the mind does not think at all because of being without impressions,

original: amanastā tadodeti paramātmapadapradā // iti /
analyzed: amanaḥ tā tadā udeti paramātma pada pradā iti
translated: Then non-mentation arises, bestowing the state of the supreme self.

original: atra dvāv evopāyau paryavasitau prāṇaspandanirodhārtham abhyāsaḥ /
analyzed: atra dvau eva upāyau paryavasitau prāṇa spanda nirodha artham abhyāsaḥ
translated: Here, only two means are concluded for the purpose of stopping the fluctuations of the life force: practice,

original: vāsanāparityāgārthaṃ ca vairāgyam iti /
analyzed: vāsanā parityāga artham ca vairāgyam iti
translated: and non-attachment for the purpose of abandoning latent impressions.

original: sādhusaṅgamādhyātmavidyādhigamau tv abhyāsavairāgyopapādakatayānyathāsiddhau tayor evāntarbhavataḥ /
analyzed: sādhu saṅgama adhyātma vidyā adhigamau tu abhyāsa vairāgya upapādaka tayā anyathā siddhau tayoḥ eva antarbhavataḥ
translated: But association with the good and the acquisition of knowledge of the self are included within those two, since they are established in another way as producing practice and non-attachment.

original: ata eva bhagavatābhyāsena vairāgyeṇa ceti dvayam evoktam /
analyzed: atas eva bhagavatā abhyāsena vairāgyeṇa ca iti dvayam eva uktam
translated: For this very reason, the Blessed Lord has said only two things: by practice and by non-attachment.

original: ataeva bhagavān patañjalir asūtrayat abhyāsavairāgyābhyāṃ tannirodhaḥ YogaS / iti /
analyzed: ataeva bhagavān patañjaliḥ asūtrayat abhyāsa vairāgyābhyām tad nirodhaḥ yogaḥ iti
translated: For this very reason, the Blessed Lord Patañjali has formulated thus: The cessation of those [fluctuations] is yoga by practice and non-attachment.

original: tāsāṃ prāguktānāṃ pramāṇaviparyayavikalpanidrāsmṛtirūpeṇa pañcavidhānām anantānām
analyzed: tāsām prāguktānām pramāṇa viparyaya vikalpa nidrā smṛti rūpeṇa pañcavidhānām anantānām
translated: Of those fluctuations, which were previously mentioned as being of five kinds in the form of valid knowledge, error, imagination, sleep, and memory, and as being infinite,

original: āsuratvena kliṣṭānāṃ daivatvenākliṣṭānām api vṛttīnāṃ sarvāssām api nirodho nirindhanāgnivad
analyzed: āsura tvena kliṣṭānām daiva tvena akliṣṭānām api vṛttīnām sarvāssām api nirodhaḥ nirindhana agni vat
translated: both the afflicted ones, which are demonic, and the unafflicted ones, which are divine, all of them, their cessation, like a fire without fuel,

original: upaśamākhyaḥ pariṇāmo 'bhyāsena vairāgyeṇa ca samuccitena bhavati /
analyzed: upaśama ākhyaḥ pariṇāmaḥ bhyāsena vairāgyeṇa ca samuccitena bhavati
translated: is a transformation called peace, which occurs by the combined practice and non-attachment.

original: tad uktaṃ yogabhāṣye cittanadī nāmobhayatovāhinī vahati kalyāṇāya vahati pāpāya ca /
analyzed: tat uktam yogabhāṣye citta nadī nāma ubhayatas vāhinī vahati kalyāṇāya vahati pāpāya ca
translated: That is said in the Yoga Bhāṣya: The river of the mind, which flows in two directions, flows for good and flows for evil.

original: tatra yā kaivalyaprāgbhārā vivekanimnā sā kalyāṇavahā
analyzed: tatra yā kaivalya prāgbhārā viveka nimnā sā kalyāṇa vahā
translated: Of these, that which has Kaivalya (isolation) as its burden and is inclined towards discrimination is conducive to good.

original: yā tv avivekanimnā saṃsāraprāgbhārā sā pāpavahā /
analyzed: yā tu aviveka nimnā saṃsāra prāgbhārā sā pāpa vahā
translated: But that which is inclined towards non-discrimination and has worldly existence as its burden is conducive to evil.

original: tatra vairāgyeṇa viṣayasrotaḥ khilīkriyate /
analyzed: tatra vairāgyeṇa viṣaya srotaḥ khilīkriyate
translated: There, by non-attachment, the current of objects is dammed up.

original: vivekadarśanābhyāsena ca kalyāṇasrota udghāṭyate ity ubhayādhīnaś cittavṛttinirodha iti /
analyzed: viveka darśana abhyāsena ca kalyāṇa srotaḥ udghāṭyate iti ubhaya adhīnaḥ citta vṛtti nirodhaḥ iti
translated: And by the practice of the vision of discrimination, the current of good is opened up. Thus, the cessation of the modifications of the mind depends on both.

original: prāgbhāranimnapade tadā vivekanimnaṃ kaivalyaprāgbhāraṃ cittam ity atra vyākhyāyate /
analyzed: prāgbhāra nimna pade tadā viveka nimnam kaivalya prāgbhāram cittam iti atra vyākhyāyate
translated: Here, in the words 'burden' and 'inclination', it is explained that the mind which is inclined towards discrimination and has Kaivalya (isolation) as its burden.

original: yathā tīvravegopetaṃ nadīpravāhaṃ setubandhanena nivārya kulyāpraṇayena kṣetrābhimukhaṃ
analyzed: yathā tīvra vega upetam nadī pravāham setu bandhanena nivārya kulyā praṇayena kṣetra abhimukham
translated: Just as a river current endowed with intense speed is stopped by building a dam and by constructing canals, it is directed towards the fields,

original: tiryakpravāhāntaram utpādyate tathā vairāgyeṇa cittanadyā viṣayapravāhaṃ nivārya
analyzed: tiryak pravāha antaram utpādyate tathā vairāgyeṇa citta nadyāḥ viṣaya pravāham nivārya
translated: and another horizontal current is produced, similarly, by non-attachment, the current of objects of the river of the mind is stopped,

original: samādhyabhyāsena praśāntavāhitā sampādyata iti dvārabhedāt samuccaya eva /
analyzed: samādhi abhyāsena praśānta vāhi tā sampādyate iti dvāra bhedāt samuccayaḥ eva
translated: and by the practice of concentration, the state of flowing peacefully is accomplished. Thus, there is combination itself due to the difference in the means.

original: ekadvāratve hi brīhiyavadvikalpaḥ syād iti /
analyzed: eka dvāra tve hi brīhi yava dvikalpaḥ syāt iti
translated: For, if there were only one means, there would be an option like that between rice and barley.

original: mantrajapadevatādhyānādīnāṃ kriyārūpāṇām āvṛttilakṣaṇo 'bhyāsaḥ sambhavāt /
analyzed: mantra japa devatā dhyāna ādīnām kriyā rūpāṇām āvṛtti lakṣaṇaḥ bhyāsaḥ sambhavāt
translated: As for the repetitions characterized by the practice of the rites such as the muttering of mantras, meditation on deities, etc., it is possible.

original: sarvavyāpāroparamasya tu samādheḥ ko nāmābhyāsa iti śaṅkāṃ nivārayitum abhyāsaṃ sūtrayati sma tatra sthitau yatno 'bhyāsaḥ YogaS / iti
analyzed: sarva vyāpāra uparamasya tu samādheḥ kaḥ nāma abhyāsaḥ iti śaṅkām nivārayitum abhyāsam sūtrayati sma tatra sthitau yatnaḥ bhyāsaḥ iti
translated: But in order to remove the doubt as to what kind of practice there is for the concentration which is the cessation of all activity, he has formulated the practice thus: Abhyasa, practice, is the effort for stability in that.

original: tatra svarūpāvasthite draṣṭari śuddhe cidātmani cittasyāvṛttikasya praśāntavāhitārūpā
analyzed: tatra sva rūpa avasthite draṣṭari śuddhe cit ātmani cittasya avṛttikasya
translated: There, in the pure Self which is the seer abiding in its own nature, the state of the mind which is free from modifications, which is of the form of tranquil flow,

original: niścalatāsthitis tadarthaṃ yatno mānasa utsāhaḥ svabhāvacāñcalyād bahiṣpravāhaśīlaṃ
analyzed: niścala tā sthitiḥ tad artham yatnaḥ mānasaḥ utsāhaḥ svabhāva cāñcalyāt bahiṣpravāha śīlam
translated: is steadiness. The effort for that is mental enthusiasm. The mind which is naturally fickle, which is of the nature of flowing outwards,

original: cittaṃ sarvathā nirotsyāmīty evaṃ vidhaḥ /
analyzed: cittam sarvathā nirotsyāmi iti evaṃvidhaḥ
translated: is to be stopped in every way. Such is the practice.

original: sa āvartyamāno 'bhyāsa ucyate /
analyzed: saḥ āvartyamānaḥ bhyāsaḥ ucyate
translated: That, when repeated, is called practice.

original: sa tu dīrghakālanairantaryasatkārāsevito dṛḍhabhūmiḥ YogaS / anirvedena dīrghakālasevito vicchedābhāvena nirantarāsevitaḥ satkāreṇa
analyzed: sa tu dīrgha kāla nairantarya satkāra āsevitaḥ dṛḍha bhūmiḥ yogaḥ anirvedena dīrgha kāla sevitaḥ viccheda abhāvena nirantara āsevitaḥ satkāreṇa
translated: But that practice, when pursued for a long time, uninterruptedly, with reverence, becomes firmly grounded, and is yoga. When pursued for a long time without despair, when pursued uninterruptedly without breaks,

original: śraddhātiśayena cāsevitaḥ /
analyzed: śraddhā atiśayena ca āsevitaḥ
translated: when pursued with reverence, with excess of faith,

original: so 'bhyāso dṛḍhabhūmir viṣayasukhavāsanayā cālayitum aśakyo bhavati /
analyzed: saḥ bhyāsaḥ dṛḍha bhūmiḥ viṣaya sukha vāsanayā cālayitum aśakyaḥ bhavati
translated: that practice becomes firmly grounded, incapable of being shaken by the impressions of sensual pleasures.

original: adīrghakālatve dīrghakālatve 'pi vicchidya
analyzed: a dīrgha kāla tve dīrgha kāla tve vicchidya
translated: If it is not pursued for a long time, or even if pursued for a long time but with interruptions,

original: vicchidya sevane śraddhātiśayābhāve ca layavikṣepakaṣāyasukhāsvādānām aparihāre vyutthānasaṃskāraprābalyād adṛḍhabhūmir abhyāsaḥ phalāya
analyzed: vicchidya sevane śraddhā atiśaya abhāve ca laya vikṣepa kaṣāya sukha āsvādānām aparihāre vyutthāna saṃskāra prābalyāt adṛḍha bhūmiḥ abhyāsaḥ phalāya  /
translated: When there is no excess of faith in the practice of cutting off, and when there is no avoidance of laxity, distraction, and the taste of pleasure, due to the strength of the latent impressions of emergence, the practice is not firmly grounded and will not lead to the result.

original: na syād iti trayam upāttam /
analyzed: na syāt iti trayam upāttam
translated: Thus, the three are included.

original: vairāgyaṃ tu dvividham aparaṃ paraṃ ca /
analyzed: vairāgyam tu dvividham aparam param ca
translated: But detachment is of two kinds: lower and higher.

original: yatmānasaṃjñāvyatirekasaṃjñaikendriyasaṃjñāvaśīkārasaṃjñābhedair aparaṃ caturdhā /
analyzed: yat māna saṃjñā vyatireka saṃjñā eka indriya saṃjñā vaśīkāra saṃjñā bhedaiḥ aparam caturdhā
translated: The lower is of four kinds, distinguished by the notions of non-self, separation, single sense, and mastery.

original: tatra pūrvabhūmijayenottarabhūmisampādanavivakṣayā caturtham evāsūtrayat dṛṣṭānuśravikaviṣayavitṛṣṇasya vaśīkārasaṃjñā vairāgyam
analyzed: tatra pūrva bhūmi jayena uttara bhūmi sampādana vivakṣayā caturtham eva asūtrayat dṛṣṭa ānuśravika viṣaya vitṛṣṇasya vaśīkāra saṃjñā vairāgyam
translated: Among them, with the intention of accomplishing the higher stage by conquering the lower stage, he taught only the fourth: Detachment is the notion of mastery for one who is free from craving for seen and heard objects.

original: YogaS / iti /
analyzed: yogaḥ iti
translated: This is yoga.

original: striyo 'nnaṃ pānam aiśvaryam ity ādayo dṛṣṭā viṣayāḥ /🔽svargo videhatā prakṛtilaya ity ādayo vaidikatvenānuśravikā viṣayās teṣūbhayavidheṣv api satyām eva tṛṣṇāyāṃ vivekatāratamyena yatamānāditrayaṃ
analyzed: striyaḥ annam pānam aiśvaryam iti ādayaḥ dṛṣṭāḥ viṣayāḥ  svargaḥ videha tā prakṛti layaḥ iti ādayaḥ vaidika tvena ānuśravikāḥ viṣayāḥ teṣu ubhayavidheṣu api satyām eva tṛṣṇāyām viveka tāratamyena yatamāna ādi trayam
translated: Seen objects are such as women, food, drink, and power, etc.

original: bhavati /
analyzed: bhavati
translated: Heard objects are such as heaven, disembodied state, and merging into primordial matter, etc., which are considered Vedic. Even when there is craving for both kinds of objects, the three - striving, etc. - arise due to the gradation of discrimination.

original: atra jagati kiṃ sāraṃ kim asāram iti guruśāstrābhyāṃ jñāsāmīty udyogo yatamānam /
analyzed: atra jagati kim sāram kim asāram iti guru śāstrābhyām jñāsāmi iti udyogaḥ yatamānam
translated: Here, the striving is the effort to know through the teacher and the scriptures what is essential and what is inessential in this world, thinking I will know.

original: svacitte pūrvavidyamānadoṣāṇāṃ madhye 'bhyasyamānavivekenaite pakvā ete 'vaśiṣṭā iti cikitsakavad vivecanaṃ vyatirekaḥ /🔽dṛṣṭānuśravikaviṣayapravṛtter
analyzed: sva citte pūrva vidyamāna doṣāṇām madhye bhyasyamāna vivekena ete pakvāḥ ete iti cikitsaka vat vivecanam vyatirekaḥ  dṛṣṭa ānuśravika viṣaya pravṛtteḥ
translated: Discrimination is the discernment like a physician that these are ripe and these remain among the faults previously present in one's own mind, by means of the discrimination being practiced.

original: duḥkhātmatvabodhena bhair indriyapravṛttim ajanayantyā api tṛṣṇāyā autsukyamātreṇa manasy avasthānam ekendriyam /
analyzed: duḥkha ātma tva bodhena bhaiḥ indriya pravṛttim a janayantyāḥ api tṛṣṇāyāḥ autsukya mātreṇa manasi avasthānam eka indriyam
translated: The one-sensed [state] is the abiding of the mind in mere eagerness, even though it does not generate the activity of the senses like a physician, due to the knowledge that the nature of engagement with seen and heard objects is suffering.

original: manasy api tṛṣṇāśūnyatvena sarvathā vaitṛṣṇyaṃ tṛṣṇāvirodhinī cittavṛttir jñānaprasādarūpā
analyzed: manasi api tṛṣṇā śūnya tvena sarvathā vaitṛṣṇyam tṛṣṇā virodhinī citta vṛttiḥ jñāna prasāda rūpā
translated: Detachment is the complete absence of craving in the mind even in the mind, devoid of craving, and the mental activity opposing craving, which is in the form of the clarity of knowledge.

original: vaśīkārasaṃjñā vairāgyaṃ samprajñātasya samādher antaraṅgaṃ sādhanam asaṃprajñātasya tu bahiraṅgam /
analyzed: vaśīkāra saṃjñā vairāgyam samprajñātasya samādheḥ antaraṅgam sādhanam asaṃprajñātasya tu bahiraṅgam
translated: The internal means of the meditative concentration with discursive thought is called mastery, but the external means of the non-discursive meditative concentration is detachment.

original: tasya tv antaraṅgasādhanaṃ param evaṃ vairāgyam /
analyzed: tasya tu antaraṅga sādhanam param evam vairāgyam
translated: But the supreme means of the internal is such detachment.

original: tac cāsūtrayat tatparaṃ puruṣakhyāter guṇavaitṛṣṇyam YogaS / iti /
analyzed: tat ca asūtrayat tat param puruṣa khyāteḥ guṇa vaitṛṣṇyam yogaḥ iti
translated: And that has not been formulated, that is the supreme, which is the non-desire for the qualities due to the knowledge of the supreme Self. Yoga is that.

original: samprajñātasamādhipāṭavena guṇatrayātmakāt pradhānād viviktasya puruṣasya khyātiḥ sākṣātkāra utpadyate /
analyzed: samprajñāta samādhi pāṭavena guṇa traya ātmakāt pradhānāt viviktasya puruṣasya khyātiḥ sākṣātkāraḥ utpadyate
translated: By the skill in samprajnata samadhi, there arises the manifestation, the direct realization, of the Purusha, who is distinct from Prakriti, which consists of the three qualities.

original: tataś cāśeṣaguṇatrayavyavahāreṣu vaitṛṣṇyaṃ yad bhavati tatparaṃ śreṣṭhaṃ phalabhūtaṃ vairāgyam /
analyzed: tatas ca aśeṣa guṇatraya vyavahāreṣu vaitṛṣṇyam yat bhavati tat param śreṣṭham phala bhūtam vairāgyam
translated: And then, the non-attachment to all the transactions of the three qualities, which occurs, is the supreme, the best, the resultant non-attachment.

original: tatparipākanimittāc ca cittopaśamaparipākād avilambena kaivalyam iti ////
analyzed: tad paripāka nimittāt ca citta upaśama paripākāt avilambena kaivalyam iti
translated: And from the maturity of that, and from the maturity of the pacification of the mind, there is Kaivalya, isolation, without delay.

original: viśvanāthaḥ /
translated: Visvanatha.

original: uktam artham aṅgīkṛtya samadadhāti aśaṃśayam iti /
analyzed: uktam artham aṅgīkṛtya samadadhāti aśaṃśayam iti
translated: Having accepted the stated meaning, he agrees with without doubt.

original: tvayoktaṃ satyam eva /
analyzed: tvayā uktam satyam eva
translated: What you have said is indeed true.

original: kintu balavān api rogas tatpraśamakauṣadhasevayā sadvaidyaprayuktaprakārayā muhur abhyastayā yathā cirakālena śāmyaty eva /
analyzed: kintu balavān api rogaḥ tad praśamaka auṣadha sevayā sat vaidya prayukta prakārayā muhur abhyastayā yathā cira kālena śāmyati eva
translated: But just as a powerful disease is pacified only after a long time by the use of medicine that alleviates it, by the method employed by a good physician, and by repeated practice,

original: tathā durnigraham api mano 'bhyāsena sadgurūpadiṣṭaprakāreṇa parameśvaradhyānayogasya
analyzed: tathā durnigraham api manaḥ bhyāsena sat guru upadiṣṭa prakāreṇa parameśvara dhyāna yogasya
translated: in the same way, the mind, though difficult to control, is grasped, i.e. can be brought under one's own control,

original: muhur anuśīlanena vairāgyeṇa viṣayeṣv anāsaṅgena ca gṛhyate svahastavaśīkartuṃ
analyzed: muhur anuśīlanena vairāgyeṇa viṣayeṣu anāsaṅgena ca gṛhyate sva hasta vaśīkartum
translated: by practice, by the method taught by a good guru, by the yoga of meditation on the Supreme Lord,

original: śakyata ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: śakyate iti arthaḥ
translated: and by non-attachment, by non-attachment to objects.

original: tathā ca pātañjalasūtram abhyāsavairāgyābhyāṃ tannirodhaḥ YogaS / iti /
analyzed: tathā ca pātañjala sūtram abhyāsa vairāgyābhyām tad nirodhaḥ yogaḥ iti
translated: And thus the aphorism of Patanjali: Its cessation is yoga by means of practice and non-attachment.

original: mahābāho iti saṅgrāme tvayā yan mahāvīrā api vijīyante /
analyzed: mahā bāho iti saṅgrāme tvayā yat mahāvīrāḥ api vijīyante
translated: O mighty-armed one, that in battle you conquer even great heroes.

original: sa ca pinākapāṇir api vaśīkṛtas tenāpi kim /
analyzed: sa ca pinākapāṇiḥ api vaśīkṛtaḥ tena api kim
translated: And that even the wielder of the Pinaka (Shiva) is subdued by you, what of that?

original: yadi mahāvīraśiromaṇir mano nāmā prādhāniko bhaṭo mahāyogāstraprayogeṇa jetuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: yadi mahāvīra śiromaṇiḥ manaḥ nāmā prādhānikaḥ bhaṭaḥ mahā yoga astra prayogeṇa jetum śakyate
translated: If the chief warrior named mind, the crest-jewel of great heroes, can be conquered by the application of the weapon of great yoga,

original: tadaiva mahābāhuteti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tadā eva mahā bāhu tā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: then alone you are mighty-armed, is the idea.

original: he kaunteyeti tatra tvaṃ mā bhaiṣīḥ /
analyzed: he kaunteya iti tatra tvam mā bhaiṣīḥ
translated: O son of Kunti, there you should not be afraid.

original: matpituḥ svasuḥ
analyzed: mad pituḥ svasuḥ
translated: Of my father's sister

original: kuntyāḥ putre tvayi mayā sāhāyyaṃ vidheyam iti bhāvaḥ ////
analyzed: kuntyāḥ putre tvayi mayā sāhāyyam vidheyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: Kunti, in you, her son, I should render assistance, is the idea.

original: baladevaḥ / uktam artham svīkṛtya bhagavān uvāca aśaṃśayam iti /🔽tathāpi svaprakāśasukhaikatānatvātmaguṇābhimukhyābhyāsenātmavyatirikteṣu viṣayeṣu doṣadṛṣṭijanitena vairāgyeṇa ca mano nigrahītuṃ śakyate
analyzed: baladevaḥ uktam artham svīkṛtya bhagavān uvāca aśaṃśayam iti  tathā api sva prakāśa sukha ekatāna tva ātma guṇa ābhimukhya abhyāsena ātma vyatirikteṣu viṣayeṣu doṣa dṛṣṭi janitena vairāgyeṇa ca manaḥ nigrahītum śakyate
translated: Balarama. Having accepted the stated meaning, the Lord said undoubtedly.🔽Even so, by the practice of being absorbed in the qualities of the Self, which consists of the Self's being one-pointed in the bliss of its own manifestation, and by non-attachment, which is produced by the perception of faults in objects other than the Self, the mind can be controlled.

original: tathā cātmānandāsvādhābhyāsena layapratibandhād viṣayavaitṛṣṇyena ca vikṣepapratibandhān
analyzed: tathā ca ātma ānanda asvādha abhyāsena laya pratibandhāt viṣaya vaitṛṣṇyena ca vikṣepa pratibandhān
translated: And thus, by the practice of tasting the bliss of the Self, there is the obstruction of inertia, and by the absence of craving for objects, there is the obstruction of distraction.

original: nivṛttacāpalyaṃ manaḥ sugrahaṃ yathā sadauṣadhasevayā sadvaidyaprayuktaprakārayā
analyzed: nivṛtta cāpalyam manaḥ su graham yathā sat auṣadha sevayā sat vaidya prayukta prakārayā
translated: Just as the mind, free from fickleness, becomes easily controllable by the use of good medicines and the application of proper remedies,

original: muhur abhyastayā yathā cirakālena śāmyaty eva /
analyzed: muhur abhyastayā yathā cira kālena śāmyati eva
translated: and just as it is pacified only after a long time by repeated practice,

original: tathā durnigraham api mano 'bhyāsena sadgurūpadiṣṭaprakāreṇa parameśvaradhyānayogasya
analyzed: tathā durnigraham api manaḥ bhyāsena sat guru upadiṣṭa prakāreṇa parameśvara dhyāna yogasya
translated: in the same way, even the difficult-to-control mind is controlled by practice, by the method taught by a good guru, by the yoga of meditation on the Supreme Lord,

original: muhur anuśīlanena vairāgyeṇa viṣayeṣv anāsaṅgena ca gṛhyate svahastavaśīkartuṃ
analyzed: muhur anuśīlanena vairāgyeṇa viṣayeṣu anāsaṅgena ca gṛhyate sva hasta vaśīkartum
translated: and by dispassion, by non-attachment to objects, it is possible to bring it under one's own control,

original: śakyata ity arthaḥ /
analyzed: śakyate iti arthaḥ
translated: this is the meaning.

original: tathā ca pātañjalasūtram abhyāsavairāgyābhyāṃ tannirodhaḥ YogaS / iti /
analyzed: tathā ca pātañjala sūtram abhyāsa vairāgyābhyām tad nirodhaḥ yogaḥ iti
translated: And in the same way, the Pātañjala Sūtra says: Its cessation is yoga by practice and dispassion.

original: mahābāho iti saṅgrāme tvayā yan mahāvīrā🔽api vijīyante /
analyzed: mahā bāho iti saṅgrāme tvayā yat mahāvīrā  api vijīyante
translated: O mighty-armed one, in battle, you conquer even great heroes,

original: sa ca pinākapāṇir api vaśīkṛtas tenāpi kim /
analyzed: sa ca pinākapāṇiḥ api vaśīkṛtaḥ tena api kim
translated: and even the Pināka-wielding one (Śiva) is brought under control by you. What is that?

original: yadi mahāvīraśiromaṇir mano nāmā prādhāniko bhaṭo mahāyogāstraprayogeṇa jetuṃ śakyate /
analyzed: yadi mahāvīra śiromaṇiḥ manaḥ nāmā prādhānikaḥ bhaṭaḥ mahā yoga astra prayogeṇa jetum śakyate
translated: If the foremost of great heroes, the mind named Prādhānika (born of the primordial matter), can be conquered by the application of the weapon of great yoga,

original: tadaiva mahābāhuteti bhāvaḥ /
analyzed: tadā eva mahā bāhu tā iti bhāvaḥ
translated: then alone you are mighty-armed, this is the idea.

original: he kaunteyeti tatra tvaṃ mā bhaiṣīḥ /
analyzed: he kaunteya iti tatra tvam mā bhaiṣīḥ
translated: O son of Kunti, do not be afraid in that (battle).

original: matpituḥ svasuḥ kuntyāḥ putre tvayi mayā sāhāyyaṃ vidheyam iti bhāvaḥ ////
analyzed: mad pituḥ svasuḥ kuntyāḥ putre tvayi mayā sāhāyyam vidheyam iti bhāvaḥ
translated: The idea is that I should render assistance to you, the son of my father's sister Kunti.

original: BhG /
analyzed: bhg
translated: BhG.

original: asaṃyatātmanā yogo duṣprāpa iti me matiḥ /
analyzed: asaṃyata ātmanā yogaḥ duṣprāpaḥ iti me matiḥ
translated: Yoga is difficult to attain, I think, by one whose mind is not controlled.

original: vaśyātmanā tu yatatā śakyo 'vāptum upāyataḥ ////
analyzed: vaśya ātmanā tu yatatā śakyaḥ vāptum upāyataḥ
translated: But by one whose mind is controlled and who strives, it can be attained by means of the prescribed methods.

original: śrīdharaḥ / etāvāṃs tv iha niścaya ity āha asaṃyateti /
analyzed: tu iha   iti āha
translated: Sri Sridhara: The conclusion here is stated as follows: Asamyanatmana, by one whose mind is not controlled.

original: uktaprakāreṇābhyāsavairāgyābhyām asaṃyata ātmā cittaṃ yasya tena yogo duṣprāpa prāptum aśakyaḥ /
analyzed: ukta prakāreṇa abhyāsa vairāgyābhyām asaṃyataḥ ātmā cittam yasya tena yogaḥ duṣprāpa prāptum aśakyaḥ
translated: Yoga is difficult to attain, i.e., cannot be attained, by one whose mind is not controlled in the manner described above by practice and detachment.
